Southampton's comeback from two goals down against Burnley on Sunday might have looked fortunate, but underlying data reveals they deserved the win.  Their Fantasy Premier League Threat score, which measures the quality of goalscoring chances, reached a gameweek 30 high of 352.  Danny Ings' individual Threat of 122 was second only to Harry Kane (126) and nearly matched Burnley's entire team total (125).  A deeper dive into the week's statistics can inform your fantasy strategy.

**Threatening Heights:**

* Mohamed Salah (Liverpool) GW1 - 161
* Dominic Calvert-Lewin (Everton) GW2 - 144
* Ollie Watkins (Aston Villa) GW15 - 140
* Harry Kane (Tottenham) GW3 - 138
* Harry Kane (Tottenham) GW30 - 126


Kane and Ings' triple-digit Threat totals represent only the 22nd and 23rd instances of a player reaching 100 in a single match this season. Ings shattered his previous best of 82, while Kane, who also boasts a 138 from gameweek three, now holds two of the seasonâ€™s top five Threat scores. Ings' performance ranks seventh.  With Tottenham's double gameweek in 32 approaching, overlooking the England captain seems incredibly risky.

**Spurs' Defensive Deficiencies:**

Despite Kane's attacking prowess, Southampton, along with Newcastle, dominated the Threat metric in gameweek 30.  Newcastle, surprisingly, generated the second-highest Threat total of the week (338), comfortably their best this season and only the third time they've surpassed 200. While Dwight Gayle led Newcastle with 78, their challenging upcoming fixtures suggest avoiding Tottenham defenders might be wise.

**James's Creative Spark:**

Chelsea's heavy defeat to West Brom offered little solace, but Reece James shone with a league-leading Creativity score of 66.  Creativity, which measures the potential of passes to become assists, mirrors Threat for goals.  A defender topping this metric is significant.  Chelsea, despite playing with 10 men, were one of two teams to generate more Threat than their opponents but still lose.

**Wolves' Emerging Opportunity:**

Wolves, the other team to out-Threat their opponents in a losing effort, appeared to have West Ham's number despite a slow start.

The two men, Jonathon Radcliffe and Valentine Spencer, stood in the middle of nowhere, a dusty road winding back towards the city.  A midday breeze whipped sand around them. There was no trace of any vehicle that might have brought them to this desolate spot.  Radcliffe, clad in a tough leather coat and high boots, cut a stark contrast to Spencer, whose attire consisted of sharply lined slim trousers and a finely tailored silk shirt, conspicuously lacking sleeves.  Despite their differing tastes, they were firm friends, the kind who often saved each other's lives â€“ one rarely seen without the other.

"Why did you have to announce it?" Radcliffe questioned, his gaze fixed on Spencer. "Why didn't you just do it?"

Spencer, the smaller of the two, pushed his spectacles back up his nose with a delicate forefinger. "Because this way we're living life."

"As opposed to...?"

"I don't know. Being boring. The point is, Jon, it has been announced, and we are obligated."

"Obligations have placed us in danger quite a bit lately, Val," Radcliffe countered, his eyes scanning the road where occasional horse-drawn carriages and steam-carriages interrupted the monotony.

"Obligations are usually best avoided, I agree. But this time it's important. Trust me."

They had set their meeting spot; now they waited. Their contacts were due to arrive, though the wait promised to be lengthy. A half-hour passed before the first group of police appeared.  Their wagons pulled up at the side of the road, the officers immediately falling into a nervous discussion, clutching fliers in their hands.

"In a moment," Radcliffe murmured to Spencer, "they are going to walk up here and arrest us. Care to let me in on the plan?"

"It's really simple. They can't arrest us yet because we haven't done anything illegal."

"But we were planning on it."

"I know. That's why I put it on the poster," Spencer replied, a hint of mischief in his voice.

"The same posters that you put up all over town?"  Radcliffeâ€™s incredulity was evident.

Spencer shrugged. "We had to let Leem know where to meet us somehow."

"Carrier pigeon would have been a lot less.... loud," Radcliffe grumbled.

"Ostentatious," Spencer corrected.

"That word is ostentatiousâ€¦"

Their exchange was interrupted by a policewoman.  Jumping down from a wagon, she approached, identification held high in one hand, a rolled-up parchment gripped tightly in the other.  An uneasy smile played on her lips.

"Spencer and Radcliffe, I presume? The notorious sky pirates?"

"That's us," Spencer responded, tipping his hat. "Rather warm out here today isn't it, officer?"

"Is that why you cut the arms off your shirt?" she asked, suspicion lacing her tone.

"I lost them in a bet last night," Spencer explained smoothly. "Drunkards gamble for the strangest things, you know. Anyway, I presume you're here to arrest us?"

"I am."

"You can't," Radcliffe interjected. "We haven't done anything illegal yet."

The policewoman unfurled the parchment. Spencer grinned, indicating Radcliffeâ€™s identical copy. "We have our own. Although I do appreciate you bringing it along.â€

With a sigh, the policewoman began to read aloud, her voice clipped and official:  "I, Valentine Spencer, hereby arrange to meet with Leem and his gang on the Main Road at High Noon precisely eight miles outside of town. I will bring my business associate Jonathon Radcliffe and we will engage in illegal activities. I trust our reputation precedes us. Sincerely, Valentine Spencer and Jonathon Radcliffe. PS; That's Spencer and Radcliffe, the two sky pirates who have bounties on their heads in twelve counties. Captains of the Starchaser."

She looked up, her confusion evident. Spencer simply nodded.

"That's what I wrote. What questions do you have, Mira?"

"You know my name?"

"Of course. You've been chasing us for some time. Dockman warned us when we landed that you'd probably come gunning for us. I thought we would give you a fair chance."

Increasingly bewildered, Mira glanced at Radcliffe, who shrugged.  "Don't look at me. I'm as in the dark as you are."

"Mira," Spencer addressed the policewoman, "can I make a suggestion? As you can't arrest us until you see us do something illegal, I suggest you take a seat on your wagon over there or you are going to get awful tired. Either that or stay with us and we can play some games?"

"What kind of games?"

"The kind where I can win a pair of sleeves."

Thunder crossed Mira's face, quickly followed by a furious retreat to her wagon, barking orders at the other officers.  Radcliffe turned to Spencer, his voice low. "I don't appreciate being kept out of the loop on this one, Val. Just a warning will be good."

"Admit it, you're enjoying this. The adrenaline rush has got to be worth it," Spencer retorted with a grin.

"Yea, I am," Radcliffe conceded. "But if we end up in prisonâ€”"

"â€”againâ€”" Spencer finished.

"â€”then I reserve the right to be angry at you."

"Right reserved, friend. Now just hush up, there's an entire wagon of police there waiting for us to say something incriminating."

Semantic textual similarity (STS) and information retrieval (IR) tasks have been principal measures for tracking the progress of dense representation models (Agirre et al., 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016; Cer et al., 2017; Thakur et al., 2021).  While STS remains a common evaluation metric in sentence representation research, it is known for its limited real-world applicability (Neelakantan et al., 2022; Muennighoff et al., 2023b), inherent ambiguity (Deshpande et al., 2023), and performance orthogonality with IR and other downstream tasks (Reimers et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2021; Xiao et al., 2023a).

In the era of large language models (LLMs), Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) (Lewis et al., 2020; Neelakantan et al., 2022; Xu et al., 2023; Gao et al., 2023) has become a favored alternative to standard end-to-end generative language models (OpenAI, 2023; Touvron et al., 2023). This shift is driven by LLMs' inherent weaknesses regarding factual errors stemming from hallucinations (Ji et al., 2023), outdated knowledge (Vu et al., 2023), limitations with long-tailed knowledge (Kandpal et al., 2023; Malaviya et al., 2023), and reasoning failures, such as in logical deduction (Berglund et al., 2023).

RAG is employed differently across various NLP tasks:

* **Knowledge-Intensive Tasks:** RAG retrieves up-to-date and reliable knowledge references (Vu et al., 2023; Malaviya et al., 2023), which serve as new prompts for LLMs to extract information and formulate responses. This mitigates hallucinations (Ji et al., 2023) and reduces the need for frequent LLM fine-tuning.
* **Reasoning-Dependent Tasks:** RAG fetches the most relevant chunks from extensive inputs to guide LLM focus, for example, in multi-hop question answering where reasoning across multiple documents is required.  Reasoning with such long contexts is challenging even for LLMs with extended context windows, and impossible for those with shorter ones (Xu et al., 2023).

Despite the promise of dense retrievers for knowledge-intensive tasks, they struggle to retrieve reliable and cite-worthy references (Malaviya et al., 2023) compared to state-of-the-art proprietary LLMs used independently (OpenAI, 2023). This highlights a weakness in retrievers' ability to assist LLMs.  This discrepancy is amplified in reasoning-intensive tasks, where RAG often shows inconsistent gains or even performance degradation compared to standalone LLMs (Bai et al., 2023; Xu et al., 2023).

Given the complex role of dense representation models in the LLM era, accurately assessing their advanced language understanding capabilities is crucial.

Identifying conserved quantities has significant practical applications, driving decades of research in applied mathematics.  This work presents a novel data-driven methodology for learning the symbolic forms of conservation laws, minimizing data requirements and automating parameter selection.

Traditional approaches for discovering conservation laws include analytical methods, such as solving linear systems derived from stoichiometric matrices [2, 3, 4] for linear relations and employing more sophisticated techniques for nonlinear ones [5]. Lie group theory has also been extensively used [6, 7, 8, 9, 10].  Computationally, algorithms like manifold learning [11] and AI-PoincarÃ© 2.0 [12] learn conservation laws from dynamical system inputs.  The Sparse Invariant Detector (SID) [13] offers a non-black-box linear algebraic approach.

However, with the rise of data-driven modeling, the challenge lies in recovering conservation laws *without* a priori knowledge of system dynamics. Existing data-driven methods range from specialized approaches for Hamiltonian functions [14, 15] to more general neural network-based techniques like AI-PoincarÃ© [16] and ConservNet [17].  Other approaches leverage deep neural nets with Noether's theorem [18], manifold learning with optimal transport [19], and machine learning to identify both conservation laws and dynamical system structure [20]. Koopman theory combined with data-driven regression provides symbolic representations [1].  These methods typically require between 100 [20] and over 1000 data points [12], with higher-order systems potentially needing more.  Robustness to noise remains a key challenge.

This paper adopts an SVD-based null space estimation method, offering robustness and lower data requirements.  Often, as few as 20 points suffice for accurate recovery, even with substantial noise.  Beyond minimizing data needs, the method learns the *functional form* of the conservation law(s), a feature shared with the sparse identification paradigm used in [1].  Challenges associated with this approach include choosing appropriate functional libraries and optimality thresholds.

To address these challenges, we develop a unified data-driven approach for automatically selecting the optimal learning library and polynomial degree.  This approach utilizes a sequence of data transformations, including SVD decomposition and echelon form reduction, letting the data guide the identification of the singular value gap and inform subsequent optimization parameter selection.  The method's effectiveness is demonstrated on various problems, including multiple and nonlinear conservation laws, with applications in physics and biology.

Our proposed methodology offers two key advantages: (1) robust discovery of conservation laws with minimal data, even in the presence of noise and without knowledge of underlying dynamics, and (2) automated selection of optimal libraries and thresholds based on estimated noise and the singular values of the library matrix.  Due to the ease of SVD and LU-based implementation, this framework integrates well with other learning approaches.

The waves slammed against the ship, sending spray over the deck. We were constantly soaked.

It began with a knock on my door.  I opened it to find Don Reist, who invited me to Europe on a cattle boat. I couldn't refuse.

It was 1945. World War II raged in Europe, leaving many countries devastated.  These ravaged nations desperately needed supplies and food, aid that I and others would deliver.

Forty-four nations united to form the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA). The organization hired "Seagoing Cowboys" to care for the horses, cows, and mules being shipped overseas. Don and I signed up for the job.

We arrived on August 14th, the day the war in the Pacific ended.  Don and I received our seaman's papers and boarded the SS *Charles W. Wooster*, bound for Greece.  Our cargo: 335 horses and their feed.

Being 18 was precarious; I could have been drafted.

By my discharge in 1947, I had completed nine tripsâ€”the most of any Seagoing Cowboy. The cattle trips were incredible, yet demanding.  Crossing the Atlantic from the eastern United States took about two weeks, plus we cared for and fed the animals three times a day.

Helping on my Aunt Katie's farm had prepared me somewhat for the work, but not for the dangers we faced.

Life on board was also enjoyable. We played baseball, volleyball, and other games.

The experience heightened my awareness of others and their needs. This awareness has stayed with me throughout my life, realizing that people around the world needed what I had.  Helping them was more rewarding than I could have imagined, and I learned a great deal from the experience.  More than anything, the trip solidified my friendship with Don, the one who had invited me on this adventure.

In "A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves," Luke's actions during World War II exemplify the principle of reciprocal altruism: helping others often leads to help in return.  It's crucial to understand and value what matters to others.  Some might find entertainment in observing conflict, but witnessing our allies embroiled in war while we remain passive is deeply unsettling.

Helping others generates a cycle of support.  This could manifest in practical assistance, like help with a building project, or in shared experiences, such as preparing a meal together.  Regardless of the form it takes, offering assistance is inherently the right course of action.  Whether initiating a favor or reciprocating one, the act of helping strengthens bonds and builds community.

Doing what's necessary is paramount.  People consistently prioritize the needs of their families, friends, and even pets.  Failing to address these crucial needs can lead to regrettable choices in the future.

Luke's aid during World War II demonstrates this principle in action.  Countless individuals in that conflict sacrificed their lives to protect what they held dear.  Similarly, many would willingly make the ultimate sacrifice for loved ones.

I disagree with the concept of driverless cars.  Primarily, I believe they are inherently dangerous. The requirement for a driver to remain alert negates the very purpose of autonomous driving.  Alerts designed to recapture the driver's attention shouldn't be necessary. If a car is truly driverless, it should function without any human intervention.

While I understand the appeal for long road trips, where one person typically bears the burden of driving, and the desire for drivers to rest, the safety implications are concerning.  Even if a sleeping driver is alerted to an impending accident, their reaction time and judgment could be severely impaired.  Expecting someone roused from sleep to instantly take control in a critical situation is unrealistic.  They might panic and exacerbate the situation, leading to further collisions. The potential for catastrophic failures with driverless technology is simply too high.

While many anticipate the widespread adoption of such technology, I'm reminded of the dystopian future portrayed in the movie Wall-E, where people became obese and indolent due to reliance on automated systems.  Do we really want to follow that trajectory?  The United States already struggles with obesity, and eliminating the need to drive will further reduce opportunities for even minimal physical activity.

In conclusion, I believe driverless cars are a misguided innovation.

Ever felt bored in class, wishing for something more engaging than a tedious lecture?  Facial Action Coding System (FACS) technology offers a potential solution. By recognizing facial expressions and interpreting emotions, FACS can revolutionize the classroom. It can gauge student interest, identify when a spark is needed, and even adjust the lesson's pace if a student becomes confused or frustrated.

Emerging technologies like FACS hold immense potential for education.  This system could significantly improve student performance and foster genuine interest in learning.  As noted by its creator, Dr. Paul Ekman,  "Six basic emotionsâ€”happiness, surprise, anger, disgust, fear, and sadnessâ€”are associated with characteristic facial muscle movements."  This classification system forms the foundation of FACS, enabling it to recognize student engagement levels and provide valuable feedback to teachers.

This technology could also pinpoint students struggling due to disinterest. Dr. Huang suggests, "A classroom computer could recognize when a student is becoming confused or bored. Then it could modify the lesson, like an effective human instructor." This adaptability could dramatically alter how students learn, catering to individual needs and preventing boredom by instantly adjusting the lesson.

Confusion, anger, and even depression can significantly impact a child's learning.  FACS could identify these emotional states, potentially alerting school counselors when a student needs support.  Dr. Huang emphasizes the importance of nonverbal communication, stating, "Most human communication is nonverbal, including emotional communication, so computers need to understand that, too."  This implies that FACS could also help students struggling with issues they might be hesitant to discuss, such as family problems affecting their schoolwork. By recognizing signs of depression, the system could help connect these students with necessary support.

This undated photo, provided by the United States Capitol Police, shows U.S. Capitol Police Officer Brian Sicknick, who died Thursday from injuries sustained during the riot at the U.S. Capitol.  A native of South River, New Jersey, Sicknick served in the New Jersey Air National Guard before fulfilling his lifelong dream of a career in law enforcement. He joined the U.S. Capitol Police in 2008.

Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a powerful paradigm enabling collaborative model training across numerous devices without direct data sharing, driven by the increasing prevalence of machine learning in the Internet of Things (McMahan et al. 2017; Imteaj et al. 2022).  Traditional FL employs a parameter-server (PS) architecture where a central server aggregates models and broadcasts updates (Kairouz et al. 2019). However, this centralized approach suffers from communication bottlenecks and potential server vulnerabilities (Lian et al. 2017).

Decentralized learning offers a promising alternative, utilizing peer-to-peer communication for faster convergence (Lian et al. 2017, 2018).  In this framework, each worker maintains a local model copy and collaborates with neighbors to achieve a consensus model.  However, data heterogeneity, a common challenge in both centralized and decentralized learning, can hinder performance. When data distributions vary significantly across workers, a single shared model may perform poorly on individual devices. Consequently, personalized decentralized learning, where each worker learns a tailored model (Vanhaesebrouck, Bellet, and Tommasi 2017; Dai et al. 2022), becomes crucial.

This paper advances personalized decentralized learning by leveraging the concept of shared representations.  Inspired by observations in centralized learning (Bengio, Courville, and Vincent 2013; LeCun, Bengio, and Hinton 2015), we exploit the idea that heterogeneous data, even with different labels, can share a common low-dimensional representation.  Following the pioneering work of Collins et al. (2021) in the centralized setting, we extend this principle to decentralized learning.  We propose that each worker's model comprises a shared global representation map (Ï•: R<sup>d</sup> â†’ R<sup>z</sup>) and a personalized local head (Î¸<sub>i</sub>: R<sup>z</sup> â†’ Y), where z â‰ª d.  This structure simplifies local optimization of the worker-specific heads. While Collins et al. (2021) analyzed linear global representations, we address the open questions of developing a fully decentralized algorithm for the general non-linear case and providing its convergence analysis.

Specifically, we introduce DePRL, a decentralized algorithm that alternates updates between global representation and local head parameters to solve the optimization problem min<sub>Ï•âˆˆÎ¦</sub> (1/N) Î£<sup>N</sup><sub>i=1</sub> min<sub>Î¸iâˆˆÎ˜</sub> F<sub>i</sub>(Î¸<sub>i</sub> â€¢ Ï•), where F<sub>i</sub>(â€¢) represents worker i's loss function.  In each round, workers update their local head and global representation using stochastic gradient descent, share updated global representations with neighbors, and compute a weighted average to achieve consensus.

Unlike conventional decentralized learning with a single shared model (Lian et al. 2017, 2018; Assran et al. 2019), DePRL involves coupled updates of local head and global representation parameters, requiring novel proof techniques for convergence analysis.  Our contributions are threefold:

* **DePRL Algorithm:** We introduce DePRL, the first fully decentralized algorithm that learns a shared global representation and personalized local heads for improved performance in heterogeneous data environments.

* **Convergence Rate:** We establish a new notion of Ïµ-approximation solution and provide the first convergence analysis for personalized decentralized learning with shared non-linear representations. We demonstrate a convergence rate of O(1/âˆšNK), where N is the number of workers and K is a sufficiently large number of communication rounds, indicating a linear speedup with respect to the number of workers. This result, highly desirable for large-scale decentralized systems, also guarantees consensus on the shared global representation while maintaining personalized local heads, offering insights into generalization to unseen workers.

* **Evaluation:**  We empirically validate DePRL's performance and theoretical findings through experiments on various datasets with representative DNN models, demonstrating superior performance in heterogeneous settings compared to existing baselines.

A fleet of a hundred thousand ships, each capable of obliterating a city from orbit, emerged from a wormhole. At the center, their mothership loomed large.  "We're coming out of the wormhole, General. No signs of any defences on the perimeter of the system," a voice reported.

"It's finally been a hundred years for the people of Earth," the great alien general addressed his command room, his long green tongue flicking in distaste.  "Perhaps I gave them too little time. This won't be much of a challenge."

The fleet entered Earth's system, holding position before a field of asteroids, the anticipated location for Earthâ€™s defenses. Hours passed. Scouts returned with nothing. System-wide scans for technology, even cloaking systems, yielded no results. A chill ran down the general's spine.  Had the Earthlings developed technology capable of hiding from them? The thought sparked excitement; a challenge he couldn't resist. Perhaps heâ€™d overestimated humanityâ€™s potential.

"Move our most advanced scouts towards Earth's known flight path. Send three. Losses are acceptable."

Several hours later, a live video feed flickered to life on the mothershipâ€™s command screen. A scout strolled casually down a deserted city street. "General, no one is here. We haven't seen an Earthling since we landed. Scout 45 reports the same. The buildings look abandoned for years."

"Not a single Earthling? No resistance? What's going on down there?" the general demanded, his voice laced with frustration.

The scout paused, flipping through a small booklet. The cover displayed a large airship. The general's eyes fixed on the image, a mixture of satisfaction and puzzlement.  They'd attempted larger space-faring vessels, but none had been detected. "I'm sorry, General," the scout continued, "but based on the science team's findings, I'm afraid you're not going to get the fight you were hoping for."

The general turned a dark shade of purple. "Blast it allâ€¦ let me guess? Disease? Mass extinction?"

"No, General." The scout turned the page. The general recognized a device eerily similar to their own wormhole generators.  "We believe mass migration."

The Facial Action Coding System (FACS) offers potential benefits in the classroom.  By analyzing students' facial expressions, FACS could identify confusion, boredom, or engagement with the lesson.  This has practical applications, particularly for students who hesitate to ask for help.  For instance, a classroom computer equipped with FACS could recognize a confused or bored student, prompting the teacher to offer assistance. This would be particularly helpful for students who, despite struggling, might not outwardly seek clarification. FACS could also provide valuable feedback, allowing teachers to adjust their lessons based on student engagement levels.  Imagine a scenario where a teacher, alerted by the system, proactively modifies their approach to re-engage a bored class.

However, the use of FACS raises valid privacy concerns.  Many students already express unease about being watched, evidenced by the number who cover their laptop cameras. Even those who dismiss such concerns might feel uncomfortable knowing their expressions are constantly monitored.  This discomfort, shared by some parents, could create resistance to FACS implementation.

While FACS offers intriguing pedagogical possibilities, student and parent comfort levels are paramount.  Ultimately, fostering an environment where students feel comfortable expressing their needs and feedback directly remains crucial.  While technology can play a supporting role, it shouldn't replace open communication between students and teachers.

For over thirty years, the question of the Face on Mars has lingered: alien artifact or natural landform?  Despite intense media scrutiny, evidence overwhelmingly supports the scientific conclusion that the Face is a natural formation, much like a butte or mesa common in the American West, contrary to the claims of conspiracy theorists.

NASA's Viking 1 orbiter first captured the formation in 1976, describing it as "an enormous head nearly two miles from end to end."  A few days later, when NASA released the image to the public, speculation about alien life ignited.  As the article "Unmasking the Face on Mars" explains, "The 'Face on Mars' had since become a pop icon. It has starred in a Hollywood film, appeared in books, magazines, radio talk showsâ€”even haunted grocery store checkout lines for 25 years!"  The article continues, "Some people think the Face is bona fide evidence of life on Marsâ€”evidence that NASA would rather hide, say conspiracy theorists."  The media amplified the idea of extraterrestrial intelligence, often disregarding scientists' explanations.

Eighteen years after the Viking missions concluded, the Mars Global Surveyor, a Mars orbiter, flew over Cydonia (the region where the Face is located) for the first time. The orbiter team captured an image ten times sharper than the original Viking photographs.  These photos revealed a natural landform, not an alien monument.  On April 5, 1998, during a cloudless summer day on Mars, the Mars Global Surveyor passed over Cydonia again, close enough for the orbiter team to acquire an exceptionally detailed image using the camera's maximum resolution. Each pixel in the 2001 image represented 1.56 meters, compared to 43 meters per pixel in the best 1976 Viking photograph.

Jim Garvin, chief scientist of NASA's exploration program, explained, "As a rule of thumb, you can discern things in a digital image three times bigger than the pixel size. So, if there were objects in this picture like airplanes on the ground or Egyptian-style pyramids or even small shacks, you could see what they were!"  The image of the Face actually depicts the Martian equivalent of a butte or mesa. "It reminds me most of Middle Butte in the Snake River Plain of Idaho," Garvin noted. "That's a lava dome that takes the form of an isolated mesa about the same height as the Face on Mars."

Amazon Prime Video is a popular streaming service competing fiercely with Netflix, Hulu, and other platforms.  It offers a vast library of films and TV shows spanning various genres, from action and adventure to period dramas, romantic comedies, and science fiction.  If you're looking for steamy TV shows, Amazon Prime has several options, though availability may vary by region. Here are a few examples:

**Available on Amazon Prime Video:**

* **The Affair:** This American drama explores the emotional fallout of extramarital affairs, starring Dominic West, Ruth Wilson, Maura Tierney, and Joshua Jackson. The series ran for five seasons and concluded in 2019.

* **Californication:** This comedy-drama follows Hank Moody (David Duchovny), a novelist battling writer's block, substance abuse, and complicated relationships with his longtime lover and daughter. The series aired for seven seasons on Showtime.

**Not Available on Amazon Prime India:**

* **Secret Diary Of A Call Girl:** Based on the blog and books by Belle de Jour, this British drama follows Hannah Baxter, a prostitute living a double life.  Beyond the steamy scenes, the series offers compelling drama.

* **Strictly Se*ual: The Series:**  Based on the independent film, this miniseries follows the romantic adventures of two modern women.  It features well-executed steamy scenes and explores deeper truths about love and life.

* **Girls:** This HBO original series, created by and starring Lena Dunham, follows four friends navigating their twenties and figuring out what they want from life. The series won a Golden Globe Award in 2013 for Best Television Series â€“ Musical or Comedy.

Imagine a computer that can detect your emotions â€“ whether you're happy, sad, or confused. This isn't science fiction; it's the potential of Facial Action Coding System (FACS) technology. While the idea of emotion-reading technology might seem intriguing on a personal level, its value truly shines in the classroom.

Developed with the help of Professors Thomas Huang and Nicu Sebe, FACS can benefit not only students but also teachers and administrators. As mentioned in paragraph six of the original text, a classroom computer equipped with FACS could recognize student boredom or confusion.  Imagine you're having a bad day and face a daunting five-page essay.  While you might try to hide your frustration, this technology could subtly inform your teacher of your emotional state, allowing them to adjust accordingly, perhaps postponing the assignment to a better time.

This technology offers a significant advantage in understanding student engagement. Teachers could gain insight into how students genuinely feel about an activity or project.  What the teacher perceives as engaging might actually bore the students, leading to decreased effort and suboptimal learning.

Beyond the classroom, this technology has applications in online advertising.  Paragraph six also mentions how online ads can adapt to your reactions. If you smile at a web ad, a similar one might appear next.  Frown, and the advertisement changes. This principle, applied to classroom computers and iPads, could personalize the learning experience and filter out distracting or irrelevant content.  While pop-up ads are often dismissed as annoying, the ability to tailor them to individual emotional responses could transform them into a more useful tool.


This technology holds promise for improving the learning environment and personalizing digital experiences.  It allows for a deeper understanding of individual emotional responses, paving the way for more responsive and effective educational strategies.

"Take a seat, Miles," the doctor said, his eyes kind, a gentle smile gracing his lips. "How are you feeling today?"

Miles, a long-term resident of Westgate, squirmed in his chair, unable to control his twitching.

"I'm Doctor Erdely, and I'm here to help our inmates with recovery and mental health. Even condemned men like you, Miles. Four life sentences is a long time."

Miles blinked rapidly, avoiding the doctor's gaze.

"Miles, you and I have doctor-patient confidentiality. This is a private place. No cameras. No guards. Just us," the doctor said confidently.

He slid his chair closer to Miles.  "So I think I can be very honest with you," he whispered. "Your new inmate, Vasquezâ€”he's not who he says he is."

Miles rippled with nervous energy.

"You know what he really is, don't you?"

Miles hesitated.

"One of *them*."

Miles shook his head back and forth. "No, no, no, no, no, no, no, no."

"Milesâ€¦"

"No, no, no, no, no, no!"

"At lights out tonight, you know what you have to do. For all of us. For your soul. Miles. Look at me."

Miles glanced up briefly before the doctor grabbed his neck, forcing their eyes to meet.

"You *have* to do it, Miles. He's one of *them*!" the doctor growled. "Do you understand?"

Miles nodded.

"Good. I'll show you out."

The doctor escorted the cuffed Miles to the door. After the guards led Miles away, the warden approached.

"Doctorâ€¦ this isn't part of our arrangement. Iâ€”"

The doctor cut the warden off with a press of a finger to his lips.  He turned and looked at a guard.

"Send Vasquez in."

An Innocent Mistake

The sweet snow hid his tracks, a blanket of white.
Hands shoved deep in his pockets, he took flight,
Leaving no proof that he'd ever trod there,
Wishing the snow would conceal his red candy wrapper.

For a moment, the sun caught the young boy's brown eyes.
He watched the sunset's beauty, a smile starting to rise.
His tongue savored the last of the small, sweet treat,
But his smile froze as his eyes met his father's.

Perched on the doorstep, framed by the doorway,
His father's figure was unmistakable on this late winter's day.
A desperate swallow, a silent, whispered prayer,
That the only witnesses to his candy were the snow and the air.

He greeted his father with a smile and respect,
But quiet dread gnawed at him, knowing what to expect.
Piano notes drifted through the house to his ears.
If only he were his sister, that would quell all his fears.

The hope of escaping unnoticed, fleeting and free,
Was extinguished by a hand placed firmly on his shoulder.
The same hand reached quickly into his small pocket,
His face draining of color, his back against the proverbial wall.

"You have red on your face, son. Oh, what have you done?
And look here in my hand, a red wrapper. I demand
A complete explanation to placate my humiliation."
He held his breath as he replied, "An innocent mistake."

His father stared, veins bulging in his head.
"We will deal with this after our evening bread.
But be it innocent mistake or guided adulteryâ€”"
He took a deep, ragged breath.  "You know what to expect from me."

The boy could barely eat, knowing what was coming.
No one spoke to their father; one look from his eyes would send anyone running.
Sister and mother ate with hearts full of pity,
Knowing he'd tasted the forbidden city.

The meal finished, cleared in a dark and pallid mood.

The temple doors swung open, revealing a sight I hadn't anticipated.  In front of me, where I'd expected marble plinths, golden frescoes, and a proud display of the finest weapons forged by men and gods, was a chaotic mountain of unsorted weaponry. Every legendary sword, every fabled weapon, lay jumbled together in a bureaucrat's nightmare.

"Excuse me," I said, struggling to keep my voice level.  I turned to the Curator, who appeared older than the crumbling temple itself. "Does the Great Hall always look like this?"

She hesitated, a flicker of embarrassment in her eyes. "Well, you see, we, err, we get so much coming in that I just don't know what to do with them all, and before I know it they just start..."

"Piling up?" I offered.

A dry chuckle escaped her lips. "Young man, every hero who's come here has faced the same predicament! If Samson could climb halfway up just to find a jawbone, I'm sure you'll do just fine."  With that, she turned and left me alone in the Great Hall, her footsteps echoing until only my own thoughts remained.

I turned towards the towering pile of weapons. Following my training, I closed my eyes and focused on the task at hand.  The Curator had said each weapon possesses a voice, and though many may call out, only one would choose me, earning me the title of Hero.

As I stood there, waves of whispers filled the room.  "Have the dragons returned? Take me and bring your people salvation." "Is the RagnarÃ¶k come? Now is your hour of need, and I am here to serve." "The people crave a champion, and only I can deliver them one." "The end days are coming, boy. You need me to drive the demons away."

Dozens of voices swirled around me, each claiming to be the sole key to my people's salvation.  Shivering, I squeezed my eyes shut, overwhelmed by the cacophony. How could I choose just one? I longed for a moment of silence to think.

Gradually, the voices faded, leaving the Great Hall quiet.  Hours passed, but still, I hadn't found my fated weapon. Had I failed to become a Hero?

Then, a voice cut through the silence. "Isn't that much better? I hate it when it gets too loud in here. No way to make myself heard."

It was *my own voice*, emanating from somewhere within the pile. A shiver ran down my spine. This was it.  This was the feeling of being chosen.

"Where are you?" I asked, my voice cracking after the long silence. Darkness had fallen within the Great Hall.

"Around the other side of this heap, near the bottom," my own voice replied.  Suppressing the unsettling sensation of hearing myself speak, I carefully navigated the mountain of weapons, avoiding the sharp edges of spearheads and battle-axes.  As I reached the back, I spotted my fated weapon.

I oppose using technology to read faces because sometimes our expressions don't accurately reflect our feelings. A computer can misinterpret them.

The program's creation involves a computer generating a 3-D model of a face, with all 44 facial muscles programmed to mimic human movement.  However, this doesn't mean the computer understands our emotions. It only recognizes the physical configuration of facial muscles.

Therefore, using this technology in a classroom is problematic. A teacher might wrongly conclude a student is angry based on a computer's interpretation of their facial expression, even if the student is happy or sad.

Similarly, if the program indicates a student is happy when they are actually sad, their friends might tease them, leading to unwanted conflict and hurt feelings.

It's simply not possible for a computer to reliably determine our emotional state.

Self-driving cars are often touted as the future of transportation, with many believing they will soon become the norm. However, I argue that autonomous vehicles are destined to fail for several key reasons, ranging from the impracticality of implementation to significant safety concerns and the simple fact that many people genuinely enjoy driving.

For many, driving is not a chore but a cherished pastime, a stress-relieving activity, and a source of personal freedom.  Self-driving cars would eliminate the simple pleasure of a leisurely drive, the thrill of a spontaneous road trip, and the immersive experience of controlling a vehicle.  Autonomous vehicles, presumably reliant on GPS, would require pre-planned destinations, stripping away the spontaneity that defines many driving experiences. Replacing this with a motionless passenger experience is unlikely to appeal to a significant portion of the population.

Furthermore, the financial and logistical challenges of adapting our current infrastructure for autonomous vehicles are staggering.  Our roads are designed for human drivers. A sudden shift to self-driving cars would necessitate a massive overhaul of the entire highway system. The costs associated with installing motion sensors, GPS monitoring systems, and replacing existing public transportation with autonomous taxi services would be astronomical, placing an unreasonable burden on taxpayers.

Safety is another paramount concern.  While human error contributes to accidents, entrusting driving to computers introduces a whole new set of risks.  Software glitches, hacking vulnerabilities, and unforeseen technical malfunctions could lead to catastrophic consequences, potentially causing widespread accidents and traffic chaos. The inherent unpredictability of these issues makes autonomous vehicles a far greater threat than human drivers.

In conclusion, the widespread adoption of autonomous vehicles is simply not feasible.  The exorbitant cost of infrastructure modifications, the inherent safety risks, and the disregard for the enjoyment many find in driving all point to the failure of this technology. For those who value the freedom and experience of driving, sticking with a traditional vehicle remains the best option.

Juno-nominated singer-songwriter Craig Cardiff, known for his intimate performances and community engagement, led a songwriting workshop for Algonquin College students on February 7th.  Sipping a pink fruit smoothie, clad in wool socks, Cardiff sat on the floor of the small stage in the Commons corner lounge, guitar in hand. "Everybody here has something to share," he announced to the dozen participants gathered before him.

Cardiff, a seasoned performer at the college, often incorporates workshops before his concerts.  "Why not get the chance to connect with people?" he explained, highlighting his belief in the power of community involvement.  He routinely conducts these sessions in schools.

The students, eager to learn from the experienced musician, embraced the opportunity. "I really wanted to do something new," shared Anastasia Young, a first-year travel and tourism student, in an interview with the Times. Although not a musician herself, Young recognized the value of refining one's craft. "Weâ€™re always trying to make ourselves better in every area of our lives," she observed. "So why not in writing, or in our craft?"  She emphasized the benefit of feedback, believing that the perspectives of others can lead to "opportunities for growth" and collaborative projects. For Young, the presence of others in the creative process is a necessity, not a luxury.

The workshop involved small groups writing songs within a time limit set by Cardiff, culminating in performances for their peers. Among the participants were Jake Devine and Felix Ducharme, both first-year introduction to music industry arts students.  Devine, self-described as "pretty stubborn," admitted he had never co-written a song before but was open to the experience.  His motivation was clear: "I wanted to see someone elseâ€™s perspective on how they write songs.â€  Similarly, Ducharme acknowledged his solitary writing habits but reconsidered after the workshop.  "I donâ€™t write with people, but I think maybe I should start," he reflected. "Different perspectives arenâ€™t so bad."

Cardiff expressed his hope that the workshop would foster connections beyond the session. "We spend all our time alone then wonder why we get stuck," he pointed out, underscoring the advantages of collaborative songwriting.

Following the workshop, Cardiff treated the intimate audience to a performance, his smooth voice and rhythmic fingerpicking echoing through the candlelit room.  He shared the story behind his song "Boy Inside the Boat," explaining that it was inspired by the negativity he witnessed in the worldâ€”deaths, terror attacks, and more.  "Thereâ€™s always a surplus of bad things if we look for them," he remarked.

Electronic Arts (NASDAQ:EA) saw its stock price rise $0.56 to $93.88 during Wednesday's trading, with a volume of 3,906,864 shares traded. The company boasts a market capitalization of $27.96 billion, a PE ratio of 23.89, a P/E/G ratio of 1.54, and a beta of 1.12.  Other key financial ratios include a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.19, a quick ratio of 2.99, and a current ratio of 2.82.  The stock's 52-week range spans from a low of $73.91 to a high of $151.26.

Oppenheimer raised its price target for Electronic Arts from $88.00 to $110.00, maintaining an "outperform" rating.  They also provided earnings estimates for Electronic Arts: Q3 2020 at $1.86 EPS, Q4 2020 at $1.19 EPS, and FY2021 at $3.95 EPS. This positive outlook contrasts with other recent analyst activity.  Robert W. Baird lowered their price objective to $90.00, while Benchmark, citing a valuation call, reduced theirs to $120.00 but maintained a "buy" rating.  Other adjustments include SunTrust Banks setting a $105.00 price objective with a "buy" rating, MKM Partners lowering theirs to $112.00 with a "buy" rating, and Wedbush reiterating a "buy" rating with a reduced price objective of $111.00. For the same quarter of the previous year, the company earned $1.31 EPS. Analysts project Electronic Arts will post 3.67 EPS for the current fiscal year.

Recent insider activity includes CEO Andrew Wilson selling 29,000 shares at an average price of $103.00 on April 1st, and insider Chris Bruzzo selling 12,000 shares at an average price of $102.11 on February 11th. The idea of driverless cars in today's world presents both exciting possibilities and serious concerns. While the prospect of autonomous vehicles appeals to many, perhaps due to increasing convenience or simply the novelty of the technology, we must carefully consider the potential benefits and drawbacks before fully embracing this future.

One major advantage often cited is the potential for increased safety.  Proponents argue that removing human error from the equation could drastically reduce accidents.  However, this assumes flawless technology, which is unlikely in the early stages of development.  As seen with systems like BMW's "Traffic Jam Assistant," introduced in 2013, even partially autonomous features still require driver oversight and engagement.  The driver must remain alert and ready to intervene, negating some of the theoretical safety benefits.  If a driver is required to maintain focus, the question arises: what is the true purpose of a driverless car if it still needs a driver?  As Dr. Werner Huber suggests, perhaps we need to rethink the concept of "driving fun" in the context of autonomous vehicles.

My concern is that fully autonomous vehicles could lead to complacency and decreased vigilance.  Drivers, freed from the task of driving, might be tempted to sleep, use their phones, or engage in other distracting activities, becoming less prepared to react in emergencies.

Deep neural networks have proven incredibly powerful across a wide range of machine learning tasks. However, they are highly sensitive to small input perturbations, which can dramatically reduce their accuracy (Carlini & Wagner, 2017; Szegedy et al., 2013). In natural language processing (NLP), these adversarial examples often take the form of spelling mistakes, synonyms, or other meaning-preserving transformations that alter the network's prediction (Ebrahimi et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2019a; Michel et al., 2019).

This paper addresses the problem of training robust models over natural languageâ€”or more generally, sequences over a finite alphabetâ€”that are resilient to adversarial examples.  The discrete nature of the adversarial space for sequences makes it difficult to explore efficiently using gradient-based optimization techniques common in computer vision.  A common approach to achieving robustness is adversarial training (Goodfellow et al., 2015; Madry et al., 2018), which has been extensively researched in computer vision and, more recently, in NLP (Ebrahimi et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2019a; Michel et al., 2019).  Given a perturbation space R(x) for a sample xâ€”for example, if x is a sentence, R(x) might contain all possible misspellings up to a certain limitâ€”adversarial training incorporates an adversary into the training objective. Instead of computing the loss for a sample (x, y), it computes the loss for the worst-case perturbed sample z âˆˆ R(x). Formally, the adversarial loss for (x, y) is max zâˆˆR(x) L(z, y, Î¸).

The central question of this paper is: Can we train models robust against rich perturbation spaces over strings?

The practical challenge lies in computing this worst-case loss. The perturbation space R(x) can be enormous, making exhaustive enumeration impractical, especially in NLP tasks where R(x) should contain semantically equivalent inputs, such as variations of x with typos or synonyms.  Therefore, we need to approximate the adversarial loss.  Two classes of approximation techniques exist:

* **Augmentation:** This class computes a lower bound on the adversarial loss by exploring a finite subset of R(x). This is typically done using gradient-based attacks like Hot-Flip (Ebrahimi et al., 2018) for NLP or Projected Gradient Descent (PGD) (Madry et al., 2018) for computer vision.  These techniques effectively augment the training set with perturbed samples.

* **Abstraction:** This class computes an upper bound on the adversarial loss by overapproximating, or abstracting, the perturbation space R(x) into a set of symbolic constraints that can be efficiently propagated through the network.  Interval abstraction, for instance, has been used in several works (Mirman et al., 2018; Gowal et al., 2019; Huang et al., 2019).

Both techniques can be suboptimal: augmentation may severely underapproximate the worst-case loss, while abstraction may severely overapproximate it.  Furthermore, they exhibit complementary utility, performing well on some perturbation spaces but not others. For example, Huang et al. (2019) showed that abstraction works better for token substitutions, while augmentation-based techniques like Hot-Flip (Ebrahimi et al., 2018) and MHA (Zhang et al., 2019a) are more general, applying to token deletions and insertions as well.

Venus, sometimes called the "Evening Star," is one of the brightest objects in the night sky, easily spotted even by amateur stargazers.  However, this nickname is misleading, as Venus is a planet, not a star.  Often referred to as Earth's "twin" due to its similar size and density, Venus is occasionally the closest planet to Earth in terms of distance, too.  Because of this relative proximity, humans have sent numerous unmanned spacecraft to this cloud-draped world.  Each mission has been unmanned for good reason: no spacecraft has survived the landing for more than a few hours.  On Venus's surface, temperatures average over 800 degrees Fahrenheit, and the atmospheric pressure is 90 times greater than Earth's.  Interestingly, Venus has the hottest surface temperature of any planet in our solar system, even hotter than Mercury, despite being farther from the sun.

Long ago, Venus may have been largely covered by oceans and could have supported various life forms, much like Earth. However, studying Venus from orbit provides limited insight into ground conditions.  The dense atmosphere prevents most light from penetrating, rendering standard photography and videography ineffective.  Researchers are working on innovations to allow their probes to survive long enough to contribute meaningfully to our knowledge of Venus.  NASA, for example, is exploring approaches like simplified silicon carbide electronics, which have survived for three weeks in a chamber simulating Venus's harsh surface conditions.

This paper investigates tensors of minimal border rank, motivated by algebraic complexity theory and the study of secant varieties.  We aim to overcome complexity lower bound barriers identified in [22, 26] and provide new "minimal cost" tensors for Strassen's laser method, which are not subject to the barriers described in [2] and [10]. These new tensors are not binding, circumventing the limitations established in [10] for minimal border rank binding tensors.

A tensor T âˆˆ C<sup>m</sup> âŠ— C<sup>m</sup> âŠ— C<sup>m</sup> = A âŠ— B âŠ— C has rank one if T = a âŠ— b âŠ— c for nonzero a âˆˆ A, b âˆˆ B, c âˆˆ C. The rank R(T) is the smallest r such that T is a sum of r rank one tensors. The border rank R(T) is the smallest r such that T is a limit of a sum of r rank one tensors, or geometrically, the smallest r such that T âˆˆ Ïƒ<sup>r</sup>(Seg(P<sup>m-1</sup> Ã— P<sup>m-1</sup> Ã— P<sup>m-1</sup>)) âŠ† P(C<sup>m</sup> âŠ— C<sup>m</sup> âŠ— C<sup>m</sup>).

A concise tensor (formally defined in Â§1.1) cannot be expressed in a smaller ambient space.  A concise T âˆˆ C<sup>m</sup> âŠ— C<sup>m</sup> âŠ— C<sup>m</sup> has border rank at least m. If the border rank equals m, T has minimal border rank.

Self-supervised pre-training, leveraging large-scale unlabeled data, has revolutionized Natural Language Processing (NLP) (Devlin et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2019; Conneau et al., 2020; Jiao et al., 2020a).  However, its adoption in Machine Translation (MT) has been limited. This is likely due to the architectural mismatch between pre-training models (e.g., Transformer encoder) and Neural Machine Translation (NMT) models (e.g., Transformer encoder-decoder).

To address this gap, sequence-to-sequence (Seq2Seq) pre-training models like MASS (Song et al., 2019) and BART (Zhu et al., 2019; Lewis et al., 2020) have been proposed.  mBART (Liu et al., 2020) further extends BART by training on massive multilingual data, significantly improving translation performance.  While previous approaches often focused on pre-training only the encoder (Lample and Conneau, 2019), mBART pre-trains a complete autoregressive Seq2Seq model by reconstructing masked input sentences. This raises a crucial question: what is the specific contribution of the jointly pre-trained decoder?

This work provides a deeper understanding of state-of-the-art Seq2Seq pre-training, focusing on the role of the jointly pre-trained decoder.  Through experiments on various WMT and IWSLT benchmarks across different language pairs and data scales using mBART-25 (Liu et al., 2020), we analyze the decoder's impact. Our findings (Â§ 2.2) reveal that jointly pre-training the decoder:

* Produces more diverse translations with varied word orders, necessitating multiple references for accurate evaluation on large datasets.
* Consistently reduces adequacy-related translation errors compared to pre-training the encoder alone.

Despite the performance benefits, we also identify side effects stemming from discrepancies between pre-training and fine-tuning (Â§2.3):

* **Domain Discrepancy:** Seq2Seq models are often pre-trained on general domain data (e.g., arXiv), while downstream tasks focus on specific domains (e.g., news). This necessitates further adaptation during fine-tuning.
* **Objective Discrepancy:** NMT models learn to translate between languages, while Seq2Seq pre-training focuses on input reconstruction. This leads to over-estimation and hallucination with noisy input, exacerbating the beam search degradation problem already associated with Seq2Seq pre-training (Liu et al., 2021).

To mitigate these issues, we introduce two strategies (Â§3): in-domain pre-training and input adaptation during fine-tuning.  In-domain pre-training bridges the domain gap by continuing mBART pre-training on in-domain monolingual data. Input adaptation involves adding noise to the source sentences during fine-tuning, facilitating knowledge transfer from the pre-trained model.

Our experiments demonstrate that in-domain pre-training significantly improves translation performance, while input adaptation enhances robustness. Combining both yields a high-performing NMT system.  Further analysis shows that our approach reduces domain discrepancy, particularly for low-frequency words, and alleviates over-estimation and beam search degradation.

## Reliving 1960s Dorchester, Ted Williams, and the Red Sox with Paul Korins

Author Paul Korins returns to his roots in his new book, "A Summer to Remember with Ted Williams," revisiting his beloved Dorchester and the era of his idol, Ted Williams.  This is Korins' fourth novel for young readers and the second installment in his Sammy Baker time travel series.

â€œI grew up in Dorchester from age 11 to 16, and Ted Williams was my idol,â€ Korins shared. â€œSeeing him at Fenway Park was a rare and thrilling occasion.â€

In this stand-alone sequel, 12-year-old Sammy once again utilizes the magic typewriter from Korins' first novel. This time, instead of traveling to the Great Depression, Sammy finds himself transported to 1960, landing right in the Red Sox dugout beside â€œTeddy Ballgame.â€  Williams becomes Sammyâ€™s mentor, offering life and batting advice. While Sammy relishes his time with his newfound hero, he also yearns for home and must complete a mission before returning.

â€œThere is a puppy love interest,â€ Korins teased, adding that the story offers something for everyone, even those who aren't baseball enthusiasts.  During his time travel adventure, Sammy takes on the persona of his uncle, Terry, and even finds a bit of romance.

Dorchester itself plays a significant role in the book.  â€œReaders will recognize landmarks,â€ Korins noted.

Korins, who has dreamt of being a writer since he was 11, draws inspiration from his own childhood experiences. â€œYou have to be a reader to be a writer,â€ he emphasized. â€œI always had a book in my hand.â€  Saturday mornings were spent at the local toy store, adding the latest Hardy Boys Mystery to his collection.  Just like his character Sammy, Korins played Little League.

â€œI had a great childhood,â€ he reminisced. â€œThe character is a composite of the kids I knew, the kids I grew up with.â€ He remains connected with many of these childhood friends, who continue to inspire his writing. â€œI wrote for that age group because I enjoyed that age. There is part of me in every book.â€


Though his reading list now includes authors like Richard Russo and Colum McAnn, Korins offers advice for aspiring writers, particularly those interested in writing for young readers. "Donâ€™t write down," he cautioned.

The rusted city gates groaned closed, the sound swallowed by the roar of our engines. Outpost guards pointed, wagering on our chances.  We were dropping loot packs, desperate to pick up speed. Tony, in the lead, hurled a duffle bag overflowing with books.  The gate was feet from sealing us out for the night. We surged forward. Tony lunged, his foot catching on a stray reinforcement pole. A sickening crunch, then an agonizing scream that made even the jaded guards flinch.

We froze, staring at the mangled mess of garage door, pipes, barbed wire, and stop signs. Tony's foot, still trapped, hung grotesquely. We heard the medic sprinting, amputation kit undoubtedly in hand. Tony, I realized with a chilling jolt, was the lucky one. Iâ€™d trade both arms to be inside the safety of the camp.  I turned to my group. Amy hid tears under her hood. Zip pounded the ground, cursing. Dave, as always, stood silent, seemingly daring the encroaching darkness to challenge him.

The sprawling clouds swallowed the mountain peak, a grim omen.  We all knew the guards' methods.

â€œWe have to go back down,â€ I said.

â€œFuck you,â€ Zip spat.

Amyâ€™s voice was thick with sobs. â€œYou know what will happen.â€

â€œWe can take it,â€ I insisted, gesturing to Amyâ€™s rifle and Zipâ€™s AR.  â€œWe have weapons for a reason.â€

â€œHeâ€™s right,â€ Dave said quietly, his voice a low rumble.

â€œFineâ€¦â€ Zip conceded.  â€œBut you lead.â€

â€œLetâ€™s go,â€ I said, and we descended into the swirling ocean of clouds.

The descent was shrouded in deepening gloom, our morale plummeting with every foot. Dave, of course, remained stoic. We reached the infamous â€œShit Show,â€ a sprawling bandit market where everything was for sale and no one was safe. Kidnappings, drug deals, and shootouts were the norm in this shantytown.  We navigated the chaotic streets, avoiding eye contact, our ragged clothes and visible weapons providing a veneer of belonging.

I approached a weapons merchant, knowing we needed more firepower to reach the next town.

â€œWatcha need, hot shot?â€ the old man rasped, gesturing to his arsenal.

I pointed to a wicked-looking sawed-off shotgun, two of its four barrels rusted and crudely bolted on.

â€œItâ€™ll turn anything into a nice red slush,â€ he grinned, laying it on the counter. â€œAnything else?â€

Amy stepped forward, rummaging through a bucket of ammo. She selected ten bullets, each marked with a different colored skull.

â€œEach colorâ€™s a different effect,â€ the merchant explained, dragging on a cigarette. â€œI wonâ€™t bore ya with the details, but the darker the color, the deader your targetâ€™s gonna be.â€

Daveâ€™s voice was cold. â€œThe bunker buster grenade. Two of them.â€

The merchantâ€™s eyes gleamed. â€œWell, thisâ€™ll be one helluva payday for me. How ya wanna pay?â€

I hefted the duffle bag of books onto the counter. The merchantâ€™s cigarette tumbled to the steel, his apprentice taking a hasty step back.

â€œHowâ€¦?â€ he stammered, staring at us.

â€œWeâ€™re scrappers,â€ I said. â€œFound a school a few miles out. Are you taking them or not?â€

â€œYe-yeah, yeah,â€ he said, snatching the bag and glancing nervously around. â€œAnd come back if you get any more.â€

We grabbed our new gear and headed towards the next city. Thatâ€™s when they attacked.

An armored car slammed into the makeshift booze fountain in the center of the market, a mounted LMG spitting fire.

This story strains belief, but I swear it's true. I witnessed it unfold, every agonizing step of the way.

First, you have to understand Nick's obsession with Instagram modelsâ€”those impossibly attractive women who've monetized their looks without resorting to stripping.  They fill their feeds with barely-there workout clothes, sponsored drinks, and endless selfies. Nick was hooked. He'd crane his neck at the gym, hoping to spot someone even remotely similar.  Sometimes we did, but they never measured up.  I'd point out a beautiful woman, and he'd flex in the mirror, saying, "Dude, she's not as hot as Demi Rose. Think I'm vascular enough?"

Second, Nick was technologically inept. I had to set up his Facebook account. It wasn't that he was stupid, just incredibly lazy. I couldn't believe he didn't already have one.  He kept complaining about not being able to follow anyone on Instagram, so I grabbed his phone, created his account, uploaded a few photos, followed some of those models for him, and *voilÃ *â€”Nick was on Instagram. He loved it. He finally started posting his own pictures.

Finally, the last piece of this tragic puzzle.

It was a Monday after work, leg day. Nickâ€™s attendance was always hit-or-miss. That day, he was supposed to be there.  I pulled up to his apartment as usual and found the place swarming with police.

It was about Nick.  When I told them I was his friend, they let me in.

Nick was dead at his computer.

He looked emaciated, his muscles withered to thin cords. He was so dehydrated his veins, especially in his shoulders, bulged grotesquely. His pants were around his ankles.  His fingers were skeletal. One hand still gripped the mouse.

"What happenedâ€¦?" I stammered.

One officer almost laughed at my bewilderment. "Isn't it obvious? Dude died jerking off to his own Instagram."

Another officer frowned. "Look at him.

The year was 1980-something. David Draiman, a young boy from Brooklyn, enjoyed the typical pursuits of his era â€“ perhaps Slinkys, penny boards, or those short shorts. One night, his life took a dramatic turn. He was abducted, not by earthly beings, but by the gods of rock.  While heâ€™d dabbled in music, listening to the Beatles and other popular artists, it was merely a pastime. This night changed everything.

Following his otherworldly encounter, David moved from city to city, his focus shifting from observant Jewish tradition to the heavy riffs of rock and roll. He rebelled against conformity, seeking his own definition of "normal."  He formed bands in various cities, including Los Angeles and Milwaukee, prioritizing his newfound religion of rock over everything else, much to the chagrin of his parents.  But David was driven by a force beyond their understanding, a mission bestowed upon him by the rock gods.  As the 80s faded, so did his childhood idols. A new era dawned â€“ the age of heavy metal.  The first time David heard Metallica, the sheer power and beauty of the music sent shivers down his spine. The symphony of vocals, guitar, bass, and drums captivated him completely.

The following decade saw the rise of bands like Nirvana, Sublime, and Red Hot Chili Peppers, further fueling Davidâ€™s passion.  In 1996, fate intervened. A struggling band called Disturbed parted ways with their lead singer, and David answered the call.  He was nearing the summit of Rock Olympus, and the gods, who had patiently watched his ascent, bestowed upon him their final gift.

A strange ailment began to plague David.  He felt an unknown force building within him, an energy he couldnâ€™t control.  It worsened with each passing day, defying any medical explanation.  Music, his usual solace, offered no comfort.  Melodies became distorted, chords refused to resolve. Only a few specific patterns resonated, hinting at a deeper meaning. David realized this was a test from the rock gods.  After months of struggle, the pressure became unbearable.  "After constant struggle, months of battling it, he could no longer contain it. It was itching to break out, to explode into the world."

The ship parted the clouds like an old sailing ship parting the waves, a rough, slipshod thing â€“ "like a flying cinderblock," my father called it â€“ before landing with a gentle thunk on the other side of my TV screen.  The media, the President, dignitaries I'd never know, all were there to witness it. A rope ladder, not even wood, descended from a port in the cinderblockâ€™s side. "Goddamn it," my father laughed, stuffing crackers into his mouth, "they can't even build a ladder out of *wood*, why in the Hell is anyone afraid of these guys?"  But I was rapt.

A plume of smoke obscured the figures emerging from the ship. A *clank* echoed as the first touched Earth â€“ a momentous occasion, we'd learn later.  Four figures walked through the dissipating smoke.  The reporter muttered a disbelieving, "*well fuck me*," before announcing the obvious: "Human! The visitors appear to be human!"

Clinking and clanking, they approached the assembled dignitaries.  Their expressions were of tearful reminiscence, echoing memories passed down through stories, paintings, and legends. One paused, touching a purple flower with the tenderness of a first love. The others waited patiently before joining him for the final steps.  Hands were outstretched, and the visitors clasped arms, nodding and speaking in elegant, unintelligible phrases.

Suddenly, a man in the back, the Italian Prime Minister as we later learned, pushed his way through the presidents and premiers of the worldâ€™s superpowers.  He shouted, interrupting the visitors, grasped a hand, shook it vigorously, and spoke rapidly. The visitors turned, bemused.

Thatâ€™s when I noticed their outfits. The metallic shoulder plates, the jangling mail skirts, the helmets protecting their noses, the crestsâ€¦ I *knew* them.  They were different, the colors altered, the metal a dull, dark hue, the crests unfamiliar, but I *knew*.

The reporter yelled at the Prime Minister, a spectacle unfolding, his career likely over.  Then the Prime Minister laughed, a boisterous sound.  "The fuck is wrong with this guy?" my father muttered, "like the cat that ate the canaryâ€¦"

The visitors laughed too. It was Greek, a language the Prime Minister, unlike the rest of the assembled dignitaries, understood.  The visitors, it turned out, were descendants of ancient Greeks, saved from barbarians by Diana, goddess of the moon, and cast into space. Now they had returned to reclaim what they had lost. Some Earth leaders invoked *our* gods.

The lead centurion whistled. Another figure scurried from the ship, catching a thrown object. He ran towards the procession. Shouts arose: "It's a spear! It'sâ€¦ is that blood?"  He hurled the spear.  It landed at the feet of the visitors. The centurion spoke one word that needed no translation: *War*.

They never made it back to their ship.  They drew their swords, attempting to kill the Prime Minister, and were gunned down. Hundreds more poured from the ship, fighting to the death.  My father laughed. "They think that can kill us? All this giant ships and moon-talk and shit, and they try to stab us?"  The world echoed his derision.

Then, at nine the next morning, it went dark.  Unbelievably, impossibly dark.  We brushed it off at first. A day or two, whatâ€™s the harm?  But the darkness persisted. Days bled into weeks, then months, then years.  They began confiscating our satellites, casting them adrift. Even the ISS was flung away.  But there was no other aggression, onlyâ€¦ darkness.  Those accustomed to the dark corners of the Earth knew what this meant.

Many died, including my father, killed in the ensuing chaos.  As he lay dying, I felt my own mind slipping.  And in the sky, Diana hung, where she hangs to this day.

The man in the hoodie slid a small envelope across the table with gloved hands. We were at the diner at Fourth and Union, just as he'd requested.  I couldn't see his face â€“ normal for most clients meeting in the flesh â€“ but I could hear him snickering.  

"The mark?" I asked.

He nodded, his body shaking with suppressed laughter. He was doing that pulsating thing people do when theyâ€™re trying to stifle a laugh, the kind that jiggles their whole frame.  Whatever. The money was most important.

I opened the envelope and saw a picture of myself.  Looking up at the man, I snarled, "Is this a fucking joke?"

He pulled off his hoodie.  The sight underneath was too horrifying to describe.

***"SURPRISE MOTHERFUCKER!!"***

He laughed all the way to Hell.  Even after he'dâ€¦ finishedâ€¦ he kept asking if I got the joke.

My name is Luke Bomberger, and I'm a Seagoing Cowboy. Joining the Seagoing Cowboys program changed my life, and I believe it could change yours too.  Why?

Because you get to help people around the world.  The Seagoing Cowboys cared for horses, cattle, and mules shipped overseas as part of a massive relief effort.  Forty-four nations joined together to form UNRRA (the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration) to help war-torn countries rebuild their food supplies and agricultural infrastructure.

For example, my friend Don Reist and I sailed to Europe in 1945. World War II had just ended, leaving many countries devastated.

Beyond the important work, there's also the opportunity to see the world.  You'll experience once-in-a-lifetime trips and create lasting memories.  Life aboard ship, especially on the return voyages after the animals have been unloaded, is a unique experience.

We kept ourselves entertained with baseball and volleyball games, table tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling, and other games.

Being a Seagoing Cowboy opens up the world to you.  It's more than just an adventure; it's a chance to make a real difference.  While the work is demanding, the rewards are immense.  You'll have a lot of fun and help countless people, and that's what truly matters.

This "Innovative Practice" paper examines Reusable Learning Objects (RLOs), exploring their effectiveness based on current literature and practice, highlighting successful strategies and areas for improvement.  We begin by defining Learning Objects and reviewing relevant literature. Then, we analyze the RLO life-cycle, encompassing authoring, revising, producing, delivering, and ultimately, reusing.  This analysis informs the introduction of key factors and features designed to enhance sharing and reuse effectiveness.  Finally, we present the CourseGen framework and tool-set, which focuses on creating detailed, flexible, and reusable learning objects. This tool-set comprises open-source software and a substantial collection of open-source learning objects for Software Engineering and Entrepreneurship courses.

What are Reusable Learning Objects (RLOs)?  While Noguera et al. [1] define Learning Objects as "reusable entities either digital or otherwise used to support learning," this definition, while intuitive, is somewhat circular.  The term originated in the 1990s and has appeared in the literature with various similar definitions. We can better understand RLOs by breaking down the term:

* **Reusable:** This implies that a learning object created for one purpose can be repurposed in different contexts by different users.  This requires a flexible and appropriate level of granularity, modularity, and composability, as well as a non-proprietary data format and appropriate originator permissions, each of which will be discussed further.
* **Learning:**  While intuitively connected to learning, teaching, or education, the scope of "learning" could be broadened.  Reuse opportunities exist beyond strict learning contexts, such as grading policies or teacher-student agreements.
* **Object:** Likely originating from Object-Oriented Programming, "object" in the RLO context signifies a small, reusable unit with an abstracted internal structure.

"Don't be ashamed of crying," I said. "You're not the only one battling this addiction. Many of my patients suffer from it."  He continued to weep, bloody tears spotting the third carpet I'd bought that week. Thankfully, my assistant had the foresight to cover the couch in plastic. My patients occasionally leave behind a finger, a foot, or even half their skin, torn from their bones after colliding with a table. Many of my former patients would have been appalled, but we live in different times. Different times, different measures, as the saying goes. The apocalypse changes everything.

When the dead started rising, I was barely scraping by as an assistant to the professor.  "The Freud of the 23rd century," they called the old fool.  If you ask me, he was a buffoon, his authority derived solely from his title, his meaningful research having ceased years ago.

"I'm not the only one?" he abruptly raised his head, as if my words had finally penetrated his decaying brain.

"Of course not," I soothed, acutely aware of the need to manage his volatile temper.

"But why am I doing it? Why? I know I could accomplish so much in my afterlife." He shook his head violently, his right earlobe nearly landing on my suit.

"Many of my patients experience the same guilt. Like you, they know killing humans is wrong."  Something in my voice must have betrayed me, because his slimy, yellow eyes narrowed skeptically.  The truth was, I didn't agree with the sentiment. It had been a pleasure watching one of his zombie friends rip that 23rd-century Freud apart.  The other assistants had fled in terror. I, however, was delighted as Jackâ€”I think his name was Jackâ€”tore off the professor's left arm and finally snapped his neck. It sounded like breaking a chocolate bar.  I watched with satisfaction as Jack sucked the blood from the professor's head, weeping tears of blackish blood. Then he saw me. We were alone in the university's fifth-floor hallway. Jack advanced. With a distinct sense of displeasure, I envisioned myself meeting the same fate.

My job is awful. There are good moments, of course, like when I get to play with the puppies and bathe them. Or when I'm allowed to comfort those we euthanize.  There was a big uproar a few months ago about whether kill shelters should be considered death row and euthanasia a death penalty, now that they can talk. Because they *can* talk. And since this recent development, their final words aren't just garbled nonsense.

My hands trembled as I led him from his cramped cage. It wouldn't be long now. He whined during his bath but didn't resist, nor did he struggle as I dried him. Their silence is what scares me. It makes me wonder if something will go wrong. When I asked him to lie down, he complied, gazing up at me with mournful brown eyes.

"I didn't want to do it," he finally confessed. I squeezed my eyes shut, unable to watch the unnatural movements of a canine mouth forming human words. His voice was soft, filled with sorrow. "I understand why you're doing this, but I want you to knowâ€¦ she had a cigarette, and it was headed for my eye. Not on accident. You understand, right? She's not a nice lady."

"I understand." *Threeâ€¦ twoâ€¦ oneâ€¦ breathe.* I opened my eyes, meeting his gaze. He was a handsome dog, with well-defined brow ridges and soft ears. I gently stroked one â€“ they never said I had to be a cruel executioner. "We'll look into it." Surely I could convince them. They recorded these sessions, after all. He licked my wrist, his lips parting in what looked like a doggy smile. "I'll make sure we look into it."

"Thank you." He whimpered as I inserted the catheter. His eyes closed.  I felt my own eyes welling up.  At least this would be peaceful. As the fluid flowed from the IV bag, I petted his side, feeling it rise and fall with each shallowing breath.
