Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson, speaking at MOD St Athan in Wales on Friday, accused the Welsh Government of hindering military investment in Wales by refusing to engage in talks with Westminster.  Mr. Williamson, accompanied by Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns, met with RAF and Army representatives to discuss the base's future and proposed developing new barracks at the site.

He stated, â€œWe want to see more service personnel based here in Walesâ€¦bringing wealth, prosperity, and opportunity.â€  Mr. Williamson claimed the Welsh Government is "resisting" and "not properly engaging" with proposals to increase the number of army personnel stationed at St Athan.  He emphasized the potential economic benefits of new barracks, including job creation and increased prosperity, but expressed frustration with the Welsh Government's alleged refusal to consider the proposals necessary for this investment.  â€œSadly all the options we keep putting forwardâ€¦is something the Welsh Government are resisting and not properly engaging with us about," he added.  "This will have an enormous impact on the local economy, guaranteeing jobs, guaranteeing prosperity, but sadly at the moment the Welsh Government is refusing to look at the optionsâ€¦to make that investment happen.â€

A Welsh Government spokesman countered this claim, welcoming military investment but highlighting the UK Government's cancellation of the Â£14bn Defence Training Academy at St Athan in 2010, a project that had promised 2,000 jobs.  The spokesman explained, â€œOur interests in St Athan result from the Defence Training Academy, a legacy defence project which was costly for Wales and which the MOD subsequently cancelled before completion.â€ Following the cancellation, the Welsh Government promoted the area as a business park, successfully attracting Aston Martin with a commitment to continued development.

While reiterating their welcome of UK Government investment in Welsh military infrastructure, the spokesman pointed to the availability of â€œhundreds of acresâ€¦including around 50 acres within and adjacent to West Camp,â€ suitable for accommodating new personnel without impacting the business park.

The stark white walls of the room amplified the contrast between the two figures within. One, in standard prison uniform, was human. The other, in a suit, was not quite.  "Did you ever steal candy when you were younger?" the suited figure began. "That first time â€“ terrifying, wasn't it? Heart thumping, convinced the cops were coming, almost backing out, but unable to resist."

"Only degenerates steal candy," the prisoner retorted.  "You're talking about *killing* someone." His hands balled into fists within the restraints.

The suited man leaned forward, judgment heavy in his gaze.  The confession had been surprisingly easy. A slip during interrogation, a detail only the victim and her mother could have known, and the rest had followed. â€œItâ€™s no different," the prisoner continued, a disturbing relish coloring his tone. "After the first time, the candy gets so much sweeter. Enjoying something you shouldnâ€™tâ€¦ itâ€™s incredible.  Do you know the exact DNA sequence of the common house tabby? I do. I shouldn't. But the fact that I doâ€¦ it's so sweet."  He arched his back, a soft moan escaping his lips, before snapping forward, hungry eyes locking onto the suited figureâ€™s flat stare.  â€œAnd the best part? You never know what youâ€™re going to get. Do you know what the female orgasm feels like?â€

â€œYouâ€™re sick,â€ the suited man stated, his expression not one of disgust, but a strange disappointment. "How did it take me so long to find you? It'll be good to watch the world slip from your eyes.  Then Iâ€™ll know I've made this world a better place."

"I'll be the first, you know," the prisoner said.

"First what?"

"The first death row kill since the change, of course." A flicker of something like pride crossed the prisonerâ€™s face. "I think about it at night. The poor sap pushing the buttonâ€¦ heâ€™s not murdering me. That would be you. Or the families pushing for my head. One or the other. We will see.â€ He was right. Capital punishment had been globally abolished twenty years prior. Wars had all but vanished. The world wasâ€¦ peaceful. Except for a few.

â€œIâ€™m sure Iâ€™ll be fine,â€ the suited man said, rising to his feet. â€œItâ€™s been twenty years. We know how things work now. Anyway, Iâ€™m done with you.â€  He walked out.


The viewing room was oddly bright.  Darren, in the room for the first time, noted its disuse â€“ a consequence of the twenty-year moratorium. The families of the victims filled the seats: parents, lovers, children, siblings. *Children.* Darren was taken aback. Who would bring a *child* to an execution?  Each person in the room, presumably, had reason to hate the man strapped to the table.

Adam, the condemned, was unsettlingly calm, even happy.  Probably reliving another stolen memory.  The unfairness of it struck Darren â€“ the sheer volume of precious moments stolen from so many. Children, lovers, sons, daughters.  A perverse cross-section of humanity violated.

The biting wind whipped around Leo as he lay perched atop the Tokyo skyscraper, the city's million lights twinkling below like a frozen swarm of fireflies. He had his target locked in his sniper rifle's sights. *Alright, I got you now. Another 50k in the bank for me. Where should I travel after this? Maybe Argentina? Must be warm there this time of year.*

**CRACK**

A sharp sound ripped through the air, spinning Leo around. *What the fuck?*

**SCRAPEâ€¦**

*What theâ€¦*

His eyes, still adjusting from the scope's digital glare to the rooftop's darkness, made out a tall figure cloaked in black.  A long brown stick, tipped with something that glinted in the city's reflected light, was clutched in its hand.  The figure stood motionless, about ten yards away. An icy chill snaked down Leo's spine, the air growing colder around him. He saw his breath plume in the frigid air.

Quickly, Leo drew his sidearm and fired five rounds at the figure.  Nothing. The figure remained unmoved. Shock gripped him.

Then, an unnaturally deep voice, resonating with an unearthly power, boomed around him.

â€œ**HELLO LEO. LET'S PLAY A GAME.**â€

Leo scrambled to his feet, pulling a knife from his hip holster. â€œWhatâ€¦ whatâ€¦ who are you?â€

A booming laugh, laced with a scratchy, grating undertone, shook him to his core.  â€Oh Leo, you are more familiar with me than perhaps anyone.â€

Leo stared, speechless.

â€You've seen me in your dreams. You've felt me watching you. You've felt my icy touch when you kill your next victim. You've even prayed to me. You know who I am.â€

Leo gulped.

â€Yes, that's right. You know.â€

*I can't believe this is happening,* he thought.

â€œWhat do you want?â€

The creature laughed again. â€It's not about what *I* want. It's about what *you* want, Leo.â€ A long, raspy breath echoed in the night.  Leo found himself wondering, absurdly, why the creature needed to breathe.

"Dude! You got ta do something! The world is gonna end. There will be *no* more days off if you don't do anything! Do you not understand what is happening right now?!"

"You don't understand. This is like... my first day off in months. All I wanted to do today was sleep in late, watch some bad movies, and chill the fuck out."

"Dude! I hate to do this, but you know your mom's gonna die! Your brother!

Change detection in remote sensing plays a critical role in rapid humanitarian assistance and disaster response (HADR) for natural disaster relief.  Improvements in computer vision models for change detection are crucial for accurate identification of areas requiring assistance, enabling effective planning and resource allocation by HADR organizations and communities.  The development of large-scale labeled change detection datasets has fueled this progress.

Self-supervised learning methods have recently become the dominant approach for pretraining these models due to their simplicity and ability to leverage large unlabeled datasets.  This is particularly relevant in remote sensing and Earth observation, given the abundance of multiview and multimodal data.  For instance, Manas et al. [2] demonstrated performance gains by pretraining with Sentinel-2 imagery of the same location captured in different seasons as multiple views. Similarly, Heidler et al. [3] showed effective learning and improved downstream performance by pretraining on an audiovisual dataset of aerial image and audio pairs, outperforming traditional transfer learning approaches.

Several recent studies have explored self-supervised learning for change detection, primarily using pre- and post-event imagery as multiple views. Leenstra et al. [4] used a large dataset of Sentinel-2 imagery to train a model to predict spatial overlap between patches as a pretext task.  Chen et al. [5] employed a contrastive framework with pre- and post-event imagery. However, to the best of our knowledge, no prior work has explored contrastive training using overlapping remotely sensed imagery and 3D surface maps as a pretext task.

I strongly support the development of smart/driverless cars for several compelling reasons: their potential for increased fuel efficiency, enhanced safety features, and reduced driver burden.

These vehicles promise significant fuel savings, potentially using half the fuel consumed by current taxis.  This efficiency, combined with their personalized routing, offers greater flexibility than public transportation options like buses.  Replacing traditional taxi services with driverless cars also eliminates the potential for human driver error. While the passenger becomes solely responsible for their safety, the removal of human unpredictability from other drivers significantly enhances overall road safety.

Smart cars excel at detecting and responding to road hazards. Equipped with advanced sensors and technology, they can react to dangers faster than a human driver, preemptively applying brakes and mitigating potential collisions. Features like "Traffic Jam Assistant," while still requiring driver alertness, automate much of the driving process in challenging traffic situations, increasing both safety and convenience.

Furthermore, these vehicles offer a safer driving experience even with reduced driver control.  While some might find this paradoxical, the consistent and predictable nature of automated systems minimizes risks associated with human error.  As Werner Huber, a project manager from BMW, points out, this shift requires us to "interpret driving in a fun new way."

Yamaha announced today the release of firmware update v3.5 for TF Series Digital Mixers during Pro Light + Sound 2017. This free update, scheduled for release at the end of May 2017, significantly expands the utility of the TF Series by adding the acclaimed Dugan Speech System automixing capability.

The TF Series offers ease of operation and an advanced touch-panel based TouchFlow Operationâ„¢ interface, popular for a wide variety of applications. Ideal for both new and experienced engineers, these fully featured consoles allow users to achieve a great sounding mix quickly.  Firmware v3.5 enhances this ease of use even further.

Developed in cooperation with Dan Dugan Sound Design Inc., the update includes the original, innovative automatic microphone-mixing algorithm, similar to the capability found in Yamaha's QL and CL Series consoles. The Dugan automixer can be applied to up to eight channels in the TF Series. It automatically raises the gain of active microphone inputs while lowering the gain of inactive ones, creating a consistent overall mix level. This eliminates complex fader operation in scenarios like presentations or panel discussions with multiple microphones.  Furthermore, the advanced Dugan algorithm maintains a safe feedback margin, ensuring high quality, clear sound.

â€œBy incorporating the Dugan automixer in TF v3.5, we have even more flexibility in applications where TF Series mixers are used,â€ states Nithin Cherian, product marketing manager, Pro Audio Products, Yamaha Professional Audio. â€œThis includes conferences, boardrooms, corporate presentations, theater, broadcast, houses of worship, and teleconferencing.

"I can't believe he's dead..."  Ah crap, it's Sean's brother. Don't overdo it.

"Neither can I."  Truthfully, it *is* hard to believe, even though I was there. Even though I lay belly-down on his back, yanking the cheap paracord tighter against his neck until my arms hurt. I even checked his pulse.

Sean's brother (what's his name again?) seems satisfied with my answer. I briefly squeeze his shoulder, offering a show of support. His eyes lock on mine for a second, trying to thank me. He opens his mouth, but no sound comes out. Nodding instead, he turns and wanders back through the clusters of mourners.

I join a small group sharing stories about Sean's life. Small, almost meaningless actions he performed while alive now confirm the message we've been hearing all afternoon: Sean was a really great guy. Ordinary stories now glow. An unremarkable landscape is caught in this perfect sunset. I knew this would happen, dreaded coming today, but it's not as irritating as I expected.

"What about you?" Crap, what are they talking about?

"Sorry, what were you asking? I was lost in thought."

I'm still stuck on the unanswered question. *Why* did I kill Sean? Granted, he'd been a bit of an asshole since I've known him. But that grating feeling I got around him shouldn't have been enough to drive me to *this*.  There's no single action that stands out as unforgivable. I can't even remember all the conversations where he was self-centered, or degraded women, or spouted some cocky know-it-all philosophy. And I'm pretty sure he would have slept with that beyond-drunk girl at his housewarming party if I hadn't stayed behind to prevent it. Hearing stories of him harshly putting down his students doesn't help his case either.

The truth is, I didn't do it for the students or to defend anyone. I did it because I wanted to kill someone. The urge had been in me since at least middle school, returning every few months a bit stronger.

Manchester Cityâ€™s 2-1 loss to Lyon on Wednesday, their fourth consecutive Champions League defeat, lays bare the challenge facing the Premier League champions.  Despite racking up 100 points domestically last season and being tipped as favorites for the European title, City struggled in front of a partially empty Etihad Stadium.  The 15,000 empty seats highlight the nagging question of when the Champions League will capture the imagination of the club's fans and players alike.  While other contenders like Liverpool, Real Madrid, and Juventus thrive on fervent home support in European competition, City have yet to cultivate a similar atmosphere. This lack of home advantage is a stark contrast to their domestic dominance. Pep Guardiola's absence due to suspension was cited as a contributing factor to the loss, but the reality remains that City are the first English club to lose four straight Champions League matches, three of which were at home. This disappointing streak underscores the significant hurdle they face in translating their Premier League success to the European stage.

El Ministerio de Industria, EnergÃ­a y Turismo ha publicado la resoluciÃ³n que pone en marcha el nuevo sistema, el cual comenzarÃ¡ el 1 de julio. Las comercializadoras y distribuidoras tendrÃ¡n un plazo de adaptaciÃ³n hasta el 1 de octubre para implementar el nuevo mecanismo. Los ficheros de intercambio de informaciÃ³n entre las empresas y otros aspectos tÃ©cnicos deberÃ¡n aplicarse antes del 1 de enero de 2016.

**Â¿QuÃ© es un contador inteligente?**

Los contadores inteligentes son digitales y estÃ¡n programados para la telegestiÃ³n por parte de la empresa distribuidora, integrÃ¡ndose en el sistema. Generalmente, las compaÃ±Ã­as elÃ©ctricas los instalan siguiendo sus propios planes y un calendario gubernamental que obliga a sustituir todos los contadores antes de 2018.  Industria aÃºn no ha fijado una fecha lÃ­mite para la integraciÃ³n en el sistema.

**Â¿Con esto ya recibo la factura hora a hora?**

Existen dos opciones: que su comercializadora independiente ya ofrezca este servicio (algunas ya lo hacen) o que tenga la tarifa regulada, conocida como Precio Voluntario al PequeÃ±o Consumidor (PVPC).  Puede acceder al PVPC independientemente de si estÃ¡ o no en el mercado libre, siempre que su potencia contratada sea inferior a 10 kilovatios (kW). El PVPC eliminÃ³ las subastas elÃ©ctricas trimestrales y reimplantÃ³ la facturaciÃ³n bimestral. Si el contador es analÃ³gico, el recibo se emite cada dos meses con un precio adaptado a perfiles de consumo.

**Â¿A quÃ© hora serÃ¡ mÃ¡s barata la luz?**

Generalmente, el mercado mayorista registra precios mÃ¡s bajos en las horas de menor demanda (de medianoche a mediodÃ­a) y mÃ¡s altos en las de mayor consumo (tarde y noche hasta las 23:00 horas). La energÃ­a eÃ³lica puede reducir los precios en dÃ­as ventosos, mientras que los dÃ­as anticiclÃ³nicos suelen traer precios mÃ¡s altos.

Text-to-image generation models, such as Stable Diffusion [20], GLIDE [15], and DALLÂ·E 2 [18], have significantly advanced, producing high-quality images from textual prompts. While traditional Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) generate synthetic images from a Gaussian distribution, text-to-image models require textual prompts to create corresponding images, resulting in wider use and greater popularity. These synthetic images have diverse applications, including visualizing novel scenes, generating illustrations for advertising, and creating otherwise unphotographable scenarios. However, they also present societal risks, such as the potential for misuse in spreading misinformation.  Furthermore, text-to-image generative models may impact the art industry by enabling the production of fake artwork.  Therefore, it is crucial to identify the generative model responsible for a given AI-generated image (Figure 1). In other words, we need to accurately attribute unknown-source images to their source models.

Post-hoc analysis of the intrinsic characteristics of content generated by different models allows for source attribution.  Existing research on AI-generated image attribution is primarily training-based, focusing mainly on image ownership from GANs. Some studies utilize classification networks to determine the source of generated content based on inherent feature differences between models.  Yu et al. [31] designed three variant classification networks based on mainstream convolutional neural networks, capable of attributing images generated by four common GAN models. Girish et al. [7] proposed an iterative framework for discovering images generated by unknown GANs, incorporating trainable networks, outlier detection, (Figure 1: The application scenario of AI-generated fake image attribution), clustering, merging, and optimization modules.  Bui et al. [2] introduced RepMix, a GAN fingerprint technology based on representation blending and a novel loss function, significantly improving semantic generalization and robustness to perturbations compared to previous methods. Hirofumi et al. [8] leveraged the latent recovery capability of GAN-generated images for attribution, achieving good results when the image is generated by the source model. These studies assume a known candidate model pool; however, in reality, the image source model may be unknown.

To address open-set model attribution, Yang et al. [30] pioneered a progressive open-space expansion method, gradually simulating open-set samples through lightweight data augmentation models.  With the rise of large-scale text-based image models, research on their attribution has also begun.  Additionally, some work focuses on passive attribution research for deepfakes.

It started as a normal day at the bank. I was depositing a check from my accounting job, standing in line behind a large man with whom I'd struck up a conversation about the wildly fluctuating weather. I'd just remarked on the crazy wind and how things had taken a turn for the worse when a pair of individuals in balaclavas and heavy winter coats walked in.  "See, case in point," I'd quipped. "In a couple of days, they'll be putting those away and wearing t-shirts again."

Ironically, those were my last words before everything went sideways.

Suddenly, shiny metal glintedâ€”guns, imbued with murderous intent.  I felt instantly vulnerable and afraid.  Then, a bizarre thought crossed my mind: I probably wasn't going to make it to the library that day. Apparently, my mind handles crises in strange ways.

They overpowered the portly, elderly security guard in seconds.  I watched, frozen in shock. The guard looked well past his prime and clearly unable to offer much resistance.  That left the rest of us. The large man I'd been talking to had ducked behind a desk. The drive-through teller remained oblivious, but the other tellers had dropped below their counters, and the remaining customers were shrinking back from the sudden eruption of violence.

Damn. That made me the closest person to the robbers, and likely their next target.  Fortunately, I had a trick up my sleeve, one honed since elementary school for dealing with potentially dangerous individuals. I stared up into a corner of the ceiling, focusing my attention on my nose, willing the blood vessels to dilate. I felt the pressure build, then release.

I cringed, collapsing to the ground, clutching my head.  "Damn tumor," I groaned, feigning pain.  "Sorry, give me a minute," I mumbled, removing one hand and holding it palm up, fingers splayed, towards them. My other hand slid from the side of my head to my forehead. I feigned a spasm of pain before regaining a semblance of composure. I felt the warm stickiness of blood trickling down my lip, tasting the metallic tang. "Right. I guess I'mâ€¦" I winced again. "I'll talk. I don't have that much time left anyway."

The bank robbersâ€”because that's what my brain finally registered them asâ€”seemed to soften slightly. "Hey, no worries, man," one of them said. "We just want the money. Don't get me wrong, we'll absolutely kill anybody that tries anything, but we don't *want* to have to kill anybody."

"Thanks," I rasped weakly. "Just take the money and don't shoot anybody." I hoped that had bought the bank manager enough time to alert the police.

After a few minutes of the robbers shuffling things around, I saw flashing police lights approaching outside. I gestured to the others in the bank to escape. They bolted. I stayed.  Leaving wouldn't have been consistent with the character I'd created. Besides, in these situations, negotiators usually want a hostage to facilitate the robbers' demands.

Leveraging my ability to bleed on cue, I attributed it to stress exacerbating my fictitious tumor.

"Alright," she said, sliding a clip into a Desert Eagle and placing it against my temple. "Are you ready?"

Nervously wiping my sweaty palms on my medical gown, I replied, "As ready as I'll ever be."

"Okay. This *shouldn't* hurt much."  Her words offered little comfort. My gaze fell to the floor.  Click. Click. Bang! Then nothing.

I began a seemingly endless fall, my sense of time distorted.  Finally, a point of light appeared below, or at least, that's where I perceived it.  "Finally!" I thought, my disembodied mind relieved. "I thought I was actually dead there for a second!"

The light grew, bringing with it the murmur of voices.  Though unintelligible at first, I soon recognized the scientist who had shot me. "Oh, he's not going to like this. Not one bit," she said. A deep baritone, presumably the surgeon, responded, "Well, I did the best I could. He's lucky to be alive given the trauma his brain went through." He sighed. "I thought I told you no guns."  Her response was a giggle.  "Well, at least I made it," I thought, fading back into unconsciousness.

I awoke in a small, single-windowed room, the beeping of machines and the sterile hospital smell filling the air. "Ha! I made it!" I shouted, ripping out my IV lines.  Excitement propelled me out of bed and toward the bathroom mirror down the hall. The exertion winded me, suggesting I'd been out for weeks. Leaning against the wall to catch my breath, I closed my eyes, then stepped in front of the mirror.

Opening my eyes, I stared.  Initial confusion gave way to rage.  Looking back at me, in all my glory, was a fully formed dickbutt.

This article presents new efficient algorithms for evaluating $p$-adic elementary and special functions, achieving quasi-linear time complexity in the desired precision. This represents a significant improvement over previous methods, which often exhibited at least quadratic complexity.  These functions, including polylogarithms, hypergeometric functions, and solutions of "small" $p$-adic differential equations, play a crucial role in various mathematical fields such as analysis, geometry, combinatorics, and number theory. Their $p$-adic analogues are equally important, encoding deep arithmetic information, as illustrated by $p$-adic $L$-functions and their connection to Iwasawa theory and algebraic varieties.  The ability to compute these functions efficiently has far-reaching implications for calculating invariants and testing conjectures, mirroring the significance of high-precision evaluation of complex special functions, which has seen remarkable algorithmic advancements.


Our algorithms leverage a $p$-adic adaptation of the bit-burst method, pioneered by Chudnovsky and Chudnovsky, which builds upon the binary splitting technique and other ideas originating from Brent's work. This core technique is enhanced by incorporating improvements from later research.  The key to achieving quasi-linear complexity lies in the existence of recurrence relations satisfied by partial sums of series expansions. The binary splitting method efficiently computes the $n$-th partial sum by expressing it as a product of matrices based on this recurrence and constructing a balanced product tree.

While binary splitting is highly effective for small integer evaluation points, a multi-step process is employed for general evaluation points. This involves constructing a sequence of intermediate points with increasing bit sizes but decreasing $p$-adic distance to the target. Binary splitting facilitates efficient computation between consecutive intermediate points, ultimately reaching the desired value in quasi-linear time.


The paper is structured as follows: Section 2 establishes the representation of $p$-adic numbers.  Section 3 introduces the $p$-adic bit-burst method through the illustrative example of $\log(x)$. Section 4 generalizes the method to solutions of linear differential equations. Finally, Section 5 explores applications, including a fast algorithm for evaluating specific logarithmic derivatives connected to Dwork hypergeometric functions.  An important application of our algorithms is the computation of Frobenius matrices acting on the cohomology of fibrations, which satisfy Picard-Fuchs type differential equations.


The present work continues the trend of developing efficient algorithms for $p$-adic computations, exemplified by previous work on the Morita $p$-adic $\Gamma$-function, $p$-adic hypergeometric functions, certain $p$-adic $L$-functions, and the computation of Frobenius matrices on $p$-adic cohomology. My hands have always known what to do, alienated from the rest of my body, deformed. They never needed me.  I had always felt passion but was never molded by it, until now.  I found the edge, that line in my mind, and tossed myself across.  The pain is real.  A tangy mix of blood and sweat fills my mouth.  The blood is burning my eyes.

My hands are crafting something beautiful. I can feel it.  The stone floor sprawls with its cold glow.  My hands shift carefully, crafting my art. I feel alive. My soul wants to scream, wants to yell, but all I hear is laughter.  It bounces off the walls, breaking the silence, breaking my mind.

Where is the joy? In this moment of epiphany, I feel none. I realize now I have been forcing the emotion all along. This rage, thisâ€¦ *this* is what defines me.

I can feel myself seizing, shaking, filling with the rage that has always defined me. A growl, a wicked tune, bellows from the deepest parts of my soul. I feel better. I do it again, cracking the silence with the sound.

The blood dries, sticking to my face. My damp sleeve rubs against my eyes. I can fucking *see*. The room is still dark, but my pupils shift, adjusting.

How did I get here? What is happening?  My eyes focus. I see what my hands have wrought. A masterpiece.  This guyâ€¦ he had the wrong idea.  He thought he was going to teach *me* a lesson. He should have left me alone. He should never have come in here.  I want to scream, but the laughter is too loud.

The door moves. The laughter continues. A shadow advances.  I clench the bone fragment â€“ a trophy from the prisonerâ€™s jaw â€“ and move into the shadow. I thrust, putting my weight behind it, aiming to stop its advance. The laughter fills the room.

The shadow gasps as the door swings open, light flooding in.  The shadow crawls, retreating.  I have the upper hand.  I trace a line across the shadowâ€™s neck with the bone fragment.

The siren breaks the laughter. I take the badge from the shadow's belt. I canâ€™t stop laughing.

I move towards the hallway, the laughter echoing.

Parched air filled my lungs as I awoke with a start. The rough grass and slightly damp soil beneath my bare body seemed like any other savanna, save for unnatural, flowing patches of grass. An ominous feeling washed over me, amplified by the sickening metallic scent of iron emanating from the damp ground.  Something was terribly wrong. Where was I? Why was I here?

As I stumbled to my feet, fragmented memories returned. A sharp pang of painâ€¦ I'd been stabbed. The realization was strangely calm.  A small, hopeful voice whispered that perhaps this was heaven.  After all, I'd been a good person. A good student, respectful to teachers, with decent grades. A good daughter, loving to my parents and siblings.  Twenty years of faithful church attendance, prioritizing my religion above material possessions.  Wasn't that enough?

"Welcome to the new round! A warm welcome to our new arrivals, and I'm glad to see all of our returning players refreshed and ready to go. The game will start in three minutes."

A booming voice shattered my peaceful contemplation. Players? Game? What bizarre fantasy was this?  My mind reeled, unease morphing into paranoia.  If this was the reward for a life dedicated to spiritual fulfillment, I felt cheated.

A feral growl snapped my attention to a figure â€“ a woman, or something more beast than human.  She lunged, lips peeled back to reveal stained teeth.  I braced for impact, but felt nothing. An invisible barrier shielded me from her furious clawing.  I tried to speak, but my words didn't reach her; her eyes held a chilling, primal madness.

"Get ready, players! The game is starting, in threeâ€¦ twoâ€¦ one! Happy Hunting everybody!"

The booming voice echoed again.  Simultaneously, my protection vanished.  The woman attacked with inhuman speed and strength, her teeth tearing into my flesh.  I cried out in agony, yet there was no blood, only excruciating pain.  In a horrifying flash of insight, I realized the stains on her teeth weren't from neglect, but something far more sinister.

The throbbing pain persisted as I drifted in and out of consciousness, reliving moments from my life.

Computers designed to recognize human emotions primarily focus on external muscle movements in the face. However, these systems lack the sophistication to detect nuanced emotional states, including internal conflicts like hypocrisy.  Furthermore, such technology overlooks the diversity of the human experience.  It fails to account for individuals with exceptional talents or mental health conditions, as well as those prone to frustration in unexpected situations.

Consider the example of a comedian.  A joke may only genuinely amuse 30% of the audience. Yet, if that 30% laughs, the remaining 70% may feel compelled to join in, reducing social tension and supporting the comedian, rather than expressing genuine mirth.

The text mentions a claim of universality (presumably regarding emotional expression), but this overlooks individual differences, much like the existence of left-handed individuals or those with high IQs.  Forcing the technology to assign an emotion to every individual can lead to feelings of exclusion, potentially contributing to mental health issues like suicidal ideation.

The text also suggests that faces don't lie.  However, this ignores individuals with Down syndrome, whose facial expressions can be misinterpreted, and deceptive individuals, like criminals who feign remorse.  Students, too, can mask their true feelings.  A student might cheat on an exam and then complain to the teacher about its difficulty.

In conclusion, I have attempted to demonstrate the inherent limitations of using technology to accurately recognize students' emotional expressions.  There are simply too many variables and nuances in human behavior for current technology to reliably interpret.

The bespectacled Dorts Abory emerged from his wooden cabin, a deep breath filling his lungs as he traded the cramped confines for the verdant expanse of the outdoors.  An apple basket swung from his hand. Heâ€™d spent days inside the small structure, his only companion a small cat upon which he lavished affection.

Today was Sunday, a glorious summer Sunday.  A day free from work, save a trip to the market square for supplies.  A day for Dorts Abory to indulge in utter degeneracy â€“ lounging, drinking, and picking apples from his trees without a care in the world.

The apple fields, a twenty-minute walk, had been cultivated by his family for generations, shared with seven other families.  Constant bickering amongst the collective regarding orchard management was a given. From the fields, it was another twenty-minute walk to town for bread, lamp oil, ice, and ink.  Perhaps, if foot traffic was light, he might even try that new restaurant everyone was talking about.  Although, rumors of a rat problem gave him pause. He might stick with the usual place â€“ the one with the frog issue.

This idyllic Sunday was, of course, too good to be true.  Destiny, as always, had other plans, scheduled weeks in advance with no regard for Mr. Aboryâ€™s own.

Ten minutes into his walk, a white stallion and a reindeer pulling a carriage bearing three passengers nearly flattened him.  Abory cursed his luck.

â€œAre you alright, sir?â€ asked the blond driver. â€œIâ€™m not used to carriages, and I might have gone a bit too fast.â€

â€œYes,â€ chirped a slick-haired brunette from the back, â€œthe man who delivers ice for a living thinks *you* can go too fast. Can we get moving? I'm uncomfortable.â€

â€œOh, donâ€™t be such a stick in the mud, Eugene,â€ countered a red-haired woman. â€œIâ€™ve never seen this part of your country.  Thereâ€™s hardly any snow.â€

Abory eyed the bickering trio, remembered it was Sunday, and bolted for the woods.  The stallion, with improbable dexterity, snagged him by the collar, hoisting him into the air.

The horse sniffed him, flinging snow in his face, then pointed a hoof at the basket.

â€œWhat?â€ Abory asked.

The stallion neighed at the reindeer, who in turn vocalized to the blond.

â€œWhich way to the apple fields?â€ the blond translated.

â€œDown the road, left at the pine tree, beware the ducks,â€ Abory blurted, the last part escaping involuntarily.

Venus, often called the "Evening Star" due to its brilliance in the night sky, presents a compelling yet perilous target for exploration.  Its proximity to Earth and the Sun makes it a valuable subject for studying the effects of extreme planetary conditions, such as intense heat, pressure, and a dense, toxic atmosphere.  However, these very conditions pose significant challenges and dangers to any potential mission.

The dangers on Venus are numerous. A thick atmosphere, composed almost entirely of carbon dioxide, traps heat and creates a runaway greenhouse effect.  Clouds of corrosive sulfuric acid further contribute to the hostile environment.  Surface temperatures average over 800 degrees Fahrenheit, hot enough to melt lead, and the atmospheric pressure is a crushing 90 times that of Earth.  These extreme conditions explain why no spacecraft has ever successfully landed on Venus.

Exploring Venus would require innovative solutions to overcome these challenges.  Scientists would need to develop specialized vehicles, perhaps blimp-like crafts, capable of hovering miles above the scorching surface where temperatures are a comparatively cooler 170 degrees Fahrenheit.  Even at this altitude, robust thermal protection would be essential.

"Are you kidding me?"  I set my glasses carefully on the table and buried my face in my hands, sighing heavily. The all-too-familiar throb of a headache pulsed menacingly behind my left temple.

It had taken years to acquire the necessary materials for the summoning, not to mention a substantial investment and dealings with the dregs of society. The research alone had forced me back to school and into the shackles of student debt just to access and translate the necessary manuscripts.

"I need you to sign my review before I can get my credits, Miss."

The book had promised unlimited potential: power, riches, revenge, immortalityâ€”anything I desired for the paltry price of a soul.  Hell, it didn't even have to be mine.

Of course, it was just my luck to summon a demon scrambling to complete his externship.

Lord save me from more paperwork.

"I'll meet you for coffee at our favorite cafe," Donna choked out, her voice raspy from smoke-damaged lungs.  Her sister, Katie, checked her phone again.

"Yeah, I'll tell Mom and Dad you died. See ya," Katie said, placing a hand on Donna's charred arm before turning to leave.  Donnaâ€™s death had become a serious inconvenience.  Katie had been summoned at least five times this year to identify the body or speak to Donna one last time.  The requests were always the same: water the plants, feed the cat, and meet for coffee later.  It was hard for Katie to suppress an eye roll. Donna had fallen asleep with a cigarette again and set herself on fire.

On her way home from the body collection point, Katie passed Ed the Jumper. Every last Saturday of the month, at approximately 6:00 PM, Ed jumped from the highest bridge in town, landing face-first on the concrete below.  Katie had once asked him why. Heâ€™d explained that it was simply his time to be dead, like the old days, when death was permanent. So, he kept himself dead as much as possible by immediately killing himself upon revival. Over the years, Katie had noticed that while Ed's body repaired itself and appeared functional, heâ€™d become paler and more obsessed with maintaining his state of death.  Perhaps constant death was detrimental to his mental state. But Katie didn't dwell on it; Ed would be dead again in two minutes anyway.

Katie almost made it home before remembering Donna's cat.  Those creatures, unlike humans, still died permanently if neglected.  With a sigh, she turned down an alley beside her house.

"To die or not to die! This is your choice!" a man shouted from a street corner, waving flyers. He thrust one into Katie's hands before she could react and hurried down the street, pursuing a group of unsuspecting pedestrians with his pamphlets. Katie recognized the type: a "Cryo-napper," slang for someone who cryogenically froze themselves, hoping death would be permanent again upon their eventual thawing.  Katie tossed the flyer.  She doubted anyone was working on a cure for their semi-permanent state. Why would they? Death, the ultimate disease, had been cured. There was no undoing it, only living with it.

Reaching Donna's apartment, Katie texted her parents: "Donna died again. I plan to as well. Check on cat and plant for D. See ya later."

She walked to the busy road that ran across Ed's preferred bridge and waited for the next wave of traffic.  She didn't have to wait long.  A few semi-trucks began rumbling up the incline towards her.

Have you ever considered a unique journey to Europe?  Imagine traveling on a cattle boat, caring for horses, cows, and mules as they're shipped overseas. This is the mission of the Seagoing Cowboys, offering a remarkable opportunity to contribute to a vital cause.

Born from the devastation of World War II, the Seagoing Cowboys are part of UNRRA, the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.  This collaborative effort of 44 nations provides aid to war-torn countries. Joining this group means becoming part of something larger than yourself, contributing to a global effort of rebuilding and recovery.

Beyond the rewarding work with animals, traveling with the Seagoing Cowboys offers opportunities for exploration. Imagine sightseeing in new lands, encountering unique animals, plants, and rivers. This journey is not just about helping animals; it's about helping people and experiencing different cultures.  The core mission of UNRRA is humanitarian aid, and your participation directly contributes to this vital work.

Joining the Seagoing Cowboys promises a rich and fulfilling experience, both personally and for those you assist. We believe it would be an invaluable opportunity for you.  Won't you consider joining us?

"NO CHEATING IN MY CLASSROOM!"  The words boomed out, but his gaze, magnified by thick reading glasses perched above his Sunday Times, wasn't directed at me. He was staring intently at Faraz, who trembled and nervously licked his lips. I understood then â€“ the admonishment wasn't meant for me. It was a veiled message for Faraz.

"I didn't know --" Faraz began, his words echoing in my mind as if spoken telepathically.

"Just kidding, I'm fucking with you, kid," our teacher replied, his voice similarly ethereal. "How long you been a Path?"

"A-all my life, sir, I think," Faraz stammered.

"Faraz, is it? Faraz, I need your help."

"W-what is it, sir?"

"Faraz, I sense another Path in this room.

Driverless cars are rapidly approaching the horizon of everyday life, with multiple companies vying to perfect this autonomous technology.  While some have demonstrated impressive progress, the technology remains under development. This essay will explore both the potential benefits and drawbacks of driverless cars, ultimately culminating in my personal perspective on their role in our future.

Proponents of driverless cars envision a future with increased convenience and safety.  Imagine a world with reduced traffic congestion and fewer accidents, a world where commuting becomes productive time or simple relaxation.  Companies like Google have already made significant strides in developing autonomous vehicles, though a fully realized consumer version remains elusive.  The technological groundwork has been laid, suggesting widespread adoption is a matter of when, not if.

However, the prospect of driverless cars raises several critical concerns.  While convenient, this technology could contribute to a more sedentary and dependent lifestyle.  Beyond the potential societal impact of increased inactivity, the question of liability in the event of an accident remains a complex legal and ethical dilemma.  Who is responsible in a crash: the owner, the manufacturer, or the software developer?  Furthermore, the reliability of technology is always a concern.  What happens when a system malfunctions, potentially leading to injury or even death?  The first major accident involving a driverless car will undoubtedly spark public outcry and potentially stall the progress of this technology.

Ultimately, I am skeptical of the benefits of driverless cars. While innovations like water-powered engines or enhanced safety features are welcomed advancements, autonomous driving feels like a step too far.  We live in a society increasingly reliant on technology, from smartphones to drones, and driverless cars seem to exacerbate this trend toward passivity. This dependence raises critical questions about the future of employment and the potential for widening socioeconomic disparities if access to this technology is limited.  For these reasons, I believe the focus should remain on improving existing transportation rather than pursuing fully autonomous vehicles.

Colin and Felicity were the proudest of parents. Little Rupert had been born in perfect health. They beamed at each other as the doctor transferred Rupert into the genetic coding chamber.

"Are you ready to program your son?" the doctor asked with a smile.

Colin and Felicity exchanged a nod.  "Yes," Felicity said, squeezing Colin's hand. "Yes, we are."

Rupert lay within the gene manipulation chamber. The machine had eradicated genetic diseases overnight, allowing parents to select their newborns' traits. However, while harmful genes were automatically corrected, "luxury alterations" (as they were called) were subject to chance. Excessive population-wide perfection was deemed dangerous and undesirable by various governing bodies. Thus, parents rolled dice to determine their child's development.

"Okay," the doctor said, gesturing to a slot on the contraption, which resembled a vending machine. "Collect the dice from here," he explained, pointing to another opening, "and drop them in the slot up here. The machine will display the roll, which represents your child's ability in that specific area. Once you have the score, press 'next' here, and the dice will drop again." He chuckled. "Any questions?"

Colin glanced at Felicity. "No," he said. "I think we've got it, thanks."

"Then over to you," the doctor chirped.

Alone in the room with his wife and child, Colin walked to the machine, placing his palm against the glass. Rupert already looked perfect. Felicity watched from the bed.

"What's the first trait?" she asked excitedly.

"Beauty," Colin replied, retrieving the dice. "Ready?" he asked, looking back at Felicity.

"Yes, do it!" she squealed.

Colin dropped the dice into the slot.  A click, a rattle, a gulp, and the digital display behind Rupert flashed a '6'.

"Yes!" Colin shouted. "Six out of six! Our kid's going to be a looker!"

The parents celebrated, whooping, high-fiving, and hugging. After a minute or two, Colin pressed 'next' and collected the dice again.

He turned around, his face serious. Felicity's expression mirrored his concern.

"Is there a problem?" she asked.

"This one is intelligence," Colin said soberly.

Felicity gasped. "Make sure you roll it well!" she pleaded, clasping her hands in prayer.

Colin nodded and turned back to the machine. Exhaling deeply, he dropped the dice â€“ click, rattle, gulp â€“ and the machine displayed a '3'.

"What is it?" Felicity cried.

"Three," Colin said.  Silence hung in the air.

Felicity looked up, concentrating. "You know, three isn't too bad, Colin."

Colin considered the score. "No, I suppose not."

"After all," Felicity continued, "Margaret told me Jerry's boy rolled low for intelligence!"

"Jerry's boy?" Colin said incredulously. "He seems perfectly bright to me..."

"Well, exactly!" Felicity exclaimed. "And our Rupert has a three! That's not even low! It's middle of the road!"

"Middle of the road..." Colin echoed, a sense of wonder in his voice. Suddenly pleased, he pressed 'next' with renewed optimism.

A four followed for empathy, initially met with a cheer from Felicity and a dubious look from Colin. But, as Felicity pointed out, Jerry's boy had rolled low for empathy and was quite the unfeeling troublemaker. Colin's smile quickly returned.

Autonomous navigation has seen remarkable advancements, evident in the rise of self-driving cars and delivery robots.  However, significant challenges remain.  Classical planning methods, utilizing analytic optimization and reactive rules [1]-[3], offer safety and interpretability but often result in unnatural and inefficient behaviors with poor social norm compliance [4].  Conversely, machine learning approaches leveraging imitation learning [5], [6] and deep reinforcement learning [7]-[11] can capture nuanced human actions and improve environmental awareness.  However, these methods require extensive datasets, lack safety guarantees [12], and suffer from limited interpretability and transparency [13], leading to unpredictable failures [14], [15].

This work addresses these limitations by combining the strengths of classical and learning-based methods.  We introduce a sample-efficient learning strategy to enhance classical planners and a fallback system with a trained supervisor for guaranteed safety. Our approach offers a general framework for using learning to improve classical algorithms while retaining their advantages.

Specifically, we propose the following: 1) Train a planner using deep reinforcement learning (DRL) with policy guidance from a classical planner.  This involves seeding the replay buffer with classical planner experiences and regularizing the actor in an actor-critic algorithm using the classical planner's policy. 2) Implement a classical rule-based navigation policy as a fallback and train a supervisor for minimal switching between the neural and classical planners to ensure safety.

This approach leverages existing classical algorithms for faster, improved convergence and uses a regularization term for stability and transparency, keeping the learning process close to the well-understood classical algorithm.  Furthermore, unlike methods relying on human demonstrations, ours requires no human involvement, as this is implicitly present in the classical algorithm's formulation and the reward function.

Our main contribution is this combined approach, resulting in a sample-efficient learning strategy and a safety-guaranteed fallback mechanism.  While focusing on navigation planning, our methodology provides a broader recipe for integrating learning with classical algorithms.  The supervisor level ensures safety and transparency.

Relevant code and videos are available at https://github.com/eliasgoldsztejn95. *(This work was supported by ISF Grant 1651/19, the Helmsley Charitable Trust through the ABC Robotics Center of Ben-Gurion University, and the Lynn and William Frankel Center for Computer Science. Elias Goldsztejn and Ronen Brafman are with the Department of Computer Science at Ben-Gurion University of the Negev. eliasgol@post.bgu.ac.il, brafman@bgu.ac.il)*  (Figure 1: A robot navigating autonomously using a system that integrates an RL-based policy, regularized with a classical planner, alongside a safety switching mechanism - *This caption refers to a figure not included in the provided text*)

## Minimal Problems in Three-View Geometry Under Partial Visibility

This paper presents a complete classification of minimal problems for generic arrangements of points and lines in 3D space, observed partially by three calibrated perspective cameras. We focus on the case where each line is incident to at most one point (PLâ‚P).  This restriction simplifies the problem while remaining relevant to practical applications using features like SIFT [36] and LAF [37], which can be interpreted as points with attached lines [38].

Minimal problems, essential for tasks like 3D reconstruction [24, 25, 26], image matching [27], and visual odometry [28, 29, 30, 31], involve recovering camera poses and world coordinates from images.  These problems are characterized by a finite positive number of solutions for random input instances.  While a complete characterization of minimal problems under full visibility exists [32], partial visibility, where occlusions and missed detections occur, presents a significantly more complex challenge.

We address this challenge for the three-view case with the PLâ‚P restriction. This allows us to manage the enumeration complexity while still encompassing practical scenarios.

**Definition 1.** A point-line problem is defined by the tuple (p, l, I, O), representing p points and l lines with incidence relation I âŠ‚ {1, . . . , p} Ã— {1, . . . , l}, and visibility in m views described by O = ((Pâ‚, Lâ‚), . . . , (Pm, Lm)).  (i, j) âˆˆ I indicates the i-th point lies on the j-th line. Páµ¥ and Láµ¥ specify the points and lines visible in view v.  We assume I is realizable in â„Â³ and complete (containing all implied incidences).  O is such that if a camera observes two intersecting lines according to I, it also observes their intersection point.

An instance of a point-line problem comprises a spatial point-line arrangement, a list of calibrated camera matrices (Pâ‚, â€¦, Pm), and the joint image projections. We aim to recover the arrangement and cameras from the given joint image.  The camera positions are assumed generic, ensuring points and lines are in general position regarding the incidences I.  We fix the coordinate system by setting Pâ‚ = [I | 0] and the first coordinate of tâ‚‚ to 1 [52].

**Definition 2.** A point-line problem is *minimal* if a generic image tuple has a non-zero, finite number of solutions.  This number, constant for generic images, is the problem's *degree*.

Often, only camera poses are of interest.  A problem is *camera-minimal* if it has a finite, non-zero number of camera pose solutions for a generic image tuple. Minimal problems are camera-minimal, but not conversely (e.g., [35]). We further define *terminal camera-minimal* problems as the simplest camera-minimal problems obtained by removing superfluous features without losing camera-minimality.

**Contribution.** We provide a complete classification of minimal PLâ‚P problems in three views. While infinitely many such problems exist, we reduce them to 140,616 equivalence classes of *reduced minimal problems* by removing superfluous features and relabeling cameras. Each class is described by its 3D incidence structure and feature visibility.  All problems within a class share the same algebraic degree.

Furthermore, we identify 74,575 terminal camera-minimal problems, significantly expanding upon the 76 previously known cases [32, 35].  We list all terminal camera-minimal problems with fewer than 300 solutions and highlight other potentially practically relevant cases.

To achieve this, we define *reduced PLâ‚Ps* as canonical representatives of the minimal PLâ‚P classes.

The theory of stable matching, introduced by Gale and Shapley [GS62], has profoundly deepened our understanding of two-sided matching markets and inspired successful real-world market design.  Examples include marriage markets, online dating platforms, school choice programs, labor markets, and college admissions.  Using the common analogy of matching "men" to "women," a matching is stable if no man-woman pair mutually prefers each other to their assigned partners.

A fundamental challenge is characterizing the stable outcomes of these marketsâ€”predicting the results agents can expect based on market characteristics. Such characterizations are crucial not only for descriptive analysis but also for effective market design.  Numerous studies have examined stable matchings in random markets, where agents' preferences are drawn uniformly at random [Pit89, KMP90, AKL17, Pit19]. This paper extends these results to scenarios where preferences are shaped by "public scores" representing varying levels of attractiveness, thus generalizing the uniform case. We investigate how these public scores influence market outcomes.

Specifically, we analyze a class of tiered random markets with *n* men and *n* women. Each side is partitioned into a constant number of "soft tiers."  A fraction *Î´áµ¢* of men belong to tier *i* with public score *Î²áµ¢*, and a fraction *Î³áµ¢* of women belong to tier *i* with public score *Î±áµ¢*. Each agent's complete preference list is generated by sampling without replacement, proportionally to the public scores of agents on the opposite side.  For instance, a man's preference list is constructed by sequentially sampling women, without replacement, based on a distribution proportional to their public scores.  Let *Î±* and *Î²* denote the vectors of scores and *Î³* and *Î´* denote the vectors of proportions for women and men, respectively. The marginal probability of selecting a woman in tier *i* is *Î±áµ¢* / (*n* â‹… *Î±* â‹… *Î³*), and an analogous statement holds for men. These preferences offer a natural progression beyond uniform distributions, introducing heterogeneity in agent quality while remaining amenable to theoretical analysis.

Our primary objective is to analyze the average rank of agents within each tier under the man-optimal stable matching, focusing on asymptotic behavior in large markets. An agent's rank is the index of their partner on their preference list (lower is better).  We also examine the match type distributionâ€”the fraction of tier *i* women matched to tier *j* men.

Non-terrestrial networks (NTNs), particularly those incorporating low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite constellations, are crucial for achieving ubiquitous connectivity [1], [2].  LEO satellites offer significant advantages over traditional MEO and GEO high-throughput satellites [6]-[8], including reduced propagation delays and lower deployment costs [3]-[5]. While current systems primarily connect ground stations (GSs) to individual satellites, leveraging multiple LEO satellites in coordinated swarms offers enhanced flexibility and scalability [9].

A key advantage of satellite swarms lies in their ability to form large virtual antenna arrays, enabling substantial spectral efficiency gains through increased spatial separation [10]-[12].  However, implementing conventional MIMO schemes necessitates complete instantaneous channel state information (CSI) and inter-satellite coordination for joint beamforming.  This is impractical due to short channel coherence times caused by high orbital velocities and relatively long propagation delays in both ground-to-satellite and inter-satellite links.  This paper demonstrates that these limitations can be overcome by exploiting readily available or easily determined positional information instead of complete CSI.

Using this positional information, we develop an approximate channel model and derive a low-complexity, distributed linear precoder and equalizer based on beamspace MIMO [13], [14]. The precoder requires only knowledge of each satellite's own rotation and the position of itself and the GS, achieving near-optimal spectral efficiency.  Similarly, the equalizer relies solely on angle of arrival (AoA) information for the satellites, demonstrating near-optimal performance with proper swarm design.  We analytically determine the optimal swarm layout and numerically evaluate the overall system performance.

Existing research on multi-satellite communication includes studies on downlink transmission from a large nano-satellite swarm to a single antenna GS, demonstrating significant array gain through in-phase signal combination at the GS [10].  Work in [15] explores communication between multiple satellites and a multi-antenna GS, using iterative interference cancellation to address spatial correlation between GEO satellites.  The capacity of multi-satellite systems is investigated in [16] and [17].  A distributed precoding algorithm based on the MMSE criterion and inter-satellite information exchange is proposed for multi-user downlink scenarios in [18].  Zero-forcing equalization at the ground terminal for reception from two satellites is explored in [11]. Finally, beamspace MIMO has been adapted to ground-to-satellite communication, primarily focusing on single satellite scenarios [19]-[21].

Understanding online privacy policies is challenging due to their length and complexity (Cranor et al., 2006).  Users often skim or ignore these dense documents, hindering informed consent.  This necessitates more user-friendly presentations that avoid cognitive fatigue and address specific user information needs (Doan et al., 2018; Wurman et al., 2001).  Previous work has explored various approaches to improve presentation, including: at-a-glance risk summaries (Tesfay et al., 2018; Zaeem et al., 2018), structured and color-coded risk overviews (Harkous et al., 2018; Nejad et al., 2019), and natural language summaries of risky practices (Manor and Li, 2019; Keymanesh et al., 2020).  However, these approaches often present a general overview, while users typically have specific concerns.

A more user-centric approach is to allow users to ask questions about their specific concerns and receive targeted answers extracted from the policy (Ravichander et al., 2019a). This work focuses on building such an automated privacy policy question-answering assistant.  We propose a system that generates an extractive summary in response to user queries, similar to guided and controllable text summarization (KryÅ›ciÅ„ski et al., 2019; Dang and Owczarzak, 2008; Keymanesh et al., 2021; Fan et al., 2017; Sarkhel et al., 2020) and reading comprehension (He et al., 2020).

However, this task presents unique challenges. Users often ask questions that are irrelevant, out-of-scope (e.g., "how many data breaches did you have?"), subjective (e.g., "how do I know this app is legit?"), or too specific (e.g., "does it have access to financial apps I use?") (Ravichander et al., 2019a). Furthermore, even answerable questions often differ significantly in style and language from the formal legal language of privacy policies (Ravichander et al., 2019b), making it difficult to connect user intent with relevant policy content.  This domain shift is compounded by the limited size of existing annotated datasets (Ahmad et al., 2020), hindering purely supervised approaches.

To address these challenges, we employ query expansion and paraphrasing techniques, including lexical substitution and back-translation, to bridge the gap between user language and policy language. We then use a transformer-based language model, fine-tuned on in-domain data, to score the relevance and informativeness of each policy segment relative to the expanded query. Finally, we generate a summary from the top-scoring segments. Our results show that this hybrid approach allows us to extract relevant summaries for 89% of user queries in the PrivacyQA dataset.

At 6:00 AM, a mighty thud jolted me awake, shattering a pleasant dream where I controlled the global thermostat.  I dove to the floor, scrambling under my bed before realizing it wasn't an earthquake. It was worse.  *Damn it,* how had they found me again?

Outside, the loudspeakers blared their familiar mantra: "Every thirty seconds, a polar bear dies from heatstroke."  The climate change activists, at least, were the least irritating of the groups that regularly besieged me.  Peeking through the curtains, I saw they'd erected their projector screen and started the dying polar bear slideshow.  Iâ€™d seen Perry, Popo, and Patrick die so many times, the spectacle had lost its emotional impact.  They could have at least updated their material.

"Hey, missy!" A man in a suit spotted me and stormed toward the window. "You better lower the temperature this instant, or you'll be sorry when your heating breaks!"

The radiator salespeople were at the opposite end of the annoyance spectrum, favoring scare tactics.  Recently, theyâ€™d threatened a nationwide boycott if I didn't lower the temperature in time for winter.  A dubious strategy, I thought. I didn't need a radiator if I maintained the outside warmth, and their ham-fisted threats only fueled my anger, keeping the temperature high.  Even their plan wasn't the worst: North Face had threatened to somehow render my entire wardrobe fashionably obsolete if I didn't comply with their demands for cooler weather.

"Go blow hot air somewhere else," I yelled back.

"Yeah, if you need someone to *vent* to, we're here for you." Another man joined him, his uniform identifying him as a member of the nationwide union of air conditioning repairmen.

"Don't listen to these people, girl. Just keep trucking; we got your back." A woman wearing an ice cream cone hat chimed in.

I was naturally inclined to support the groups who tried to make me happyâ€”the farmers, the convertible manufacturers, the beachwear industryâ€”even though I knew most only cared about profiting from the warm weather.  Some had even tried to manipulate me through anger, believing it easier than eliciting happiness.  I still remembered the infuriating sunscreen commercial that played 24/7 on the lawn of my third house. They hadn't stopped until Iâ€™d become so angry their equipment melted.

"She's killing our jobs!" A spokesman from the hot cocoa industry dramatically threw himself onto the grass, presumably seeking my sympathy.

The Facial Action Coding System (FACS) offers exciting potential for classroom use.  By recognizing characteristic facial muscle movements, a classroom computer equipped with FACS could identify when a student is experiencing confusion or boredom, common classroom occurrences. This technology allows for personalized learning experiences, modifying lessons much like a human instructor, ultimately leading to improved learning outcomes.

FACS identifies six basic emotions: happiness, surprise, anger, disgust, fear, and sadness. Each emotion is associated with specific movements of the facial muscles. These movements are called "action units." For example, the frontalis pars lateralis muscle (above the eyes) raises the eyebrows to express surprise, while the orbicularis oris (around the mouth) tightens the lips to convey anger.

By comparing expressions against a neutral face, FACS can even analyze subtle expressions like the Mona Lisa's smile, demonstrating the system's sensitivity. This technology has broad applications beyond the classroom.

The article "Driveless Cars Are Coming" presents arguments for and against the adoption of autonomous vehicles.  While the article features expert opinions from both car companies and scientists, the evidence presented leans heavily against the feasibility and safety of driverless technology.

One major concern is the cost.  As stated in paragraph 6, the sensors and other components required for autonomous driving inflate the manufacturing cost to a staggering two hundred million dollars.  This exorbitant price tag raises questions about accessibility and practicality.

Furthermore, the claim that these cars are truly "driverless" is challenged in paragraph 7.  The article notes that while the car can handle driving functions at speeds up to 25 mph, drivers are still required to keep their hands on the wheel due to touch sensors.  This requirement not only undermines the concept of a fully autonomous vehicle but also suggests that the high cost does not translate into a fully realized, hands-free driving experience.  It essentially begs the question: why pay such a premium for a feature that remains partially reliant on human intervention?

This reliance on human oversight also creates ambiguity regarding liability in the event of an accident.  If a collision occurs, determining fault becomes complex.  Is the manufacturer responsible, or does the onus fall on the driver who is expected to remain vigilant and ready to intervene?  This lack of clarity poses significant legal and ethical challenges.

Finally, the article argues that despite the futuristic appeal of driverless cars, their current limitations make them impractical and potentially dangerous.  The technology is still prone to errors, while human drivers possess the advantage of reaction time and common sense.

General Sophie Drakeheart, advisor to the Great Lord, once believed freedom was everything.  She led the Order of Light for six centuries, immortal since drinking from the fountain, her life dedicated to stopping the Dark One, the Bringer of Doom.  Sheâ€™d never even met him, only been raised to believe in his destruction.  A thousand years of conflict culminated in the battle on the Golden Fields of Avalok.  Sophie, leading the last 10,000 free souls, rallied them with the cry, "Today, we may die. But, we die as free folk."  She remembers the poison arrow, the darkness, and then, waking chained to a table in the Golden City, an orc tending her wounds.


Captured, but alive, Sophie, the veteran of countless victories and defeats, expected torture. Stories of ripped nails and unimaginable cruelty filled their legends. Instead, healed and unshackled, she was escorted to the heart of the Dark Fortress at Ungol-Tugra.  No dark throne, no jeering captains. Just a small garden, and the Dark One, quietly watering a lily.

Fifty years have passed since that day. Fifty years since Sophie Drakeheart, ruthless warrior and tactless diplomat, learned the truth.  The plague ravaging the land, believed to be the Dark One's doing, was actually the work of a gruesome clan of Lizard Folk in the northern marshes.  Her first task as his advisor?  Exterminate them. She did, swiftly and brutally, ending the plague in months.

Then came the rebuilding.  Orcish laborers, under the watchful eyes of the Dark Oneâ€™s generals, repaired the ravaged cities with astonishing speed and efficiency. Order was restored, not through brutality, but through a fear that blossomed into trust, then love.  The Dark One, once the enemy, became the savior. Even the Order of Light, the very organization dedicated to his destruction, was honored with a memorial at Gurdan, its birthplace.  The inscription? "We remember those who fought for their beliefs, even when those beliefs are wrong."

Freedom.  Sophie Drakeheart, once its champion, now knows better.  It's overrated.

NEON has announced that Tilda Swinton, George MacKay, and Stephen Graham will star in its upcoming musical film, *The End*.

According to *Deadline*, Joshua Oppenheimer will direct the film, with production slated to begin in 2022.  While most details remain under wraps, the film will reportedly follow the last human family.  Information about the creative team has yet to be released.

Swinton, who won an Academy Award in 2008 for *Michael Clayton*, has collaborated with numerous acclaimed directors throughout her career, including Luca Guadagnino, Wes Anderson, Jim Jarmusch, Joanna Hogg, and the Coen brothers.

MacKay's film credits include *The Thief Lord*, *The Boys Are Back*, *Private Peaceful*, *How I Live Now*, *Sunshine on Leith*, *For Those in Peril*, *Pride*, *Captain Fantastic*, *Where Hands Touch*, *Ophelia*, and *1917*.

Graham is currently filming Netflix's adaptation of *Matilda The Musical*, in which he plays Mr. Wormwood.

Planetary surfaces often display fascinating shapes.  Recently, a formation resembling an Egyptian Pharaoh was photographed on Mars by NASA.  These formations are natural landforms.  While theories abound, scientific evidence confirms that Earth is the only planet currently known to harbor life.  NASA conducts rigorous research, and it's important to distinguish between scientific findings and speculation.

The notion of life on Mars is unsupported.  If life existed, it likely would have been evident in the images.  The formation is described as an unusual landform. Furthermore, Mars's extremely cold climate makes it hostile to life as we know it, necessitating protective suits for astronauts.

NASA's research on this formation involves direct observation.  The "Face," as it's sometimes called, was photographed during missions to Mars.  It's identified as a large rock formation.

Theories about these formations shouldn't be taken as definitive truth.  For instance, one theory suggests the initial images were too hazy to reveal potential life.  Another, less credible, theory proposes that NASA is concealing evidence of life. These conflicting and unsubstantiated claims underscore the importance of relying on verified data.

Some might interpret the "Face" as definitive proof of life on Mars. However, the images lack any concrete evidence of life.

In conclusion, there is no scientific evidence of life on Mars.  The photographs reveal no signs of life. NASA's direct exploration of Mars supports this conclusion.  While theories can generate interest, they shouldn't be mistaken for confirmed facts.

This passage argues against visiting and studying Venus, critiquing the original author's omission of crucial considerations. While the author effectively presents Venus's similarity to Earth, they fail to address the significant challenges and costs associated with such a venture.

A major flaw in the original argument is the lack of discussion regarding the astronomical costs of a Venus mission.  The author glosses over this, likely because the expense of overcoming the immense obstaclesâ€”an average surface temperature exceeding 800 degrees Fahrenheit and atmospheric pressure 90 times that of Earthâ€”far outweighs any perceived need for another planet.  These challenges would require significant financial investment to mitigate, a point not adequately explored.

Furthermore, the author never establishes a compelling reason for comparing Venus to Earth.  While mentioning Venus as Earth's twin and suggesting the possibility of past life, they fail to articulate why this should be a primary concern. The text highlights the unsuccessful history of Venus exploration, noting that no spacecraft has survived on the surface for more than a few hours. This raises the question: why persist with a mission that appears so improbable?

**Headline:** Eagles 53-Man Roster Projection Following Preseason Win

**Byline:** By Matt Lombardo | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com

**Body:**

PHILADELPHIA --  Running back Corey Clement and defensive end Steven Means, both fighting for a roster spot, delivered strong performances in Thursday's preseason victory over the Buffalo Bills.  But was it enough to secure them a place on the final 53-man roster?

Recognizing vehicle occupants' faces in unconstrained environments, especially through the windshield, presents significant challenges.  Previous research demonstrates that windshield artifacts can severely degrade image quality within the vehicle interior.  Furthermore, images are often captured from a distance and at moderate speeds, reducing available light.  While low-intensity ultraviolet or near-infrared (NIR) illumination could help, tinted windshields, which are increasingly common, block these wavelengths, rendering such solutions ineffective.  Longer exposure times are also impractical due to vehicle motion, as the resulting motion blur significantly impairs face recognition quality.  Additionally, the reflective nature of windshields presents further complications. Reflections reduce light reaching the sensor and introduce unwanted artifacts, including obstructive glare from direct light sources (Figure 1) and superimposed reflections of other objects.

Existing solutions, such as Gatekeeper Security's system, involve flashing visible lights at the driver.  This approach is problematic, creating both driver distraction and potential glare.

To address these challenges non-intrusively, we developed a custom multi-camera imaging system designed to optimize input for deep learning algorithms.  This modular system (Figures 2, 3, and 4) integrates imaging and computational components.  Raw images captured by the system can be processed using any High Dynamic Range (HDR) method to generate refined input for facial recognition software. This paper extends previous work in two key ways. First, we created and annotated a new dataset to train HDR reconstruction models specifically optimized for our hardware. Second, we introduce a novel HDR reconstruction network architecture, MU-Net (Mertens-Unrolled Network), which uses an unrolling technique to model the Mertens-Kautz-Van Reeth HDR algorithm as a neural network.  Finally, to evaluate the end-to-end system performance, we utilize state-of-the-art (SOTA) facial detection and recognition algorithms to assess image capture and HDR reconstruction quality for detecting and identifying faces through windshields of moving vehicles. We also benchmark MU-Net's efficacy against other established classical and deep learning-based HDR methods within the same recognition pipeline.

Driverless cars are poised to revolutionize the automotive industry, offering significant advantages over traditional vehicles.  After reading an article on the subject, I'm convinced that these vehicles will be incredibly helpful and useful in the future.  The article highlighted several key benefits, including increased safety, reduced driver burden, and improved navigation.

One major advantage is the potential for increased safety.  Driverless cars, like those developed by Google, have demonstrated the ability to drive up to half a million miles before being involved in a crash.  This remarkable feat is a testament to the advanced technology that allows these cars to avoid accidents far more effectively than human drivers.  Human error is a leading cause of accidents, and driverless cars promise to drastically reduce accidents by eliminating this factor.

Furthermore, driverless cars significantly reduce the burden on the driver.  Since these cars handle the driving 90% of the time, drivers are free to focus on other tasks, whether it's catching up on work, ensuring their children are safe, or simply relaxing.  While the driver may still need to intervene 10% of the time, the vast majority of the driving experience becomes automated, freeing up the driver's attention and reducing stress.

Navigation is another area where driverless cars excel.  Integrated GPS systems allow drivers to input their destination without the distraction of manipulating a separate device. The car automatically navigates the route, eliminating the worry of getting lost or being late. This feature is particularly beneficial for those who are not confident in their navigation skills or frequently travel to unfamiliar locations.

In conclusion, driverless cars offer a compelling vision of the future of transportation. By handling the majority of the driving tasks, these vehicles enhance safety, reduce driver stress, and simplify navigation.  The ability to drive for extended periods without incident, coupled with the convenience of automated navigation, makes a strong case for the success and widespread adoption of driverless cars.
