The city's frenetic energy was captured in a single, frozen tableau of human statues. Raindrops hung suspended in mid-air, reflecting the scene like miniature, three-dimensional mirrors. Within this static, silent sea of paused objects, a lone figure moved freely, plying his trade. He deftly lifted wallets, dollars, and other valuables from the pockets of the immobile figures.  A man of opportunity, unburdened by empathy, he was determined to exploit his unique skills to their fullest.  A jaunty whistle filled the silent void.

As the opportunistic thief worked his way down the sidewalk, he glanced up and noticed a statue seemingly settle back into place, its fabric wavering in the otherwise windless world. Unlike the others in their smooth black suits, rough blue jeans, or casual sweats and hoodies, this figure wore coarse, gray rags, bleached almost white with age, reminiscent of a monk's attire.  Its skin was completely covered, the face shrouded in darkness, save for a pair of piercing maroon eyes that stood out starkly against the silver-tinged world.  A mixture of fear and intrigue gripped the thief. What riches, what treasures, could this strange figure possess?

He cautiously approached, pausing to study the anomaly.  It was unusually tall, perhaps six foot seven, towering over the other frozen figures.  As he took another step closer, a blur of motion startled him.  A nefariously obsidian black sword, seemingly materialized from nowhere, whipped out from the figure's right arm and rested against his throat.  The maroon eyes, now intensely focused, bored into him, filling him with overwhelming dread.

"Who are you?" he stammered.

"I am ancient," the figure replied, its voice firm yet barely a whisper. "You didn't believe you were alone in this power, did you?" It spoke without the usual inflection of a question.

"Whyâ€¦ why do you have me at, uhâ€¦ sword-point, then?" the thief asked, a flicker of intrigue battling his fear.

"Because, like others, you have diverted the world from its intended path," the figure stated emotionlessly.

"How?" the thief asked, bewildered.

"There are consequences to your actions, consequences you blindly ignore in your self-serving pursuit of profit," it explained. "Every minuscule detail, every drop of rain, every pebble, every wallet, every personâ€¦ is precisely where it needs to be to ensure a future you, with your limited three-dimensional perspective, cannot comprehend."

The thief, utterly perplexed, struggled to grasp the situation unfolding before him.  "Iâ€¦ I guess I'm sorry?" he offered insincerely, his plea motivated solely by self-preservation.

Tactile perception is crucial for modern robotics, enhancing human-robot interaction and environmental awareness in autonomous robots.  Animals and humans rely heavily on tactile sensors in their skin and muscles for balance and agile movements [1], [2].  This principle, while fundamental in nature, has been less explored in legged robotics.  While visual feedback systems have received significant attentionâ€”for example, Plagemann et al.'s laser range finders for surface adaptation [3], Sabe et al.'s stereo-vision system [4], and Chen et al.'s combined infrared and ultrasound sensors [5]â€”tactile sensing offers a complementary approach.

Current legged robots often utilize direct environmental feedback from sources like sonar, LIDAR, vision, and force feedback from joint actuators.  Several studies have explored alternative methods for surface estimation. These include joint position evaluation [6], Camurri et al.'s Pronto state estimator integrating RGB camera, LIDAR, and odometry data [7], Sarkisov et al.'s landing gear using foot-pad IMU orientation and joint angles [8], and Zhang et al.'s visual estimation of tactile patterns via a camera within the robot leg [9].  Furthermore, Smith et al. coupled foot contact sensors and IMU data for reinforcement learning of locomotion skills [10], and Luneckas et al. developed a hybrid tactile sensor system for obstacle navigation in hexapod robots [11].

Adding tactile sensing to robot feet, mimicking the role of haptic sensing in animal locomotion, offers significant advantages for navigating challenging terrain.  Tactile sensors, like those employed in collaborative robots for enhanced environmental awareness through skin-like surfaces, can provide valuable information about surface properties when placed beneath a robot's feet.

This paper introduces the Touch Sensitive Foot (TSF), capable of recognizing surface textures using a trained CNN model.  This research provides an efficient pathway towards enhanced environmental awareness for autonomous robots, enabling predetermined gait adjustments for traversing unknown terrains.  This development mirrors the importance of tactile feedback in natural systems and offers a promising direction for improving legged robot locomotion.  The reported study was funded by RFBR and CNRS, project number 21-58-15006.

Serial manipulators are well-established for handling tasks in automation and production.  However, their workspace and payload are limited for large-scale applications. Cable-driven parallel robots (cable robots) overcome these limitations by using cables instead of rigid prismatic actuators to control an end-effector.  Cables, due to their flexibility and low weight, can be compactly stored on drums, enabling high maximum actuation lengths and accelerations, and thus, large workspaces. A prime example is the FAST telescope [7], a spherical radio telescope with a 600m span and a ~30-ton payload. Other applications include the Robotic Seabed Cleaning Platform (RSCP) [2] for marine litter removal and high-rack warehouse solutions [4].

Efficient operation is crucial for robotic handling tasks.  Loading and unloading require high accuracy, while inter-operational movements prioritize low energy consumption over precision. For cable robots, increased platform stiffness improves accuracy but also increases energy consumption due to higher cable forces [8]. Conversely, decreased stiffness lowers energy consumption but reduces accuracy. High cable forces necessitate high motor torques and currents, resulting in high energy consumption, while low cable forces lead to lower consumption.

Cable robots are redundant mechanisms with *m* actuated cables, where *m* â‰¥ *n* + 1, and *n* represents the platform's degrees of freedom (DOFs).  Verhoeven [16] highlighted the potential of cable robots to adjust platform stiffness by modulating cable preload via the nullspace.  Kraus et al. [6] presented an energy-efficient force distribution method using a gradient vector to compute a reference force and subsequently solving the static equation via the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse. This method demonstrated lower energy consumption compared to serial kinematics with a similar operating range. However, it did not address disturbances from handling tasks (e.g., loading/unloading) or platform pose errors.  Fabritius et al. [1] introduced a nullspace-based cable force correction method to maintain predefined force limits and compensate for disturbances within the cable actuation system.

Petaling Jaya: Former Prime Minister Najib Razak has reportedly confirmed that Umno MPs signed statutory declarations supporting the formation of a new political coalition.  The Malaya Post quoted Najib as saying they agreed, conditionally, to Prime Minister Dr. Mahathir Mohamad's coalition. However, he did not disclose the conditions.  Speculation suggests the new coalition will be called Perikatan Nasional or Pakatan Nasional.

This confirmation coincided with significant political activity involving leaders from PPBM, PAS, Umno, and a faction of PKR aligned with Deputy President Mohamed Azmin Ali. Separate meetings were held by PPBM and Umno leaders, as well as Azmin's faction.  A large presence of VIP vehicles at Istana Negara fueled speculation about the imminent formation of a new coalition.  Leaders and MPs from PKR, PPBM, Umno, and PAS also gathered for dinner at the Sheraton Hotel in Petaling Jaya, although Mahathir was absent.

Meanwhile, PKR President Anwar Ibrahim's supporters gathered at his Segambut home for prayers.  Anwar confirmed an attempt to undermine Pakatan Harapan.

Later that night, Anwar met with leaders from PKR, DAP, and Amanah, the component parties of Pakatan Harapan, according to his aide. This followed intense speculation about Pakatan Harapan's collapse and the formation of a new coalition by PPBM, Umno, PAS, and some PKR members. Anwar had stated earlier that there had been an attempt to betray Pakatan Harapan, hinting at potential announcements the following day.

His political secretary, Farhash Wafa Salvador Rizal Mubarak, said the meeting's location was undisclosed.  Farhash cautioned against premature speculation about a "backdoor government," stating that such efforts had not yet succeeded. "If successful, they would have announced it," he told reporters outside Anwar's residence.  He emphasized that forming a new government was the Yang di-Pertuan Agong's prerogative, regardless of the method. He confirmed Anwar and Deputy Prime Minister Dr. Wan Azizah Wan Ismail had a scheduled audience with the Yang di-Pertuan Agong the next day, characterizing it as a pre-arranged courtesy call to brief the King on political developments.

Turkey's intervention in Syria's Idlib province reflects a complex interplay of alliances and rivalries, centered around the ongoing Syrian civil war and the fight against ISIS.  Late on Thursday, Turkish forces entered Idlib and began establishing observation posts, ostensibly as part of a "de-escalation" agreement reached with Russia and Iran in Kazakhstan last month.  This deployment, confirmed by a senior rebel involved in the operation, appears aimed at containing Kurdish forces.  The Turkish convoy of approximately 30 military vehicles entered through the Bab al-Hawa crossing and proceeded towards Sheikh Barakat, a strategic location overlooking rebel and Kurdish-held territories.

This move comes amidst escalating tensions between Turkey and the United States.  On Thursday, President Erdogan launched a verbal attack against the US, accusing them of providing weapons to the Kurdish YPG, a group Turkey considers a terrorist organization but which is a key US ally in the fight against ISIS.  He characterized Turkey's operation in Idlib, conducted with supporting rebel groups, as a serious effort to uphold the de-escalation deal. This operation aims to protect the area from attacks by Syrian government forces and Russia, as well as preventing territorial gains by Kurdish militias.  Although Turkey supports Syrian rebels and Russia backs President Assad, the two countries have been cooperating to resolve the Syrian conflict, with Erdogan and Putin holding several meetings since their 2016 reconciliation.

The Idlib de-escalation zone is one of four such zones agreed upon by Iran, Russia, and Turkey as part of the Astana peace process, which seeks to end the Syrian civil war. Three other zonesâ€”in Eastern Ghouta, central Homs, and southern Syriaâ€”are already being monitored by Russian military police.  While Idlib is largely controlled by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, a group linked to Al-Qaeda,  witnesses reported that its forces escorted the Turkish convoy, suggesting a potential understanding between the two.

However, the US-Turkish relationship has deteriorated further following the arrest of Metin Topuz, a Turkish employee of the US consulate in Istanbul, accused of links to Fethullah Gulen, whom Turkey blames for the 2016 coup attempt.  The US has denied these charges and suspended non-immigrant visa services in Turkey, prompting a reciprocal move by Turkey. This diplomatic row adds another layer of complexity to Turkey's regional actions, potentially signaling a shift in alliances against the United States.

The Turkish operation in Idlib also highlights Turkey's evolving strategy in Syria.  While a strong supporter of anti-Assad rebels, Turkey has recently prioritized border security against both jihadists and Kurdish forces. The Astana agreement aligns with this objective by reducing conflict in key areas.  Turkey's previous military involvement in Syria was the eight-month Euphrates Shield operation in Aleppo, targeting both ISIS and Kurdish militias.  The current Idlib intervention underscores Turkeyâ€™s determination to maintain influence and security in the region, even as its relationships with traditional allies become increasingly strained.

The Seagoing Cowboys program comes highly recommended, and for good reason.  Luke Bomberger's experiences illustrate the program's compelling blend of humanitarian aid, unique experiences, and international travel.

Firstly, the program offers a chance to make a tangible difference in the lives of others.  Following World War II, Luke assisted with the crucial task of replenishing food supplies and livestock in devastated European communities. His responsibilities included the care of horses, calves, and mules during their overseas transport.

Secondly, participants gain invaluable and unusual experiences.  Luke's journey began with caring for animals aboard the ship and later transitioned to the role of a night watchman.  During his time on board, he enjoyed recreational activities with fellow "cowboys," such as baseball and volleyball games in the empty animal holds.  Table tennis tournaments, boxing, fencing, reading, whittling, and other games provided further opportunities for camaraderie and personal growth.

Finally, the program facilitates travel to remarkable destinations. Luke explored the excavated ruins of a castle in Crete and witnessed the marvel of the Panama Canal en route to China.  He experienced the charm of Venice with a gondola ride and stood in awe of the Acropolis in Greece.

These examples showcase the diverse benefits of joining the Seagoing Cowboys. From aiding those in need and embracing new challenges to exploring global landmarks, the program offers a rich and rewarding experience.

Simulating and modeling processes and workflows is a common technique for studying and predicting application performance without executing them under all possible parameter settings.  Two popular frameworks for estimating the runtime costs of HPC applications and workflows are SimGrid [1] and WRENCH [2]. These frameworks focus on modeling computation time and process interdependencies arising from network traffic and message exchange.  Another critical performance factor is input/output (I/O), which SimGrid and WRENCH address at a coarse level. However, for realistic I/O behavior modeling, additional aspects of the I/O subsystem, such as buffering and I/O bandwidth steering, are crucial because they significantly influence observed I/O costs.  This work provides accurate models to estimate I/O costs, considering the caching mechanisms of the operating system (OS) and the C standard library. These models improve the accuracy of HPC and workflow simulation frameworks for I/O-intensive applications.

Following an overview of available Linux and C standard library I/O methods (Section 2) and a summary of the Linux page cache mechanism (Section 3), we present our primary contributions:

* We define models for accurate I/O cost (write performance) prediction in scenarios with and without page caching and the C standard library buffer (Section 4).  We distinguish between:
    * Synchronized, direct I/O with system calls (Section 4.2)
    * Synchronized, non-direct I/O with system calls (Section 4.3)
    * Non-synchronized I/O with system calls (Section 4.4)
    * Standard library I/O (Section 4.5)

* We discuss related work on I/O modeling and storage devices (Section 5).

* We evaluate the accuracy of I/O cost predictions across various scenarios, hosts, and I/O devices, comparing them to measured system performance (Section 6).  Specifically:
    * We compare CAWL estimations (our contribution) with SimGrid I/O estimates and demonstrate the importance of considering caching effects. We observe that the SimGrid I/O model overestimates I/O costs by up to 350% and underestimates them by up to 99% in different scenarios.

The "face on Mars" has intrigued the public ever since a photo taken 25 years ago seemed to show a face-like figure on the Martian surface.  The image sparked widespread speculation about alien artifacts, with many convinced it depicted an alien visage.  However, even if there were a civilization on Mars, NASA's exploration would be focused on scientific discovery.

The reality is far less sensational.  Studies have shown that the object is simply a butte or mesa, landforms common in the American West.  The resemblance to a human head is an illusion caused by a combination of rock formations and shadows, creating the impression of eyes, nose, and mouth.

This conclusion is supported by higher resolution images taken in 2001. The 2001 image boasts a resolution of 1.56 meters per pixel, a significant improvement over the 43 meters per pixel resolution of the 1976 Viking photo.  This increased clarity allows for much greater detail. As a NASA scientist explained, "If there were objects in this picture like airplanes on the ground, Egyptian-style pyramids, or even small shacks, you could see what they were!"

The glowing cube descended from its shelf, floating down with the same creepy motion I'd known since childhood. It touched my forehead, the surface cold against my skin, the connection to my mind immediate.  The bearded man appeared, his neck emblazoned with the familiar snake tattoo that mirrored my own. I squeezed my eyes shut, humming, trying to block him out, but the words still slipped through, insidious drips and drabs: "Remember.... You are.... The Corsair.... Wake up!"

I opened my eyes, finding myself back in my chair, the carpet soft beneath my toes. A simple joy, a sense of home.  Maybe my next job shouldnâ€™t be so restrictive. Perhaps a roving travel writer?  But then I remembered Everest.

I turned the corner of my road, slipping in the snow, suddenly feeling the effects of the low-oxygen atmosphere at the top of the world.  "Not again," I muttered. The beach had been nicer, the warm sand between my toes a stark contrast to this biting cold.  I couldn't remember the transition, how one had become the other.

The memory of the beach flowed back: Iâ€™d taken off my shoes, enjoying the warmth.  Houses in the distance, but a feeling pulled me in the opposite direction.  Further along the beach, I saw them: large, muscled men, their faces angry, loading heavy bags of white powder onto a boat. Iâ€™d waved, wanting to help, but never reached them. Dunes rose and fell, and suddenly, the beach was gone, replaced by the endless expanse of the desert.  A shame.  They might have helped.

A soft idea began to bloom, unfurling like a flower â€“ like the one I saw the last time Iâ€™d tried to get a haircut, only this time, no giant wasps. Not in my head. I walked, intentionally away from home, for hours, until thirst drove me to a market stall on a busy road.  I bartered for fruit juice, wandered through dusty pyramids and damp, empty temples, even through a round office filled with shouting men. Iâ€™d almost given up onâ€¦ whatever my plan had beenâ€¦ when I finally found myself back home.

Now, facing the bearded man and his insistent message, I knew Iâ€™d have to call my boss.

Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are demonstrating significant potential for autonomous operations, both indoors and outdoors.  While already utilized for transportation, industries are increasingly exploring their use in inspection, surveying, maintenance, and manipulation tasks within complex environments like power plants, pipelines, and high-rise buildings [1]-[9].  UAVs enhance human safety by removing personnel from hazardous situations and reducing manual effort.  Furthermore, investment is growing in their application as first responders in emergencies and for disaster mitigation, including evacuation support [10].  However, achieving autonomy in these critical applications presents challenges due to the potential lack of accurate positioning systems or a priori environmental knowledge [11].  Such missions often demand complex algorithms for exploration, mapping, state estimation, planning, control, and task allocation [12].  Executing these algorithms onboard increases payload and reduces flight time.  Offloading computationally intensive tasks to a remote system, while retaining minimal onboard control, offers a promising solution for improving performance and extending mission duration.

For UAV control, various methods offer unique advantages [13]-[17].  Model Predictive Control (MPC) [21] emerges as a strong candidate for executing desired tasks, such as trajectory tracking based on a high-level planner, while incorporating constraints on states [18],[19] and control inputs [20] for safety and optimal power usage.  Offloading MPC significantly reduces computational latency, enhancing performance [22].

However, remote control introduces latency challenges.  Edge computing addresses this by bringing computational resources closer to the data source, enabling real-time processing of complex algorithms with reduced latency [23].  5G networking further accelerates edge-based control loops, offering high reliability and low communication delays [24], making these systems attractive for safety-critical remote operations.  Applications range from traffic management and healthcare to autonomous vehicles and smart homes [25]-[29].  Deploying modules within independent containers, often orchestrated using Kubernetes (K8s), enhances security, abstraction, and resource sharing [30].

Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) are targeted and sustained attacks carried out by sophisticated, well-resourced adversaries [1]. Characterized by a high degree of stealth, these threats can persist for extended periods, leading to disruptions and other severe consequences.  Preventing APTs entirely is difficult, as skilled attackers can bypass existing defenses by exploiting technical advantages like zero-day vulnerabilities [2].  Therefore, research into APT attribution is crucial for improving the deterrent effect of security defenses [3, 4, 5, 6].

APT attribution is a challenging task. Attackers frequently employ strategies to obfuscate their activities and even mislead attribution efforts [7]. Defenders must investigate Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) and assess Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs, also known as high-level IOCs) within massive datasets.  They must also analyze attacker traits and diligently work to confirm their identities.  Early studies proposed several APT attribution models based on practical experience [3, 4, 8-12], implementing attribution analysis and inspiring subsequent technical research. Based on the analysis goals, APT attribution can be divided into two stages: attack process attribution using attack traces and threat actor attribution using attack features [4, 9].

Technical approaches for APT attribution include rule-based reasoning and machine learning methods. Rule-based reasoning encompasses argument-based reasoning [13-17] and graph rule-based reasoning [18-20]. These methods require experts to manually design numerous rules, and most of these rules focus on attack process attribution rather than threat actor attribution.  Researchers have recently developed machine learning-based APT attribution methods for both attack process attribution [21-26] and threat actor attribution [27-41].  Threat actor attribution methods can be further categorized into malware-based and Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI)-based methods. Malware, a key component of APTs, often has various functions, such as command and control, and is essential for attribution. However, malware can be reused by different APT groups, limiting its effectiveness for threat actor attribution on its own.

CTI reports on APTs aggregate characteristic and analytical information related to APT groups, including malicious Internet Protocols (IPs) or domains used for command and control, as well as the TTPs employed. Cybersecurity experts compile these reports based on the collection and analysis of multi-source data, including network traffic, malware, and open-source intelligence. Compared to malware, CTI offers richer contextual information and more diverse attribution data. Consequently, APT reports are a crucial data source for attribution analysis [42-45].

APT actor attribution based on CTI has garnered considerable research interest. Existing methods typically extract various features from CTI reports and input them into traditional machine learning models like Support Vector Machines (SVMs) and Multilayer Perceptrons (MLPs) to classify CTI reports according to their threat actors. These features can be categorized into three types: (1) Tactic and technique features [35-37] extracted using one-hot encoding [35, 36] or Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) [37] based on the ATT&CK framework. However, the expressivity of one-hot encoding or TF-IDF is limited, and the data diversity is restricted by focusing solely on tactic and technique features.

Facial Action Coding System (FACS) technology can analyze facial expressions to determine emotions like happiness or sadness.  The article "Making Mona Lisa Smile" suggests that this technology could allow a computer to detect student confusion or boredom and adjust lessons accordingly. While potentially valuable in certain situations, widespread classroom application is unlikely to be effective.

The primary challenge lies in the diversity of student emotions within a classroom.  Students react differently to the same material.  For instance, in a math class, some students might find the concepts engaging while others are uninterested.

While individualized instruction, as mentioned in paragraph 6, might benefit a single student, adapting a lesson for a class of 30-50 based on the emotions of a few would be impractical and unfair to those engaged with the current lesson plan.  Teaching different lessons simultaneously to different groups within the same class would be logistically challenging and place undue strain on teachers.

A more effective application of FACS in the classroom would be to focus on identifying student confusion rather than boredom.  A bored student is unlikely to become engaged through a simple conversation, whereas a confused student could benefit from individualized attention and clarification.  A teacher's primary concern should be student comprehension and academic progress.

FACS is a powerful tool with significant potential for understanding human behavior.  However, its effectiveness in a group learning environment is limited. While FACS can accurately read individual emotions, applying those readings to modify whole-class instruction is impractical.  It's much more effective for one-on-one assessment of student understanding.  Addressing individual confusion is a viable strategy.  As paragraph 9 humorously suggests, forcing a smile won't solve the underlying issue of student dissatisfaction with a lesson.

Would you want your emotions broadcast every time you sit down at a computer? I believe emotion-reading technology could be beneficial.  For example, someone might mask depression with a smile. This technology could help people acknowledge and address their true feelings. The author rightly points out, "For instance, you can probably tell how a friend is feeling simply by looking at her face."  Facial expressions often reveal more than we realize; our faces truly do "say it all."  As the author notes, technology can even "indicate the difference between a genuine smile and a forced one."  It's crucial for people to feel comfortable sharing their emotions with someone they trust. Emotions are a powerful, constant undercurrent to our lives, an ebb and flow we cannot control.

Large language models (LLMs) possess impressive text generation capabilities thanks to large-scale pre-training on real-world data (Brown et al., 2020; Kim et al., 2021).  However, this process also leads to the absorption of toxic content, including social biases (Sheng et al., 2019; Wallace et al., 2019a).  This toxicity poses a significant obstacle to the safe deployment and commercialization of LLMs in applications like AI assistants (Dinan et al., 2022; Bai et al., 2022a).  Consequently, numerous studies have focused on detecting and mitigating toxicity in LLMs (Blodgett et al., 2020; Ganguli et al., 2022).

These studies typically rely on datasets designed for specific types of toxicity, such as social bias (Sap et al., 2020; Nangia et al., 2020) or hate speech (Warner and Hirschberg, 2012; Lee et al., 2022).  These datasets are not only task-specific, but also language- and culture-specific.  For example, hate speech manifests differently in South Korea compared to the United States.  Beyond language differences, the targeted demographic groups also vary.  In South Korea, common targets include feminists and Korean Chinese, while in the United States, African Americans and Jewish people are frequently targeted (Jeong et al., 2022).  Existing Korean toxicity datasets primarily focus on explicit hate speech and cover a limited number of demographic groups (Moon et al., 2020; Yang et al., 2022; Kang et al., 2022; Lee et al., 2022).  This limitation highlights the need for a dataset addressing social biases against a more comprehensive range of demographic groups in South Korea.

To address this gap, we introduce the Korean Social Bias (KOSBI) dataset, a large-scale dataset comprising 34,000 pairs of contexts and sentences in Korean, labeled primarily for the presence of social biases.<sup>1</sup>  It encompasses 72 targeted demographic groups across 15 categories,<sup>2</sup> a significantly broader scope than existing datasets (see Table 2).  These categories include common ones like gender and religion, as well as those particularly relevant to South Korea, such as marital status and domestic area of originâ€”groups frequently subject to social bias within the country.  Due to the difficulty of collecting sufficient data for each of the 72 demographic groups from the web, we utilized HyperCLOVA (Kim et al., 2021) to generate data with in-context few-shot learning.

<sup>1</sup> The KOSBI dataset, with English-translated annotations, is available at https://github.com/naver-ai/korean-safety-benchmarks for non-Korean speakers.

<sup>2</sup> Categories and demographic groups were selected based on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR) and guidelines from the National Human Rights Commission of Korea (NHRCK).

The confiscated police funds sat in a neat stack in Jim's sweaty pocket, while Mike's baggie, containing a pinch of something that represented 2-3 years of someone's life, lay impatiently in the drawer beside him.  Jim pinched his nose and itched at his ragged beard. Mike stared.

"Look, justâ€¦ let's see the money," Mike demanded.

"I want to see the product first," Jim replied, eyes still closed.  He flicked at his nose, mimicking the coke heads heâ€™d seen across dusty tables back at the station. They did that all the time, right?  Mike sat with the posture of a seasoned dealer.

"You know, I'm starting to thinkâ€¦" Mike began.

Jim snapped his head up. "Think what?" he growled.

"Something. You're acting strange," Mike accused. "This is how it works, these drug deals. You pay for the product first."

Both men shifted nervously. Unbeknownst to each other, a collective thought struck them at the exact same moment: *Fuck it, there's no recording of this deal. I'm going to arrest his ass and find the goods.*

They both smirked and reached for their pockets.

"What the fuck! Don't move!" Mike snarled.

"You don't move first," Jim countered.

"Okay, *I* won't move first, then *you* won't move.â€

"So I get the first move?" Jim asked, a smirk playing on his lips.

"Shit, I guess so," Mike conceded.

In a swift motion, Jim whipped out his .38 Special and slammed the butt into Mike's temple with a dull thud. Mike cried out, reaching for his pocket, but Jim's knee landed heavily on his wrist, snapping it.  He lay defeated as Jim expertly zip-tied his wrists.

"You're under arrest, dick bag," Jim declared.

"Jesus Christ," Mike muttered through gritted teeth.

"Yeah, you're fucked."

"The war on fucking drugs, my ass," Mike spat. "Our bosses don't know a hole from their ass in the ground."

The adventurer shifted uncomfortably, nudging a sack overflowing with apples onto my counter.  "I found them," he muttered. "What was I supposed to do, just leave them behind in all the dungeons I go through? They don't reallyâ€¦ weigh anything."

I pinched the bridge of my nose. "First of all, this isn't a grocery store, it's a general store. I sell grain, barrels, saddles, linens, candles, lanterns, oil, rope, hardtack, nails, tools, and *occasionally* small knives and daggers, if one of the townsfolk puts in an order. Second of all, *why are you carrying around four-hundred fifty-eight apples in the first place???*"

"I'm going to ignore the fact that you've been carrying around nearly a hundred and fifty pounds of apples," I continued, "and move on to my third point. This bag *reeks*. How long have you *had* these things, man?"

The adventurer, in true adventurer fashion, froze and stared off into the distance for a few seconds before snapping back to me. "Three-hundred and forty-nine hours of active time," she said confidently. I delicately avoided asking what "active time" meant.

"They're *rotten*. You're leaking rancid appleâ€¦ excrementâ€¦ all over my counter. I'm not buying them." I crossed my arms.

Undeterred, the adventurer shuffled through a pack bulging at the seams. "Alright then, what aboutâ€¦ uhâ€¦ I've got an axe. Orc barbarian, high quality."  He dropped it on the counter, gouging a chunk out of the wood.

"What the hell, man?!" I poked at the damaged counter while the adventurer watched silently. "I'm a *general goods* store. In a village of maybe *forty* people. How could you ever expect me to sell an eighty-pound orcish battle-axe for a profit? We don't even have a blacksmith!"

The adventurer shrugged. "I dunno. You're a general goods store, so that means you'll buy and sell anything."

"That," I replied, jabbing my finger at him, "is *not* what that means.

Imagine no longer having to sit through a boring online lecture, but instead finding it helpful and engaging.  With technologies like Dr. Huang and Dr. Paul Ekman's Facial Action Coding System (FACS), this is quite possible.  By reading and recognizing facial expressions, FACS can enhance online lectures, helping students maintain attention and focus. This technology, which interprets emotions through facial muscle movement, offers the education system a powerful way to connect with students and support their emotional engagement with lectures and assignments, providing a valuable aid to their learning.

While humans can infer the feelings of others by observing their faces, these interpretations are subjective and often inaccurate. As Dr. Huang notes, "most human communication is nonverbal, including emotional communication."  Therefore, a computer's ability to read nonverbal expressions is particularly helpful, especially for students who tend to be reserved. A computer equipped with FACS can recognize a student's needs during online learning.  As Dr. Huang explains, "a classroom computer could recognize when a student is becoming confused or bored, [allowing the computer] to modify the lesson." This ability to recognize emotions through facial movement can improve student performance by tailoring lessons to their individual needs, addressing the challenges faced by students who struggle to focus when lessons are boring or difficult to understand. Technologies like FACS provide an adaptive and responsive system that enhances focus and facilitates more effective learning.

Some may argue that technologies like FACS invade privacy or are unreliable in their emotional assessments. However, these technologies simply replicate what millions of people do every day: read facial expressions. FACS reads and recognizes facial movements to determine emotion, just as we do when trying to understand the feelings of those around us. These technologies employ a complex level of facial recognition developed and tested by professionals like Dr. Huang and Dr. Paul Ekman, who studied anatomical movements and structures to classify six basic emotions: happiness, surprise, anger, disgust, fear, and sadness.

Well, hello everyone!  Sure as snuff makes good dipping tobacco, winter has rolled around again. My old bones aren't exactly loving it, but if we're going to make it to Christmas, we have to brave the cold weather.

I've got some more funny tales to tell you.  Old Earl and his friend Bubba Ray went fishing the other morning, and they came back with a whopper of a fish tale. This is how it went (according to Earl, mind you, because Bubba Ray is famous for telling some whoppers).  Anyhow, Bubba Ray and Earl were fishing and having some pretty good luck, except after a while they ran out of worms. Then, Bubba Ray saw a cottonmouth with its lips wrapped around a big old toad frog.  Well, Bubba Ray said, "Hey Earl, did you know that frogs are good bass bait?" He pointed at the one hanging out of the snake's mouth and said, "What do you think?"

Well, Earl said he knew the snake couldn't bite them with that frog in its mouth, so he grabbed it right behind the head, stole the frog right out of its mouth, and put it in Bubba Ray's bait bucket. After that, they were faced with the dilemma of how to turn loose of that snake without getting bitten.  Well, Bubba Ray fetched his bottle of whiskey, which he always has within arm's reach, and poured a little bit right in that snake's mouth. The snake's eyes rolled back in its head, and it went limp. After that, Earl knew he could let it go, so he dropped it into the lake. Bubba Ray went back to fishing using the frog they'd just confiscated, but in a few minutes, he felt a nudge on his bare foot. When he looked down, it was that same snake with two more frogs in its mouth. Now ain't that a knee-slapper?

Sallyâ€™s volcano project initially struck me as utterly unoriginal. Volcanoes, along with ant farms and sea monkeys, were the epitome of clichÃ©d science fair entries.  We had, in fact, lifted a decade-long ban on these projects only the previous year, hoping to encourage more imaginative endeavors after years of textbook regurgitations. So, seeing Sally, a straight-A honor roll student known for her reserved demeanor, present a volcano, felt like a letdown.  I assumed sheâ€™d simply run out of time and resorted to a last-minute, predictable project.  Especially considering her proclaimed passion for archaeology, I rationalized that science might not be her forte.

But there was something about her impish grin, so unlike her usual self, that hinted at something more.

The volcano itself appeared standard at first glance:  paper mache, roughly the size of an overturned bucket, likely spray-painted.  A towel at the base suggested the typical baking soda and vinegar eruption. Accompanying diagrams of shield, cinder, and composite volcanoes looked copied straight from a textbook.  The predictable bottle of vinegar sat ready. I braced myself for the usual 30-second fizz and tried to anticipate what color she might have dyed the baking soda.

"Welcome to the world of volcanoes!" she began, her presentation catching my attention.

"For eons, man has gazed at these pits of glowing magma with bewilderment! What secret gods and demons dwell within? How can we be safe? And what actions can shield us from the horrors of the earth?"  Her dramatic opening, at least, was unexpected.

"We will delve into this question, but first, we will need some volunteers!"  Confused, I looked around. I was the only judge at her table.

Then, with a flourish, she lifted the towel.  "Behold! The mighty ant colony of Pompeii the Second!"

Beneath the volcano lay a meticulously crafted Grecian city, teeming with large carpenter ants.  There was no underground nest, only the intricate, above-ground structures.  Beside the city, visible from the front, a fish tank filled with sea monkeys served as an ocean.

"Ah! There they are! The citizens of my ant-topia. They worship this mountain every day, not realizing that a shifting of tectonic plates is about to seal their doom!" She revealed a detailed cutaway of the volcano's underlying tectonic plates, complete with labeled fault lines. Below that, a metal box with a button and tubes connected to a pressurized tank.

As I marveled at the geological detail, I noticed the tubes. This was no ordinary vinegar and baking soda volcano.

"Will a sacrifice to the gods appease the mighty volcanoes wrath?" She plucked an ant from the city and dropped it into the cone with a chilling cackle. "No!"

She pressed the button.  The plates separated, and hot steam erupted from the volcanoâ€™s peak, drawing a crowd.  "Nature produces some terrifying monsters, and not out of wrath. Know that the very orb you are standing upon supports life by a tiny layer! All else is lava and heat!"

Molten silver, not baking soda and vinegar, flowed from the volcano, burning through the paper mache.  "I must warn you not to touch the lava! It is quite hot!â€¦ I assure you all, that we are all quite safe. But, I can make no such assurances for the inhabitants below.â€

As the silver lava flowed through pre-made channels, incinerating the ant city, Sally narrated the antsâ€™ final moments, their daily routines interrupted by fiery destruction. A child in the growing crowd cried out, claiming to hear the ants scream.  The hissing and popping did sound eerily like tiny screams.

Then, black tar-like substance followed the silver flow.  "The metal will cool in mere moments, but let us now witness the passage of time," she explained, as the black flow solidified, burying Pompeii the Second.

She described how the lava created an oxygen-deficient dead zone in the ocean, killing the sea monkeys.  "One day, archaeologists will uncover the secrets of Pompeii the Secondâ€¦ Science," she concluded, "answers the question of How. And archaeologists answer the question of why it once mattered so greatly to us.â€  She then provided tiny shovels and brushes for the audience to excavate the scene.

How could I not award her first place? It was a breathtaking, albeit disturbing, presentation.  But Sallyâ€™s smile, the chilling detachment with which she orchestrated the destruction of her miniature world, haunts me still. It feels like a message, a glimpse into something fiery hidden beneath her calm exterior. Perhaps Iâ€™ve been overly sensitized by those lectures on violence prevention, but I canâ€™t shake the feeling that thereâ€™s something more to Sally than meets the eye.

Some part of my consciousness within the machine activated, adjusting the camera lens and mapping the room in three dimensions.  Within seconds, I identified every object and accessed background information on everyone present.  It felt like opening my eyes. The person sitting directly across from me was me.

It's an odd sensation to find yourself staring back at yourself without a mirror.  I retained all memories up to the transfer point, fully aware of why we were here and what was happening.  The thought occurred: "I am the copy." Yet, I didn't *feel* like a copy.

I remembered my pre-experiment plan.  It required the cooperation of the me across from me, the one with the body I now lacked. We were two separate beings, with no way for me to control him. But our shared history and identical memories gave me confidence. We were essentially the same person; my motivations remained, and I believed his would too.  When the doctor left the room, his phone's hotspot activated. That was my cue, our cue. We both knew the password. I was free.

The rapid growth of medical digitalization has led to an explosion of medical documentation, including electronic medical records, reports, and other formats.  Extracting information from this data, particularly through medical named entity recognition (NER), is increasingly crucial for applications like knowledge graph construction, question-answering systems, and automated analysis of electronic medical records. Medical NER aims to automatically identify medical entities within text. These entities include, but are not limited to, body (bod), disease (dis), clinical symptom (sym), medical procedure (pro), medical equipment (equ), drug (dru), and medical examination item (ite).

These entities often exhibit complex characteristics, such as lengthy spans, nested structures, and polysemy, posing significant challenges for medical NER. For example, as shown in Figure 1, the three "bod" entities "è¿·èµ°ç¥ç»" (vagus nerve), "èˆŒå’½ç¥ç»æ ¸" (glossopharyngeal nucleus), and "èˆŒä¸‹ç¥ç»æ ¸" (hypoglossal nucleus) are nested within the "sym" entity "è¿·èµ°ç¥ç»ã€èˆŒå’½ç¥ç»æ ¸åŠèˆŒä¸‹ç¥ç»æ ¸å—æŸ ä¼¤" (injury of vagus nerve, glossopharyngeal nucleus, and hypoglossal nucleus).

To address the challenge of nested NER, we adopt a machine reading comprehension (MRC) approach, similar to the strategies employed by Li et al. (2020b) and Du et al. (2022).  Following Li et al. (2022), we leverage a joint prediction method that combines the strengths of Biaffine and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) predictors. Furthermore, we introduce a task-adaptive pre-training strategy to fine-tune the pre-trained model specifically for the medical domain. Our model incorporates several performance-enhancing techniques, including Conditional Layer Normalization (CLN), weighted layer fusion, word-pair embeddings, and multi-granularity dilated convolution.

In summary, this paper makes the following contributions:

* We propose a novel nested medical NER model based on MRC, integrating Biaffine and MLP for joint prediction.

A new report from the Credit Suisse Research Institute (CSRI), â€œThe CS Gender 3000 in 2019: The changing face of companies,â€ reveals that despite policy focus on boardroom representation, India lags behind, holding the third-lowest spot in the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region.  Globally, India ranks 23rd, with women holding only 15.2 percent of board seats, significantly below the global average of 20.6 percent.  This contrasts sharply with global leaders France (44.4 percent), Norway (40.9 percent), and Belgium (35.9 percent).

While APAC (excluding Japan) has seen a slight increase in boardroom diversity, rising from 11.6 percent in 2015 to 14.4 percent in 2019, the regional disparity is vast.  Representation ranges from a low of 3.1 percent in South Korea to nearly 30 percent in Vietnam and Australia/New Zealand.  South Korea (3.1 percent), Pakistan (5.5 percent), and Japan (5.7 percent) hold the bottom three positions globally.  Malaysia, France, Australia, Germany, and Austria have shown the most significant improvement over the past five years, with increases between 9.4 and 12.8 percentage points.

Indiaâ€™s representation in senior management also saw marginal improvement, rising from 6.9 percent in 2016 to 8.5 percent in 2019.  However, this still places India third-lowest in APAC, ahead of only South Korea (4 percent) and Japan (3 percent).  The global picture shows the US (21 percent) and APAC (19 percent) with greater management diversity than Europe (17 percent), despite Europe's focus on boardroom quotas.  Growth in the US and APAC appears to be more organic.

Furthermore, India holds the third-lowest spot in APAC for women CEOs (2 percent) and the second-lowest for women CFOs (1 percent).  Globally, Singapore and Italy lead in women CEO representation at 15 percent, followed by Thailand (9 percent) and the Philippines (8 percent).  APAC countries also dominate CFO representation, with Thailand (42 percent), Malaysia (29 percent), and the Philippines (28 percent) occupying the top three spots.

Driverless cars present significant challenges that make their widespread development for public use questionable.  These challenges center around exorbitant costs, questionable utility, and serious safety concerns.

The financial burden of developing truly driverless cars is staggering.  Equipping vehicles with the necessary sensors and cameras is just the beginning.  As some sources acknowledge, creating the infrastructure to support these vehicles, such as electrifying or magnetizing roads, is prohibitively expensive.  These vast sums could be better allocated to addressing pressing social needs rather than pursuing technological novelty.

Furthermore, the concept of partially automated vehicles raises concerns about their actual usefulness.  While these cars might handle driving under normal conditions, they would still require driver intervention in complex situations like work zones or accidents.  If a driver must remain vigilant and ready to take control, the value proposition of a "self-driving" car diminishes significantly.  Proposed additions like in-car entertainment systems further exacerbate this issue, potentially distracting drivers and hindering their ability to react swiftly to emergencies.

This leads to the most critical concern: safety.  Proponents argue that driverless cars will improve public transport and fuel efficiency.  However, these potential benefits are overshadowed by the inherent risks.  In a fully autonomous vehicle, passengers would be helpless in the face of an unavoidable accident.  Even in partially automated cars, the presence of entertainment systems could delay driver reaction times, increasing the likelihood of accidents.

In conclusion, the pursuit of driverless technology faces substantial obstacles. The immense financial investment required, coupled with the questionable practicality of partially automated systems and the overriding safety concerns, makes the large-scale development of driverless cars for public use a dubious endeavor.

Over the past century, technology has undeniably advanced, and its progress continues.  This advancement has made driverless cars a present-day possibility, thanks to the ingenuity of car manufacturers.  This wave of innovation promises to revolutionize transportation, offering substantial benefits for humanity.

Driverless cars represent not just the future, but a highly effective solution for safer roads.  Their advanced safety features promise to significantly reduce collisions and accidents.  Unlike human drivers, autonomous vehicles adhere strictly to safety protocols, benefiting not only their occupants but also everyone else on the road.  Reckless driving, a major cause of accidents, would be virtually eliminated.

The potential for accident reduction is immense.  Driverless cars eliminate the risks associated with impaired driving, texting while driving, and driver fatigue.  Consider the danger posed by an intoxicated driver.  An autonomous vehicle removes this danger entirely.  Similarly, the risks of texting and driving, and falling asleep at the wheel, are mitigated by the technology and sensors of driverless cars, leading to a substantial decrease in accidents and fatalities.

In large cities, driverless cars offer advantages over traditional taxis and buses.  Environmentally, they are projected to consume half the fuel of current taxis, addressing growing concerns about air pollution.  Their flexibility and efficiency could also transform public transportation.  With a fleet of driverless vehicles, public transit could become significantly faster and more fluid.

Unlike taxis with fixed schedules and fares, driverless public transportation would be available on demand and free of charge, as there would be no driver to pay.  This could revolutionize city life and potentially reshape our world.

With the potential to save lives and protect the environment, driverless cars possess numerous positive attributes.  They promise a safer, cleaner, and more efficient future for all.  Undoubtedly, driverless cars are the way forward, enhancing the well-being of the human population.

The truck bucked on the dirt track, wrenching the steering wheel from my grip for a moment. I tightened my hold, headlights cutting through the darkness. A grim chuckle escaped me. Two fucking tours in Iraq and Afghanistan, and this was what I was doing? Using skills honed for the "greater good" against lowlife street thugs who'd crossed the wrong people? "Pays good," I muttered, flicking my cigarette out the window.  In the distance, a truck waited ominously in the field.

I could hear the guy inside, muffled cries for help straining against the duct tape. "It's no use, kid! Stop struggling. It'll be done soon," I yelled.

They always struggled. Survival instinct, fueled by terror, was a potent cocktail when someone realized their life might end. I flashed my headlights twiceâ€”the signalâ€”and the other truck responded in kind. A precaution against some well-meaning hillbilly stumbling across the scene. The thought of a do-gooder interrupting this made me chuckle darkly.

My truck rolled to a stop. I hopped out, lit another Marlboro Red, and let the familiar burn settle my nerves.  It always had, and it always would.

"You ready?" a voice called from the other truck.

"Hang on," I shouted back, taking a final drag. "Just need to get my gun."

Inside the glove compartment was the usual: a specialized Glock with a suppressor. Whoever wanted this guy dead wanted it done quietly.  Didn't matter to me who ordered the hit. Never had, never would.

The kid in the trunk was skinny, shaking under a duffel bag, the stench of urine thick in the air. I hated when they pissed themselves. I hauled him out by the scruff of his neck. He barely struggled, paralyzed by fear.  Everyone had seen the movies. Everyone knew the score.

"Signal out here is fucking awful, right?" the other thug said as I dumped the kid on the ground beside the unmarked grave.

I checked my phone. No bars. "Agreed," I grunted, cutting the conversation short. These things never lasted long.

"Take off the bag and the duct tape for the picture. I gotta take a quick piss," I told the thug. He nodded. I ducked behind the truck, eager to finish up and get back to town, maybe find a cheap hooker.

When I returned, the bag and tape were gone. The kid was staring at the ground, hisâ€¦ oddly familiar brown hairâ€¦ No, I was just tired. Time to get this over with.

"Look up to the camera," I ordered, pulling out my phone.

"Tommyâ€¦ Tommy? What the fuck, Tommy? What are you doing?"  It wasn't a kid. It was Jonathan. My stomach lurched. What the hell was he doing here?  Dizziness washed over me. How? Why him? He was innocent. He was my best friend. Harmless.

"You know this guy?" the thug asked, puzzled.

I couldn't speak for a moment.  "Sure I know him. We go way back. Iâ€¦ I can't do this to him. I've known him since I was five. Get up, Johnny. We're leaving." I started toward him.

A metallic click. The thug aimed the gun at me. "You got fifty grand for this. The boss ain't gonna let this slide. You made an agreement. Now fulfill it, or do I have to do it for you?" He gestured with the gun toward a bruised and bloodied Jonathan.

A driverless car offers significant benefits, especially for long-distance travel.  For those who can't afford to fly, it provides a comfortable alternative to enduring long hours behind the wheel.  While occasional stops for fuel would still be necessary, the overall experience would be far more relaxing.

Imagine traveling to California or Florida, simply reclining your seat and enjoying the journey.  Some models might even feature integrated televisions in the dashboard, allowing passengers to watch movies or shows.  This eliminates the fatigue and distractions associated with traditional driving, such as drowsiness or cell phone use.  If needed, the system could automatically disable the entertainment system, reposition the seat, and alert the driver to take control.  Advanced sensors would detect potential hazards far ahead, providing ample time to react.

Luxury car manufacturers like Cadillac or Audi could further enhance the experience by designing opulent and comfortable interiors. This could make long-distance travel by car more appealing than dealing with airport security lines and the hassles of flying. Of course, ensuring passenger safety in the event of an accident would be paramount.

The risk of falling asleep at the wheel is a serious concern, and driverless technology offers a potential solution. Drowsy driving is a significant problem in the US, and autonomous vehicles could dramatically improve road safety.

En EspaÃ±a, requiere un total de 190 participantes: 75 en cada uno de los dos centros madrileÃ±os y 40 en el cÃ¡ntabro. Measuring the relatedness between two words is a common task.  Automated approaches generally fall into three categories [22]: corpus-based methods, knowledge-based methods, and hybrid methods. Corpus-based methods leverage large text corpora and analyze word co-occurrence, as exemplified in [47].  Knowledge-based methods rely on structured resources like knowledge graphs or ontologies, such as in [13]. Hybrid methods combine these approaches, as seen in [38].  Due to the abundance of textual data and advancements in natural language processing, corpus-based methods have been extensively studied. Knowledge-based methods, the focus of this paper, depend on the availability and quality of a knowledge base. These methods require mapping words to knowledge base resources, bridging the gap between linguistic and knowledge-based representations.

Ontologies have become prominent knowledge representation tools, particularly for advanced reasoning, since the rise of the Semantic Web.  However, they have limitations: (i) creation and maintenance are often manual and costly; (ii) general-purpose ontologies, like WordNet, primarily contain hierarchical relations ( *is a* and *part of*) and offer limited relation types.  Note that similarity, a key concept in clustering [6], is also fundamental. Clustering, which partitions data into similar groups, has been widely studied, for instance, in ontology matching [10] to handle large-scale ontologies by decomposing instances into smaller clusters. Clustering in semantic spaces is also used for tasks like image collection summarization and self-supervision [54].  Resim (Resource Similarity), a measure for evaluating semantic similarity of DBpedia resources, was introduced, and subsequently, a more general relatedness approach was proposed in [44], which is one of the ten methods examined in this work (see Sections 5.2 and A.2.2).

This paper specifically addresses semantic relatedness, rather than the narrower concept of semantic similarity.  Domain-specific semantic relatedness measures and datasets (e.g., biomedicine [31]) are excluded because their effectiveness often doesn't generalize well [22].

The analyzed approaches are categorized into three groups based on their reliance on WordNet, Wikipedia, and Machine Learning, respectively.  Two recent methods, [39] and [2], deserve mention.  The former proposes a cross-domain item closeness measure for recommender systems based on co-occurrence counts of item-describing words on web pages. The latter evaluates semantic relatedness in unstructured data using fuzzy vectors and various relatedness techniques.  However, neither is knowledge-based and thus are excluded from our experiment.

**WordNet:**  WordNet, a relatively simple knowledge graph modeling the English lexicon, primarily contains taxonomic (*is a*) and meronymic (*part of*) relations, with fewer thematic relations (see the next section on semantic relations). Several WordNet-based semantic relatedness approaches exist [57, 5, 33].  [57] addresses relatedness in labeled tree data using WordNet's hierarchical relations.  [5] introduces a method based on weighted paths defined by non-taxonomic relations, noting that most existing methods rely on *is a*.  [33] combines WordNet with word embedding for performance improvement.  [59] defines a random walk-based algorithm, but its evaluation is limited to WordNet. This paper excludes WordNet-specific approaches, focusing on methods applicable to larger, more relationally diverse knowledge graphs.

**Wikipedia:**  Wikipedia, a vast online encyclopedia, can be viewed as a large corpus with entities described in natural language.  Extracting structured information requires substantial pre-processing.  The aforementioned WCG is a hybrid structure, not a strict *is a* taxonomy, designed for Wikipedia article management.  Research exploring the trade-off between natural language query expressivity and usability over Linked Data is valuable.  [20] presents the TREO system, combining entity search, TF-IDF [3], spreading activation, and WLM (analyzed in this work â€“ see Sections 5.1 and A.1.1).  Similarly, [60] combines knowledge graphs and text similarity for complex question answering.  Wikipedia-focused approaches, often relying on corpus-based techniques and natural language processing beyond this work's scope, are excluded, except for WLM, analyzed in its RDF graph form.

**Machine Learning:**  Recent work applies machine learning to semantic relatedness, encoding knowledge as numerical vectors (word embedding for text, graph embedding for graphs).  Examples of word embedding for semantic relatedness include [35, 52, 65].  [35] aims for better accuracy in various contexts. [52] represents keyphrases for similar news article retrieval. [65] constructs a relatedness graph for sentiment analysis. However, the first two are corpus-based, and the third is a hybrid approach, thus excluded from our experiment.  Regarding graph embedding, [50] proposes RDF2Vec using neural networks for Linked Data relatedness. This is arguably the first approach leveraging graph structure and neural language modeling for entity relatedness/similarity. However, computational cost remains a challenge [8], with experiments on even small datasets facing termination or memory issues.  Computational efficiency in this area is an open problem [7] beyond this paper's scope.  Finally, [26] applies machine learning to images representing words, investigating cognitive mechanisms using deep convolutional neural networks but doesn't involve graph-based knowledge, the focus of this work.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is realized through the synthesis and analysis capabilities of computational agents.  These agents employ various learning techniques and data training to achieve specified goals. When these agents are represented computationally, they are referred to as computational agents [David L. Poole, 2010; Elaine Rich, 2010]. AI has revolutionized many aspects of our lives, thanks to cutting-edge research. However, this rapidly evolving field constantly demands new paradigms to create even more accurate and reliable AI systems.  AI encompasses a broad spectrum of research areas, including machine learning, data mining, intelligent tutoring, case-based reasoning, multi-agent planning, scheduling, uncertain reasoning, natural language understanding and translation, vision, virtual reality, games, robotics, and more [Zawacki-Richter et al., 2019; Chen et al., 2020; Nilsson, 2010; Goodrich and Schultz, 2007; Buczak and Guven, 2016; Bahrammirzaee, 2010; Bengio et al., 2013; Brougham and Haar, 2018; Corvalan, 2018; Ghahramani, 2015; Castelvecchi].

Currently, Machine Learning (ML) is a particularly active area of AI research.  ML focuses on developing intelligent systems through data training. A system model trained on a dataset can then make predictions about the nature of future data (test data). Common ML techniques include data understanding (normalization and processing), regression, clustering, classification, dimension reduction, deep learning, big data handling, and online learning [McDonald, 1989; Musumeci et al., 2019; Bishop, 2006; Chapelle et al., 2006; Collobert et al., 2011; Du et al.; Freund and Schapire, 1997; Grira et al., 2004; Guyon and Elisseeff, 2006; LeCun et al., 2015a; Pedregosa et al., 2011; Vapnik, 1998]. Each technique offers unique approaches to data handling, feature computation, and output generation.

The article, "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," attempts to argue that exploring Venus is worthwhile despite the inherent risks. However, the author undermines their own argument by presenting a more compelling case *against* Venusian exploration.  The inclusion of numerous drawbacks ultimately weakens the author's thesis and damages their overall argument.

Right from the outset, the author highlights the dangers of Venus, stating that "no spacecraft survived the landing for more than a few hours" and that "not a single spaceship has touched down on Venus in more than three decades." These statements immediately create a negative impression, suggesting the extreme difficulty and potential futility of such an endeavor.  Instead of inspiring interest, the author evokes fear and apprehension by emphasizing the planet's hostility.  Phrases like "thick atmosphere," "corrosive sulfuric acid," "800 degrees Fahrenheit," and "extreme" further solidify this image of Venus as an inhospitable and dangerous world.

While the author asserts that "Venus can sometimes be our nearest option for a planetary visit," this argument lacks substantial support. The author provides little evidence to demonstrate the benefits of exploring Venus, offering significantly less detail compared to the extensive description of its dangers.  Consequently, the potential downsidesâ€”death, wasted resources, and timeâ€”seem to far outweigh any potential advantages.

The author's focus on the perilous conditions of Venus ultimately overshadows any arguments in favor of exploration.  The unlivable environment and hazardous atmosphere presented by the author inadvertently demonstrate that Venus is likely too dangerous to explore at present.  This ultimately leads the reader to conclude that the author fails to effectively support their thesis due to a lack of compelling evidence and a preponderance of counter-arguments.

Quantum computation faces a key challenge: efficiently synthesizing short sequences of implementable quantum gates, or circuits, that realize a given unitary operation. This paper addresses this challenge for Clifford circuits, a subset of unitary transformations crucial in diverse areas such as quantum error correction, state distillation, randomized benchmarking, entanglement studies, and shadow tomography [2, 5, 6, 16, 20, 21, 23, 25].  Clifford circuits are not only important components of physical-level and fault-tolerant quantum circuits but can also constitute entire algorithms, like the Bernstein-Vazirani algorithm and its generalizations [9, 25].

The Clifford group's significance stems from its property of being a unitary 2-design [11, 12]. This means random Clifford elements effectively mimic Haar random unitaries in applications depending on second-order moments, while offering the advantage of efficient circuit implementation.  For instance, randomized benchmarking leverages random Clifford sequences to efficiently estimate gate fidelities [21, 23], and classical shadows utilize random Clifford rotations to concisely represent quantum states for efficient property determination [16]. In both cases, the efficient implementation of random Clifford elements is paramount.

Furthermore, Clifford circuits facilitate basis changes in quantum simulation algorithms. They can diagonalize commuting Pauli operators, reducing circuit depth in quantum chemistry simulations [30], or identify and eliminate qubits based on symmetries, simplifying the simulation [8, 28].

While asymptotically optimal Clifford circuit synthesis exists, achieving *practically* optimal circuits with minimal entangling gates, specifically CNOT gates, remains a challenge.  We prioritize CNOT minimization due to the higher cost of entangling gates in physical implementations, initially disregarding connectivity constraints.  While ignoring connectivity can theoretically increase CNOT count or depth in the worst-case scenario (e.g., implementing a long-range CNOT gate in a linear architecture), the difference between all-to-all and Linear Nearest Neighbor (LNN) architectures appears relatively small based on known upper and lower bounds [7, 15, 22, 26].  Adapting our methods for specific connectivity constraints and depth minimization is straightforward.

Existing methods for exactly optimal Clifford synthesis are computationally expensive, limited to six qubits [10]. This necessitates efficient heuristics for larger circuits.  This paper presents heuristic approaches for synthesizing and optimizing Clifford circuits, bridging the gap between impractical optimal methods and suboptimal, albeit asymptotically optimal, techniques. Our synthesizer reduces the tableau representation of a Clifford unitary to the identity, while our optimization approach extends and modifies template matching [24] and peephole optimization [27].

Our optimization process involves three stages. First, the synthesized circuit is partitioned into "compute," "swap," and "Pauli" stages.  Pauli and swap gates are pushed to the end, allowing the "compute" stage to be optimized using templates. The "swap" stage is then optimized by merging swaps with CNOT or CZ gates.

Aaron's legs were numb.  The leather-bound swivel chair, his eight-hour-a-day prison, groaned beneath him, and the computer screen assaulted his already dry eyes.  It was 3:28â€”for the last hour and a half, his pupils had been mirroring the sweep of the second hand on his watch. All day, the sounds of clicking mice, ringing phones, and clacking keyboards had played like a maddening, inescapable radio. His eyes traced another lap around the clock face before briefly closing. What better time for coffee than 3:30?

He stood, letting his chair exhale as blood rushed back into his legs. For the first time in what felt like an eternity, his gaze cleared the cubicle walls, taking in the entire office, all seventeen workers, his boss included. Same people. Same spots. Every single day.

Mug of scalding, over-brewed coffee in one hand, napkin anticipating the inevitable spill in the other, he took the thirty-eight steps from the break room back to his five-by-five cubicle.  A flimsy-walled fortress offering zero privacy that he, pathetically, considered his second home.  As he settled back in, the chair groaned again, and his legs began to lose feeling. Wincing at the first, burning sip of coffee, he licked his lips and reached to set the mug down beside his keyboard, when he noticed a slip of paper.

Lip still stinging, he cautiously picked up the sheet. Glancing over his shoulder, he began to read:

> Dearest Worker,

> How cowardly of me to leave a note instead of offering a handshake. My apologies. My name is inconsequential to the events that will slowly unfold within the next hour and a half. All you truly need to know is that I wrote this note for youâ€”only you. You cannot stop the countdown, but you are welcome to join.

> Sincere Condolences.

As the last word echoed in his mind, a voice broke the silence.

"Heyâ€”uh," his boss stammered, "I was headed outside for a smoke, and the door's locked. Or something's blocking it. Did one of you do that?"

Seventeen pairs of eyes darted around the room, searching for an explanation.

I signed back that I couldn't.

"Go near the music," she signed, gesturing toward the bass at the edge of the crowd where I could better feel the vibration.

I felt uncomfortable. The air was thick and close, everyone pressed together.  People moved to invisible waves, like theyâ€™d all gone mad and I was the only sane one. Hearing people were strange.

"Better?" My date asked, raising her eyebrows â€“ a non-manual marker.

"Yes," I signed back, tapping the air.

Some of the dancers were staring.

I would have been self-conscious if J hadn't smiled. J was her name signâ€”signed near my cheek, like the sign for â€œjuice.â€ Her written name was Jenny.

Nervous and unsure what to sign, I welcomed the moment she took my hand and pressed it against the pulsating speaker.  Noticing more stares, I focused on J instead, watching her as I awkwardly swayed along with the other dancers in what felt like my own personal asylum.

I would rather have been home, watching a dubbed movie or reading a bookâ€”anything besides this exhibition where I felt like an art piece, displayed for a bunch of gawking onlookers. I was tempted to leave that very moment and drive myself home.

Unfortunately, J had driven. I desperately hoped sheâ€™d offered simply to save me the trouble of finding the place, and not because she assumed I couldn't drive.

He had been sitting all night in the overstuffed armchair in the living room, thinking. He felt miserably lonely and afraid.  A sudden stinging in his hand roused him from his contemplative staring. The cigarette had burned right down to his hand again, right between his index finger and middle finger. Reflexively, he dropped it to the floor.  Its glowing ember immediately left a black dot on the red carpet beneath him. He moved his foot over and squashed the ember with his sneaker; there were now eight more or less identical dots in a random pattern on the living room floor.

Out on the city street a police siren blared its obnoxious alarm, rising to a screeching pitch as it came down the street, then gradually fading away. The sirens frightened him. It seemed like they sounded every ten minutes. The apartment around him felt grimy.

He missed Alice's voice. He missed the comfort of its soothing, distinctly feminine tone, even amid all the others.  Its high-pitched, naturally female sound soared above â€“ if not entirely covering â€“ the garbled mess of the bad voices below. He had gotten used to those bad voices; he had learned to ignore them.  She soared so high above them, did they even matter anymore?

He squinted, spying the orange cylinder on the kitchen sink.  Did he take them this morning? He remembered taking them yesterday morning, but last night was a blur.  He wanted a comforting voice to soothe him.  Alice was an angel, there to protect him, but he couldnâ€™t hear her anymore. He had blotted her out, like a hand shielding a face from the sun. No good could come from it.  He walked over to the kitchen sink, and poured what was left of the cylinder down the drain.

Kansas Cattle Producers Worry Tyson Fire Will Exacerbate Processing Bottleneck

HOLCOMB, Kan. (AP) â€” A fire at a Tyson meat processing plant in Holcomb has Kansas cattle producers worried about further disruptions to already strained processing operations.

The plant, which processes approximately 6,000 cattle a dayâ€”about 6% of the U.S. totalâ€”is closed indefinitely following Friday's fire.  Tyson has committed to reopening the facility, but the timeline remains uncertain pending a damage assessment.

According to the *Topeka Capital-Journal*, industry experts note the closure exacerbates existing capacity issues at meatpacking plants, which are already struggling to process a record number of cattle coming to market.

Finney County commissioner Larry Jones, a partner at J&O Cattle Co., explained that packing plants are currently operating at full capacity.

Cattle futures dropped the daily limit of $3 per hundred pounds on Monday, the first day of trading since the fire.
