With the increasing penetration of distributed generations (DG), particularly inverter-based energy resources (IB-ER), in active distribution networks (ADNs), voltage violations and high network losses are becoming more severe, especially with reversed active power flow.  While IB-ERs can provide Volt/VAR control (VVC) support, effectively leveraging this capability presents challenges.  Traditional model-based VVC optimization methods, which generate optimal strategies for voltage regulation devices and reactive power resources, struggle due to inaccuracies in network parameters. These theoretical parameters often deviate significantly from real-world operational states, creating a model mismatch that hinders practical application.

This paper proposes a novel two-stage deep reinforcement learning (DRL) method for optimizing reactive power distribution in ADNs, addressing the limitations of model-based approaches.  The method combines offline learning with online learning and application, leveraging the benefits of both model-based and model-free control.

In the offline stage, an approximate ADN model is constructed using theoretical parameters.  Recognizing the inherent inaccuracies, a novel joint adversarial soft actor-critic (JASAC) algorithm is employed within an adversarial Markov decision process (AMDP) framework.  An adversary agent, representing modeling errors and risks, is trained alongside the offline agent (OFF-A). This adversarial training enhances the OFF-A's robustness to model mismatch, minimizing the "transfer gap" when applied to the real system.  JASAC leverages shared information between the adversary and OFF-A, ensuring efficient convergence.

The online stage utilizes the knowledge gained offline. The OFF-A is transferred to an online agent (ON-A), which continues learning and application using the state-of-the-art soft actor-critic (SAC) algorithm.  This offline pre-training significantly accelerates online training and improves safety, mitigating the risks associated with deploying untrained DRL agents directly in real-world systems.

This two-stage approach offers several key advantages: 1) It combines the practicality of model-free online operation with the efficiency of incorporating approximate model knowledge offline. 2) The novel JASAC algorithm, applicable to other DRL applications, efficiently trains a robust OFF-A through adversarial learning. 3) Transferring the robust OFF-A to the online stage significantly improves performance and safety compared to existing DRL-based VVC methods.

The remainder of this paper is structured as follows: Section II formulates the VVC problem as an MDP for the online stage and an AMDP for the offline stage.  Section III details the proposed VVC algorithm and JASAC.  Section IV presents and analyzes the numerical results.  Finally, Section V concludes the paper.  VVC has been successfully integrated into distribution management systems to optimize reactive power flow, eliminating voltage violations and reducing network losses. Conventionally, VVC employs model-based optimization to generate optimal strategies for voltage regulation devices and reactive power resources.  Numerous centralized and decentralized algorithms exist, including conic relaxation, interior point methods, mixed integer linear programming, evolutionary algorithms, local control, alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM), and robust/scenario-based optimization techniques.  However, these methods rely on accurate system models.  Model-free methods, such as those based on game theory or gradient-based optimization applied to wind farm control, offer an alternative.  Recently, DRL algorithms have shown promise in various control tasks, leading to the development of DRL-based VVC methods.  However, online training of DRL agents can be costly and risky. Offline training using simulated ADN models is preferable, but model inaccuracies necessitate specialized algorithms to bridge the transfer gap.  This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant 51725703). H. Liu and W. Wu (Corresponding Author) are with the State Key Laboratory of Power Systems, Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China (email:lht18@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn, wuwench@tsinghua.edu.cn).

The idea of a monument built by aliens on Mars is highly controversial.  While some believe the so-called "Face on Mars" is evidence of extraterrestrial construction, others maintain it's a natural formation.  Recent high-resolution photographs of this Martian feature provide compelling evidence to support the latter view.

NASA's exploration of Mars, beginning with the Viking 1 orbiter in 1976, has yielded increasingly detailed images of the "Face."  Initial photographs, revealing a mesa that resembled a face, fueled speculation about an ancient civilization.  Subsequent missions, including further observations in 1998 and 2001, captured the feature with significantly improved resolution.

Despite claims that the "Face" exhibits artificial characteristics, the enhanced photographic detail strongly suggests a natural origin.  Multiple high-resolution images clearly indicate that the feature is a rock formation, likely a lava dome shaped into an isolated mesa, similar in height to the "Face." The article also mentions this geological explanation.

Therefore, the prevailing evidence supports the conclusion that the "Face on Mars" is a natural phenomenon. The improved clarity of recent photographs significantly strengthens the case against artificial construction, confirming its identity as a geological formation.

Intelligent reflecting surface (IRS)-assisted communication has emerged as a promising technology to meet the increasing demand for high spectral and energy efficiency in future wireless systems.  Comprising cost-effective, passive, and programmable elements, IRSs can intelligently manipulate wireless propagation environments, tailoring signal paths between communication nodes [1]â€“[6]. This allows for directing transmitted signal energy via beamforming, leading to significant power savings.  Furthermore, IRSs, typically fabricated as thin rectangular planes, can be easily integrated into existing infrastructure by attaching them to building facades, indoor ceilings, and vehicles [6], [7].  Driven by these advantages, research has explored IRS applications for enhancing multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) transmission [8], physical layer security [9], and simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (SWIPT) [10].

To fully realize the potential of IRSs, careful design of both the IRS phase shift configuration and the base station (BS) transmit beamforming is crucial [4], [6], [10], [11].  Several studies have investigated joint BS beamforming and IRS reflection coefficient design to minimize total transmit power while guaranteeing user quality-of-service (QoS).  Assuming perfect channel state information (CSI), transmit power minimization problems have been explored for various IRS-assisted wireless systems, including multiuser MIMO systems [2], secure wireless systems [11], and SWIPT systems [10]. However, the significant power savings reported in [2], [10], and [11] rely on the assumption of continuous IRS phase shifts, which is impractical.  Due to challenges such as high energy consumption, integration complexity, and component coupling, practical IRS elements typically employ discrete, low-resolution phase shifters, often 1-bit (on-off) or 2-bit (quadruple-level) [4], [6], [12].

Consequently, research has begun investigating resource allocation with discrete IRS phase shifts.  For example, [12] proposed a suboptimal alternating optimization (AO)-based algorithm to promote user fairness in multiuser systems.  However, as shown in [8] and [11], AO-based algorithms for these non-convex optimization problems compromise optimality, often converging to local optima and exhibiting performance dependence on initial points [8], [11], [13].  To explore optimal performance, [4] considered a single-user scenario, determining the optimal BS beamformer and discrete IRS phase shifts using enumeration. This approach, however, is difficult to extend to multiuser systems due to the complexity of finding closed-form optimal beamforming vectors.  Furthermore, assuming perfect CSI, the conference version of this paper [1] presented a generalized Benders decomposition (GBD)-based algorithm for a simplified multiuser system without a direct BS-user link.  However, optimal design for IRS-assisted multiuser multiple-input single-output (MISO) systems with a direct link and imperfect CSI remains an open problem.

While [1] and [4] assume perfect CSI, acquiring accurate CSI in passive IRS systems is challenging.  Conventional channel estimation methods struggle with IRS-assisted links, leading to inevitable channel estimation errors and imperfect CSI [7], [9].  Furthermore, BS-IRS and IRS-user channels are typically cascaded for end-to-end estimation, requiring joint consideration of their CSI and estimation errors [7], [14]. Consequently, robust designs for imperfect CSI have been studied.  For instance, [7] and [14] employed worst-case robust optimization methods based on linear approximation and successive convex approximation (SCA), respectively, assuming continuous phase shifts.  However, even with this optimistic assumption, global optimality is not guaranteed.  A globally optimal robust resource allocation framework for practical IRS systems with imperfect CSI and discrete phase shifters is still lacking.

Motivated by this, we investigate, for the first time, globally optimal joint BS beamforming and IRS phase shift design for multiuser IRS-assisted systems with discrete phase shifters. Our contributions are:

* We study resource allocation in IRS-assisted systems with discrete phase shifters, minimizing BS transmit power while guaranteeing minimum signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) for each user. We develop optimal and suboptimal strategies for both perfect and imperfect CSI.
* For perfect CSI, we formulate the joint design problem as a mixed integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) problem and propose transformations enabling a GBD-based iterative algorithm that guarantees convergence to the globally optimal solution. This algorithm provides a performance benchmark for suboptimal designs [4], [12].  We also develop a computationally efficient suboptimal SCA-based scheme.
* We extend our framework to imperfect CSI, recasting robust SINR constraints as linear matrix inequality (LMI) constraints and formulating a robust MINLP problem.

The quiet neighborhood, an undisclosed location meant to keep the Captain's whereabouts a secret, was speculated to be somewhere in upstate New York, perhaps not far from his birthplace.  While many suggested Steve move further afield, even to another country, for a life truly off the grid, his response was characteristically straightforward: "I'm not going to live my life in hiding or fear. I plan on enjoying my retirement."  And he did just that.  He'd purchased a fixer-upper, an older home needing plenty of workâ€”a perfect project to keep him busy. It was an average neighborhood: suburban life with a watch, carpools, holiday barbecues, and a community garden.

The first few nights were spent on a military-issue cot, but the rough conditions were nothing new to Steve, and he slept soundly.  His days started early: measuring, making lists of materials, trips to the lumber yard. People were either politely oblivious to the fact that Captain America was buying lumber and renting equipment, or they genuinely didn't recognize him.  Either way, he appreciated the anonymity.  The work was easy. Decades spent honing his superhuman body for battle translated surprisingly well to demolition and rebuilding.  He found himself reflecting on years past, a flicker of longing for Tony already surfacing.

A knock broke his reverie.  He opened the door, jeans and shirt smeared with grime, wiping his hands on a rag. "Hello there, we're your neighbors. I'm Liz Lee, and this is my son Nathan." Liz, in her late twenties or early thirties, smiled.  Nathan, about seven, held up a bowl, his words tumbling out in an excited rush. "We brought you fruit, bread, and some snacks!"  Steve, cleaning his hand, shook Liz's hand and bent down to Nathan. "Well, that was mighty nice of you and your mother to bring me some food, Nathan."

Before Steve could say more, Nathan blurted, "ARE YOU CAPTAIN AMERICA?"  Steve laughed, while Liz admonished, "Nathan Lee, what did I say about that!"  Steve reassured her, "No, that's okay, Mrs. Leeâ€”Liz.â€ He corrected himself, meeting Nathanâ€™s awestruck gaze. "To answer your question, Nathan, no. Sorry, buddy. I'm not Captain America." Nathan's face fell, but then Steve winked. "I *used* to be Captain America. I'm retired now." The boy's face lit up again.  Turning back to Liz, Steve continued, "But please, I'm done with that. I'm just here to fix up this place and be part of the community. Just call me Steve."

â€œWelcome to the neighborhood, Steve. Let us know if you need anything,â€ Liz offered warmly.  "Thank you, Liz, I will. And thank you again, Nathan, for the food." Nathan, speechless, was nudged by his mother.  "Oh, you're welcome."  "Nice to meet you, Steve," Liz said, taking Nathan's hand.

The distribution shift between training and testing data, known as domain shift, poses a significant challenge in real-world applications. Domain generalization attempts to mitigate this by learning a universal model from available source datasets without access to the target data (Ghifary et al., 2016; Motiian et al., 2017).  Existing methods predominantly focus on learning domain-invariant representations across source domains (Muandet et al., 2013; Ghifary et al., 2015; Motiian et al., 2017; Li et al., 2018a; b). However, these approaches can falter in complex scenarios.

Consider the data model Y â†’ X defined on X Ã— Y.  Given a class label Y, feature X is generated by conditional distributions D<sub>y</sub>(X) = P<sub>D</sub>(X|Y = y), where D represents either a source domain (S<sub>m</sub>, m = 1, . . . , M) or the target domain T.  Most domain generalization methods assume that for a fixed y âˆˆ Y, the target domain's class-conditional distribution T(X|Y = y) is closer to at least one source class-conditional S<sub>m</sub>(X|Y = y) than to any distribution of a different class (Figure 1 Left). In such ideal cases, even simple k-NN methods can perform well.  However, performance degrades when the variation among class-conditionals of the same class is substantial, meaning the closest conditional distribution to T(X|Y = y) is S(X|Y = y') where y' â‰  y (Figure 1 Right) (Krueger et al., 2020).

This work proposes a class-conditioned domain generalization method inspired by distributional robust optimization (Kuhn et al., 2019).  This approach optimizes the worst-case performance over a set of distributionsâ€”the uncertainty setâ€”centered around observed reference distributions. We assume that class-conditionals of different domains form class-specific uncertainty sets, aiming to learn a universally robust classifier that remains discriminative even under the worst-case distributions within these sets.

A key challenge lies in defining a robust and computable uncertainty set.  Gao et al. (2018) addressed this for a single source domain using the Wasserstein distance, formulating the robust optimization problem as a solvable convex optimization problem.  However, the choice of parameters in Gao et al. (2018) significantly impacts generalization performance.  Our method leverages the Wasserstein barycenter as the reference distribution and employs an iterative algorithm to automatically learn the optimal radius.


## 2 BACKGROUND

Gao et al. (2018) formulated robust hypothesis testing as a minimax problem considering distributional uncertainty. As part of the 20th-anniversary celebrations of his ascension to the Golden Stool, Otumfuo Osei Tutu II was honored with a state banquet in Kumasi, hosted by President Akufo-Addo. Held last Friday at the Ashanti Regional Coordinating Council (RCC), the event attracted numerous dignitaries, all adhering to a strict dress code.

The banquet was punctuated by memorable moments, including a dance between Otumfuo and First Lady Rebecca Akufo-Addo, which drew enthusiastic applause.  Nearby, President Akufo-Addo danced with Lady Julia Osei Tutu, the wife of the Asantehene. Former First Lady Nana Konadu Agyeman Rawlings also graced the dance floor, showcasing her impressive footwork.  Highlife legend Abrante Amakye Dede captivated the audience with a stellar performance.

In a brief speech, President Akufo-Addo eulogized Otumfuo, highlighting his contributions to Ghana's political and socio-economic growth.  Describing the Asantehene as a good friend of 40 years, the President lauded Otumfuo's instrumental role in resolving the Dagbon chieftaincy dispute. He praised his work as chairperson of the Committee of Eminent Chiefs, alongside Nayiri, the Overlord of Mamprugu, and Yogbonwura, the Overlord of the Gonja state, in achieving a lasting peace.  The President further commended Otumfuo's achievements in education through the Otumfuo Education Fund, his efforts in combating HIV/AIDS, and his revitalization of the institution of chieftaincy.  President Akufo-Addo then proposed a toast to Otumfuoâ€™s long life and good health.

Otumfuo, in his response, acknowledged his long-standing relationship with President Akufo-Addo, who previously served as his personal lawyer. He expressed his appreciation for the state banquet and affirmed Asanteman's continued commitment to national transformation.  Pledging his collaboration with the President for the development of the country, particularly within his kingdom, Otumfuo painted a poignant picture of the challenges facing the Ashanti Region: "You walk alone on this path and you are struck by the picture of an old lady in the twilight of her years in decline of seeming neglect and a picture of despair. Sadly this picture is not exclusive but a reflection of the challenges confronting the people in the Ashanti Region.â€ He then challenged the President and the nation: â€œMr. President this is a challenge we must face together. A challenge we must overcome.

A strange sense of familiarity washed over me as the boy sat on my knee. I couldn't quite place him. He glanced back at his parents, then grinned at me, scooting closer and tilting his head up. "Kill the reindeer," he said.

I recoiled in surprise. "Excuse me? Do you even know what you're saying?"

"Yes."

I wrestled with the notion that this child must have had a traumatic experience. Perhaps a video game had warped his perception.  But he seemed so young.  I couldn't grasp the situation.  "Kill the reindeer, Santa."

My eyes darted from his small face to his parents. They stood waiting patiently with a dog and two teenagers, seemingly oblivious to their son's unsettling words. Only the cameraman seemed to register my shock, probably misinterpreting it as a reaction to some innocent childhood prattle.

"What's your name, son?"

He stared at me, his initial confusion giving way to a dawning realization that I wasn't the genuine article. I could see the wheels turning in his head.  The way he reacted was bizarre, reinforcing the nagging feeling that I'd encountered him before and that he was older than he appeared.

"Who are *you*?"  His confusion morphed into indignation, then disgust.  He reached into his back pocket, producing a small device I couldn't identify.  Suddenly, he pushed against my chest, attempting to jump down.

"NO!" His mother, a blur of red-orange hair, rushed forward to lift him from my lap.  As I tumbled from the throne-like chair, I saw the fatherâ€™s green pants moving toward us. A sharp pain pierced my chest.  Dizziness washed over me. The boy had stabbed me with the device. *How?*

"Sorry, Santa. If that *is* your real nameâ€¦" The father glared, his expression hinting at a perverse hope that I *was* the real Santa. The situation spiraled further into the surreal. The teenage boy in the blue shirt cried, "SANTA, SANTA, no!" The teenage girl simply stood there, her faceâ€¦ unsettling.

Then it hit me. This was the family from the news report the other night. The one involved in the bizarre incident that destroyed a neighbor's bathroom. The newsman had ridiculed the story: the father in the green pants had apparently purchased a tank and fired it at the house across the street, obliterating the upstairs bathroom and killing the man inside. And now, their son had stabbed *me*. What in the world was going on?

As the mother lifted the boy and I struggled to regain my footing, he whispered, "...curse this housewife harlot." The dog bounded forward, the boy grabbing for its leash as his mother set him down.  They turned, rejoined the teenagers, and left. I was dumbfounded, bleeding, but overwhelmingly relieved to see them go.

"A *pumpkin*!? You turned her into a PUMPKIN!?" I swerved, narrowly missing an oncoming car.

"Oh ya, no biggie." Mort's nonchalant, even bored, voice drifted from the other end of the line. "You know how I am with my plant magic. Got a real green thumb, ye? Besides, she was being a bit of a nag, and pumpkins don't have mouths.... amiright?"

It took all my self-control not to hang up. "Mort... I told you, use magic one more time in my house, and I would have your head."

"Yeh, yeh, no need to be such a buzzkill, mate." He dismissed my threat. "But, mate. Did you even hear the rest of what I said?"

I gritted my teeth. "No, Mort. I am not going to pick you up a fifth. Hell, I am not going to pick *anything* from the store for you, *until you change her back*!"

"Alright, alright, geeze." Mort sounded exasperated. "I'll get her back to normal in a jif. Don't get your panties in a wad. Gonna need that fifth though, it's an integral part of the spell."

"Uh huh. And I'm the queen of England." My grip on the phone was so tight it was painful.

"Well, hey, if you don't *want* me to change her back.... Halloween is coming up pretty soon, mate."  His hyena-like laughter blasted through the receiver, forcing me to hold the phone away from my ear. "Naw, just playing mate. I'll set her straight. But don't forget the fifth!"

The line went dead, leaving me seething. "Alright.

"Sir Egglesworth IV, theseâ€¦ how do they call themselves? â€¦Humans? â€¦are most assuredly, utterly, and irredeemably insane!" Miss Pottsmith exclaimed, her voice a shrill squeal.

"Hmm, yesâ€¦ quite," Sir Egglesworth replied, his verbal communications characteristically reserved. He preferred to gaze at his collection of clockwork contraptions, nodding absently to himself while stroking his whiskers.

"Oh! 'Twould make a marvelous asylum! Just imagine!"  A dreamy look filled Miss Pottsmith's eyes, as if envisioning lunatics cavorting and frolicking together in some ritualistic reunion.  "I shall commission it at once!" She sipped her cold tea, humming softly to the stuffed animals arranged around her tea set.

Sir Egglesworth simply nodded.

Driverless cars represent a significant technological advancement with the potential for great utility. However, their reliability remains a concern.  I personally distrust these vehicles and wouldn't want to own one, primarily due to safety concerns, especially the risk of collisions.

My biggest reservation stems from the ambiguity surrounding liability.  Consider a scenario where, while in a driverless car, another driver runs a red light, causing a head-on collision because the autonomous vehicle couldn't react as quickly as a human.  Who would be at fault?  The driver of the other car, the manufacturer of the driverless car, or myself?  As mentioned, new traffic laws will undoubtedly be required to address these complex situations.  The limited acceptance of semi-autonomous vehicles in only three out of fifty states underscores the widespread public distrust. If manufacturers intend to release these cars by 2020, legal frameworks must be in place to protect both drivers and companies.

Furthermore, I doubt driverless cars can ever achieve the same level of awareness as human drivers.  In a crash, the car itself doesn't face the same inherent self-preservation instincts a human driver possesses.

In my opinion, the release of driverless cars in the United States should be prohibited until these issues are resolved. Perhaps a trial period in other countries could provide valuable data and inform necessary adjustments to our liability laws before their introduction here.  Currently, our legal system isn't equipped to handle the complexities driverless cars introduce.

Previous work on adapting moving frames to numerically solve PDEs on curved surfaces, including conservation laws [1], the diffusion equation [2], shallow water equations [3], and Maxwell's equations [4], has typically assigned random directions to moving frames within the tangent plane when anisotropy is absent.  Since the first moving frame, denoted as *e*â‚ , must be differentiable within each element, its direction cannot be entirely independent of neighboring frames to ensure this differentiability.  While local frame directions are linked, their average orientation remains random.  Following Cartan's original definitions [5], we refer to this distribution as zeroth-order moving frames. In this case, the moving frames simply constitute an orthonormal local reference frame reflecting the tangent plane's geometry.

First-order moving frames arise naturally by aligning *e*â‚ with the tangent vector along a wave's trajectory.  For instance, in Maxwell's equations, *e*â‚ aligns with the electric or magnetic field, while in the diffusion-reaction equation, it aligns with the gradient of the variable representing electric potential or material concentration. Second- and third-order moving frames are obtained by further aligning *e*â‚‚ and *e*â‚ƒ with the binormal and normal directions, respectively.  In many scenarios, first-order moving frames inherently satisfy the conditions for second- and third-order frames. Consequently, we can collectively refer to these non-zeroth-order moving frames as Darboux frames [6].

Amazon has suspended sales of phones from Miami-based budget phone manufacturer, Blu, for allegedly transmitting significant amounts of user data to Chinese servers.

Last week, Kryptowire revealed that this silent background data collection terminated at a company called Shanghai Adups Technology, a provider of Firmware Over The Air (FOTA) updates.  While this functionality could be legitimate, the lack of transparency is concerning.

Furthermore, Adups has a history of alleged security issues.  The company has faced repeated accusations of installing spyware and backdoors on devices to facilitate data exfiltration.

This isn't Blu's first transgression either.  The former partner in Amazon's Prime Exclusive Phones program (currently unavailable in the UK) was initially suspended last October when its Blu R1 HD was found to contain the same tracking software.

At the time, Blu claimed the inclusion was a "mistake" and removed the spyware from the R1 HD and the Life One X2 model, where it was also hidden. In some instances, the system was even transmitting SMS messages.

Now, the same security firm has discovered the same spyware from Adups on more expensive Blu phone models sold by Amazon.  This time, the collected data includes cell tower information and even more personally identifiable information. This repeated lapse in security could be considered extremely foolish.

In a statement to CNET last week, Amazon said: "Because security and privacy of our customers is of the utmost importance, all Blu phone models have been made unavailable for purchase on Amazon.com until the issue is resolved."

Blu has also faced accusations of patent infringement from BlackBerry.

The problem with driverless cars raises several safety concerns. What happens if the system fails and the occupant doesn't know how to drive?  What if a malfunction occurs, or the car breaks down and the person inside can't fix it?

Consider this: You're alone in a driverless car, traveling through a remote area, when the system suddenly stops working.  If you don't know how to drive, you're stranded.  Or, imagine navigating heavy traffic when the car unexpectedly ceases autonomous operation.  If you can't take control, a serious accident could occur.

Malfunctions present another set of dangers.  Suppose you're driving in a city and the car fails to stop at a red light.  This could result in a collision, injuries, or even fatalities. The car could also veer off the road or crash into a building.  Similarly, a sudden, uncontrolled acceleration or deceleration could have devastating consequences.

Breakdowns in driverless cars pose unique challenges.  Imagine your car breaks down on a deserted back road.  Without mechanical knowledge, your options are limited: abandon the vehicle, call for help, or attempt to diagnose the problem yourself.  Even in heavy traffic, a malfunction can lead to accidents and potentially fatal outcomes.

These are just a few potential problems associated with driverless cars. While the technology holds promise, it's crucial to address these safety concerns before widespread adoption.  Hopefully, manufacturers can mitigate these risks to ensure the safety and reliability of autonomous vehicles.

Are Driverless Cars a Good Idea?

Self-driving cars are often presented as a revolutionary advancement, a dream come true for many. However, have we fully considered the potential repercussions? While proponents emphasize features like alerts for oncoming traffic and roadwork, crucial safety questions remain unanswered. What happens if a child or an animal darts in front of the car? What prevents a collision in such unpredictable scenarios?  Surely, the safety of children outweighs the allure of a technologically advanced vehicle.

The suggestion that drivers should remain attentive while simultaneously enjoying "in-car entertainment" seems contradictory.  This entertainment sounds suspiciously like television, and it's difficult to imagine anyone maintaining focus on the road while engrossed in their favorite show.

The article mentions reinterpreting driving fun.  But does driving need to be fun?  The primary purpose of driving is transportation, getting from point A to point B.  We are already a society prone to convenience, and autonomous vehicles seem designed to amplify this laziness.  While these cars may generate substantial profits, their safety remains a serious concern.

The vibrating driver's seat designed to alert drivers to obstacles while reversing raises further questions.

No. 25 Houston Beats Cincinnati, Moves into 1st in AAC

HOUSTON (AP) â€”  No. 25 Houston overcame poor shooting with a dominant defensive effort and a 22-9 edge in offensive rebounds to defeat Cincinnati 68-55 on Sunday, moving into a tie atop the American Athletic Conference with Tulsa.

Marcus Sasser led Houston with 21 points, including 12 in the second half, while Nate Hinton added 16 and Caleb Mills chipped in 15.  Despite shooting just 36% from the field, including a dismal 2-for-19 stretch spanning the end of the first half and the beginning of the second, the Cougars (22-7, 12-4 AAC) controlled the game on the boards.

â€œTo win by shooting 36% with 22 offensive rebounds, Iâ€™d rather shoot 55% with 10 offensive rebounds,â€ Houston coach Kelvin Sampson said. â€œOur kids have learned how to win without making shots. Thatâ€™s something we preach from day one.â€  Chris Harris Jr. spearheaded the rebounding effort with 11 boards and four blocks.  â€œWe knew this was a game we needed to win,â€ Harris said. â€œWe just came out and handled business.â€

Cincinnati (18-10, 11-5 AAC) shot 35% overall and just 24% in the second half.

The author of "The Challenges of Exploring Venus" strongly advocates for further study and potential human exploration of Venus, despite the planet's hostile environment.  While acknowledging the significant dangers, the author emphasizes the scientific value of such a mission. This argument is built on several key points.

First, the author highlights Venus's potential history.  As Earth's closest planetary neighbor and most similar in size and structure, Venus may once have harbored oceans and even life. This tantalizing possibility, along with present-day features like valleys, mountains, and craters â€“ reminiscent of Earth's terrain â€“ makes a compelling case for further investigation, as explicitly stated by the author: "The value of returning to Venus seems indisputable, but what are the options for making a mission both safe and scientifically productive." This sentence clearly signals the author's desire to find solutions to the challenges of Venusian exploration.

However, the author also frankly addresses the stark differences between Earth and its "twin."  Venus's thick, carbon dioxide-rich atmosphere, sulfuric acid clouds, and scorching 800-degree Fahrenheit surface temperature create extremely inhospitable conditions for human life.  Despite these challenges, the author points out that NASA is actively pursuing solutions to enable both safe and productive missions.

One proposed solution involves deploying a blimp-like vehicle to hover approximately 30 miles above the Venusian surface. This altitude would offer some protection from the extreme surface temperatures and allow for observation and data collection above the turbulent lower atmosphere. While the high-altitude environment would still be challenging, the author notes that the temperature and air pressure at this height would be potentially survivable for humans, albeit far from ideal.

By presenting both the enticing possibilities and the daunting realities of Venusian exploration, the author effectively argues for continued research and development.

Thomas Huang's newly developed computer software can detect emotions simply by scanning a person's face.  While many people mask their emotions daily, this software can recognize even the slightest hint of discomfort or anguish. This innovation holds significant potential for the classroom.

For years, students have struggled with confusion in the classroom, often too intimidated to ask clarifying questions.  This software can identify student confusion, facilitating a more effective learning experience.  Furthermore, it can detect boredom and adjust the lesson accordingly, making it more engaging.

Despite its groundbreaking potential, this software may also have drawbacks.  For example, teachers and professors could potentially face job displacement if students no longer need to ask questions. Schools might replace educators with computers equipped with this software, decreasing the demand for teachers. While this scenario may not be imminent, it raises valid concerns that warrant discussion.

However, the benefits of this innovation are compelling. Increased utilization could lead to more engaging and effective learning experiences, eliminating student confusion and boredom.  Its applications extend beyond the classroom, with the potential to personalize advertisements and enhance video games and other media.  For these reasons, the software deserves serious consideration.

In conclusion, this new emotion-recognition software offers valuable applications both in professional settings and at home.  This technological advancement could even unlock a deeper understanding of human emotions, opening up new avenues for exploration.

Twenty-five years before May 24, 2001, a peculiar event captured public attention on Mars.  In 1976, the Viking 1 spacecraft, while orbiting Mars and scouting landing sites for its sister ship, Viking 2, captured an image of what appeared to be a shadowy, human-like face on the surface.  This image, taken in the Cydonia region, sparked considerable speculation.

On April 5, 1998, the Mars Global Surveyor, equipped with the Mars Orbiter Camera (MOC) operated by Michael Malin and his team, finally had its first opportunity to revisit Cydonia. The MOC captured images ten times sharper than the original Viking photograph. Based on this significantly improved imagery, the team concluded that the "face" was not an alien monument.

The Mars Global Surveyor made an even closer pass on April 8, 2001.  "We had to roll the spacecraft 25 degrees to center the 'Face' in the field of view," explained  Garvin, a project scientist. Malin's team acquired an exceptionally detailed image of the formation using the camera's maximum resolution.

The 2001 image achieved a resolution of 1.5 meters per pixel, a dramatic improvement over the 43 meters per pixel resolution of the 1976 Viking image.

After extensive analysis of the higher-resolution images, scientists determined that the feature is a Martian equivalent of a butte or mesa, landforms common in the American West.

The prospect of self-driving cars, like those being developed by Google, raises significant questions about the future of driving.  While reaching the age of 16 traditionally grants driving privileges, the development of autonomous vehicles may soon make a driver's license obsolete.  However, I believe the potential drawbacks of these vehicles outweigh their benefits.  From safety concerns to legal ambiguities, the risks associated with self-driving cars present a compelling argument against their widespread adoption.

The article "Driverless Cars Are Coming" highlights both the positive and negative aspects of autonomous vehicles.  While acknowledging potential advantages, I believe the negative aspects are far more critical. The article rightly questions liability in the event of an accident caused by a technological failure: "If the technology fails and someone is injured, who is at faultâ€”the driver or manufacturer?" This question underscores the inherent risks associated with relying on complex technology. The article also points out the current legal landscape: "traffic laws are written with the assumption that the only safe car has a human driver in control at all times. As a result, in most states it is illegal even to test computer-driven cars."  This demonstrates widespread concern about the safety of autonomous vehicles.

While proponents might argue that removing human error from the equation will reduce accidents, technology introduces its own set of risks. The rise in accidents due to distracted driving illustrates the dangers of human error, but transferring control to technology doesn't eliminate the possibility of failure.  2015 saw a surge in car crashes, largely attributed to texting and driving.  Eliminating human drivers wouldn't necessarily solve the problem; rather, it would shift the potential for error to glitches, hacking, and even theft. These technological vulnerabilities could lead to new forms of danger, potentially facilitating criminal activity and creating unforeseen avenues for destruction.

In conclusion, the development of self-driving cars presents more dangers than advantages. Although they may appear more sophisticated and potentially efficient, the risks of accidents, technological failures, and malicious exploitation are too significant to ignore. While Google and other companies continue to develop this technology, so too will those who seek to exploit its vulnerabilities.

"Social engineering." The words roll off the tongue, don't they?  Go ahead, say it with me: Social engineering. See? I just made you say it.  Isn't it powerful?

I've always said, fake sincerity and the world is your oyster. Dress the part, get the right haircut, flash a winning smile, perfect the handshake, and boomâ€”instant CEO.  Need an ID?  A Discordian "Official Pope" card with a decent photo, laminated, works wonders.

About a year ago, I "worked" for Turnkey Synergy Inc. (TSI).  By "worked," I mean I showed up, picked a cubicle, and blended in.  My actual employer was Synergistic Proactive Associates, looking for an edge on the competition.

TSI's senior accountant was obsessively organized.  Everything on her desk was meticulously arranged: color-coded, indexed, alphabetizedâ€”paperclips, no staples, the whole nine yards.  My favorite tactic?  Nudging a single pencil fractionally out of place, or subtly lowering her monitor. Even better, turning her family photos upside down.  Then, playing the helpful colleague, I'd point out the "error," all smiles and cheer.  She'd turn crimson with frustration, but never directed at me. Never at me.

Sending flowers to happily married John from HR assistant Toni, with a few well-placed whispers, resulted in Toni's termination. Last I heard, John's living in a hotel.  His wife was a shrew anyway; he can do better.

Scattering USB drives in the parking lot was another stroke of genius.  IT scrambled for days. The payload was signed with the lead developer's private key.  Tough luck. It took them ages to discover the SSH connections to Ukraine.

Petty annoyances were also in my repertoire. Hiding toilet paper.  Eating someone's lunch and leaving the remnants on the intern's desk.  Setting the microwave popcorn for 20 minutes.  An old iPod in the ceiling, connected to a cheap speaker, played a barely audible, high-pitched squeal on repeat (that one I had to endure myself).

I'd move items from Bob's desk to Alice's, sometimes right in front of them, using a little something called misdirection.  It rolls off the tongue, doesn't it? Say it with me: Misdirection. See? You didn't even notice I misspelled it the first time.

I submitted my (fabricated) reports on time, always with a slap on the back and a hearty greeting for everyone.  Doughnuts and cookies were my stock-in-trade.  Nobody ever realized I wasn't on the payroll.

Within months, the office was a haven of paranoia and exhaustion.  That's where I failed. My unwavering optimism became a source of further irritation.  But by then, I'd cost them thousands of dollars, several valuable employees, and all of their morale. Glorious.

Perhaps later I'll share the story of how they hired me to target their competitor, Synergistic Proactive Associates, to gain that "little edge."  I always say, work through third parties. Never let them see your face. Social engineering. Say it with me.

The media's portrayal of Chris Watts, the man accused of murdering his pregnant wife and two young daughters, is deeply disturbing.  Articles often feature smiling family photos and headlines painting him as a devoted family man, a stark contrast to the horrific crimes he is charged with. This portrayal is problematic, to say the least.

Watts, 33, allegedly murdered his 15-weeks-pregnant wife, Shanann, and their daughters, 4-year-old Bella and 3-year-old Celeste, while reportedly having an affair with a co-worker. Yet, his mugshot is rarely the featured image. Instead, media outlets often use photos from Shanann's Facebook account, seemingly capitalizing on the relatable image of a happy family to attract clicks.  Is this an attempt to draw readers in by playing on the dissonance between the image and the horrific reality?

This preferential treatment is even more unsettling when compared to media portrayals of other cases, as Shaun King highlighted.  He pointed out the lack of humanizing coverage given to a father who sought vigilante justice for his daughter, a rape victim, compared to the sympathetic portrayal sometimes afforded to Watts.  This disparity raises serious questions about the influence of "white privilege" in media narratives.

We are not alone in our concern.  A quick search online reveals widespread criticism of this biased portrayal.  We must call for change and hold the media accountable. When we see this type of inequitable representation, we need to point it out and demand better.  Using a smiling family photo and quotes from acquaintances describing Watts as a devoted father, like those featured in a recent People Magazine article,  only serves to obscure the horrific nature of his alleged crimes.  Quotes like, â€œItâ€™s beyond belief, reallyâ€¦ I never saw this coming,â€ from Kris Landon, further perpetuate this misleading image.

In the town of Yardel, during the 27th year of King Ionil II's glorious reign, stood a tall tower shrouded in secrets.  Etched above its entrance, in the script of the Elder Tongue, were the words "Scholar's Stone." Within resided two men. One was known as Ynvarg, though none believed this ancient name, a relic of the era when wild magic was tamed and bound to human will, was truly his birth name.  Ancient Ynvarg suffered frequent, racking coughs that left him weakened and in pain, yet he possessed profound wisdom and spoke the Elder Tongue as fluently as his native language.

The other, a sixteen-year-old bastard boy named Ulthir, served as Ynvarg's apprentice, learning the intricacies of magic and its command through the Elder Tongue. One day, the youth approached his master. "Ynvarg," he asked, "are you my father?"  A subtle smile touched Ynvargâ€™s lips.  "And what makes you think so, young one?"

"My father vanished during the Destruction of Morgshold," Ulthir explained, "but I always sensed he lived.  I feel drawn to you, a familiarity, and we share a similar look. Yet, that wasn't enough to raise suspicion. There's more. My mother never revealed my father's name, but I found it in old letters: Vayar.  And what name did the wild witch use when she bound you with your true name? Vayar.  Then there's this."  Ulthir produced two deep red stones and touched them together. They glowed with an unnatural light. "Blood stones. Made from our blood. They glow when touched by kin."

"I hope you didn't pilfer my essence while I slept.  I need every drop of red life I can get," Ynvarg quipped.

"Of course not," Ulthir retorted. "I took it when I cleaned up after your little mishap with the summoned imp.  We share blood, and you share my father's name. So please, just tell me. Are you my father?" Tears welled in the boy's eyes as he pleaded for honesty and connection.  Ynvargâ€™s expression became strained, as if suppressing laughter during a solemn rite.

"My boy, I can offer little.  But I have two pieces of advice.  First, when you yearn for a home, you shall find it on the banks of the River Eidir.

For all the pomp and circumstance, this place was surprisingly dreary.  Ancient candelabras dripped stalactites of wax.  Couldn't they have at least dusted? Sniffling and sneezing hardly befit a mighty warrior.

A dull clang ordered us into line â€“ half a dozen men and women resembling Greek statues in their perfection, andâ€¦ me. On a good day, I resemble a well-loved armchair â€“ short and squishy.  I wouldn't say I'm unattractive, just not someone you'd display in the front parlor, if you catch my drift.  But looks mean nothing to the Committee. So, here I am.

â€œPsst. Hey.â€

Who would be goofing off on such an important day?

â€œHey.â€

I glanced to my left. Nothing but another faded, moldy tapestry. I tried to focus on the cloaked figure droning on with his congratulatory speech.

â€œCome *here*!â€

When they said our weapon would â€œcallâ€ to us, they failed to mention the hearing voices part.  That seems like pertinent information now.

â€œNo, hey! Wait, actually! Yeah, that's how it's supposed to go, right? You wait until he says so. Oh! This is so exciting! No one's heard me in hundreds of years! I'm back!â€

Apparently, I'd already been chosen.  And, no lie, being first is pretty thrilling.

Another clang of the bell. We filed forward one by one. The Adonis at the front wandered for what felt like an eternity before selecting Zeus's Bolt.  Figures.  The Amazonian woman after him took even longer before a spear of bones chose her.  One by one, my classmates were chosen, each weapon more ferocious than the last. The process took hours, and the entire time, the voice to my left chattered incessantly.

â€œStill here, yup! Just pull the curtain back! Oh, I probably look terrible. Don't hold that against me, please!â€

Finally, my turn.

â€œYay!â€

I grabbed a fistful of tapestry, took a deep breath, and yanked it back.  Behind it was a rather plain golden bow and quiver.

â€œI am Cupidâ€™s Bow, and Iâ€™m looking forward to working with you!â€

The question of whether randomized algorithms offer a fundamental advantage over deterministic ones is a central problem in computer science, encapsulated by the unresolved conjecture P = BPP.  P represents problems solvable deterministically in polynomial time, while BPP encompasses problems solvable by randomized algorithms in polynomial time with bounded error probability.  The prevailing belief is that P = RP = CoRP = BPP, suggesting randomness offers no significant advantage. This belief stems from deep connections between complexity theory, circuit lower bounds, and pseudorandom generators.

While a direct proof of P = BPP remains elusive, a more manageable approach is to focus on specific problems with known randomized but unknown deterministic polynomial-time algorithms.  One such problem is the Exact Matching problem (Em), introduced by Papadimitriou and Yannakakis in 1982.  Em asks whether, given a graph with red and blue edges and an integer k, a perfect matching exists with exactly k red edges.  Mulmuley et al. demonstrated a randomized polynomial-time solution in 1987, yet a deterministic counterpart remains undiscovered.  Each "derandomization" of a randomized algorithm provides further evidence towards the validity of P = BPP.  A prominent example is the deterministic primality testing algorithm developed by Agrawal, Kayal, and Saxena in 2002.

Interestingly, Em is connected to another problem in BPP lacking a deterministic polynomial-time algorithm: Polynomial Identity Testing (Pit).  Pit determines if a given polynomial, represented by an algebraic circuit, is identically zero.  The Schwartz-Zippel Lemma places Pit within CoRP, implying a deterministic polynomial-time algorithm should exist if CoRP = P. However, Kabanets and Impagliazzo suggest derandomizing Pit is difficult, potentially requiring breakthroughs in proving circuit lower bounds.  Existing randomized algorithms for Em utilize Pit as a subroutine or employ the Isolation Lemma, both placing Em within RP.

Em has seen deterministic polynomial-time solutions on specific graph classes, including bounded tree-width graphs, K3,3-minor free graphs, and graphs of bounded genus, often employing Pfaffian orientations.  Approximation results also exist, such as Yuster's deterministic algorithm for finding almost exact matchings in YES-instances.

Despite the lack of a complete derandomization, Em remains relevant.  Over the past decade, it has appeared in various contexts, including budgeted, color-bounded, and constrained matching; multicriteria optimization; matroid intersection; binary linear equation systems; recoverable robust assignment; and planarizing gadgets for perfect matchings.  A full derandomization of Em would often derandomize related results in these areas.  Its inclusion as an open problem in influential work on the parallel computation complexity of the matching problem has further contributed to its continued relevance.  This sustained interest underscores the importance of Em within theoretical computer science and the ongoing pursuit of a deterministic solution.

Driverless cars are rapidly approaching reality, as detailed in "Driverless Cars Are Coming."  However, I remain unconvinced that they are ready for widespread adoption. While the technology holds promise, significant safety concerns must be addressed before these vehicles can safely navigate our roads.

The article proposes two primary approaches to driverless navigation: "smart roads" and sensor-equipped vehicles.  The "smart roads" concept, involving embedding electrical cables or magnets in the road, as explored by General Motors and Berkeley engineers, presents logistical and financial obstacles.  Rebuilding every road globally is simply impractical. Furthermore, this approach fails to address how these vehicles would operate on roads lacking these modifications.

The alternative involves equipping cars with sensors, lasers, and receivers, as demonstrated by the Toyota Prius.  While seemingly more feasible, this approach relies heavily on artificial intelligence.  The critical question remains: can AI match human intelligence and reaction time in complex situations?  Can it respond effectively to unexpected events like a deer crossing the road, a cyclist, a child's ball, or even a pothole?  These scenarios demand split-second decisions that current AI may struggle to handle.

Even with a human driver present, as the article suggests, the potential for distraction remains a significant concern.  Buzzing or flashing lights intended to alert the driver to potential hazards could easily be ignored or, worse, exacerbate panic and hinder effective response.  Over-reliance on automation could lead to driver inattention, negating the supposed safety benefits.

The article positions driverless cars as a solution for preventing drunk driving. However, this argument overlooks a crucial point: impaired "drivers" are incapable of taking control in emergencies.  The distractions presented by the car's systems would further hinder their ability to react, potentially turning a supposedly safe option into a dangerous one.  Traditional alternatives like taxis or designated drivers offer more reliable safeguards.

Ultimately, the current state of driverless car technology presents more risks than benefits.  While the technology holds long-term potential, relying solely on artificial intelligence and sensors is premature.  Too many unpredictable scenarios could compromise the safety of both passengers and pedestrians.

The old manâ€™s gaze, intense and unwavering, bore into Jim.  It felt like an eternity under the scrutiny of those eyes, wise with nearly three-quarters of a century. The silence stretched, taut and painful. With each tick of the clock, Jimâ€™s hope dwindled, the sense of impending doom growing stronger. When the old man finally spoke, his voice was a harsh rasp.

"You fucked up, Jimbo."

Jim nodded, speechless.  There was no denying it. He had.

"We went over it three times. All you had to do was wait for the guys, then drive away when they got in the car."

Jim nodded again, starting to speak, but the old manâ€™s hand lashed out with a speed that belied his age, striking Jimâ€™s mouth.  A searing pain shot through Jimâ€™s head, and he winced.  The old man settled back, his gaze once more fixed on Jim. "What should I do with you, Jimbo?"

Jim looked at the old man dolefully.  A slight nod gave him permission to speak.  He stuttered, then found his voice. "I guess letting me go is out of the question."

He searched the old manâ€™s face for a reaction, but the old man simply stared blankly, leaning back in his chair, hands folded over his belly. Jim tried again. "Could I at least get something to drink?"

The old manâ€™s voice was devoid of emotion.

It had been a long time since Chris had written anything, but he pressed on, hoping for the best.  He knew his tenses might be a bit off, but this was just a quick account. He needed to get this story down.

Chris knew he had to do something for Moe.  They'd been inseparable since grade school, weathering life's ups and downs together. Girls had come and gone for both of them, but this time was different.  This one had shattered Moe. After three and a half years, Lindsey had thrown it all away in a single, stupid night.  Moe wasn't the type to get angry or vengeful.  He hadn't yelled, hadn't even raised his voice. Kind, emotional, and forgiving, Moe had poured his heart into making the relationship work.  But ultimately, he couldn't live with the betrayal.  He still loved her, even now, but the *in* love was gone. That was the part that truly broke him. The hurt, the betrayal, the indelible images of the woman he thought he'd spend his life withâ€¦ those were the wounds that wouldnâ€™t heal.

Since ending things on Thursday â€“ the day that marked both the end of the happiest period of his life and the beginning of his despair â€“ Moe hadn't left his apartment. Chris wanted to give him space, but he also knew he was the only one who could pull Moe out of this abyss.  An invitation to a coworker's party seemed like the perfect opportunity.

That afternoon, Chris went to Moeâ€™s apartment, unannounced.  He knocked, called out, hoping a familiar voice would offer some comfort.  Moe just told him to go away. Undeterred, Chris used his spare key and let himself in. He found Moe lying on the couch in his underwear, the stale air suggesting heâ€™d been there for a while.  Immediately, Chris started barking orders.  "Take a shower, get dressed, comb your hair," he demanded. "I'm taking you to lunch, and we're going out tonight." Moe refused.  "Dude, you have to leave this apartment sometime. My coworker, Dave, is having a party tonight, and we're going.  I already told him I'm bringing you.  He's excited to meet you.  There will be people, beer, and weed."  Moe still refused.  Chris tried a softer approach. "At least clean yourself up and let me take you to lunch. You need to eat. We can talk."  Finally, Moe agreed.

At the corner pub, they ordered burgers and a bucket of beer. They avoided any mention of Lindsey or Moeâ€™s heartbreak. After a few Coors, it felt like old times. They talked sports, video games, moviesâ€¦ Chris could see the tension easing in his friend.  He finally broached the subject of the party, and Moe accepted.  A quick stop at the liquor store, and they were on their way to Daveâ€™s.  Arriving with a case of beer and a bottle of whiskey, they found the party already in full swing.  They navigated through the crowd, Moe recognizing a few familiar faces â€“ inevitable in a small town.  Finally, they reached the kitchen where Dave was talking to some guests.  He spotted Chris and immediately broke off his conversation to greet them.

After introductions and a few shots, the group dispersed to mingle.  Chris and Moe headed to the basement, where they ran into more of Chrisâ€™s coworkers. Chris noticed a girl, Abby, openly flirting with Moe, but Moe clearly wasn't ready. They moved to the other room, and then Moe stopped dead.  There, on the couch, looking utterly out of place, sat Lindsey, a red cup clutched in her hand, listening uncomfortably as her friends chatted.

Once a year, everyone who turns eighteen takes a test. This test determines their future role in society: Hero, Villain, NPC, or Monster.  My parents were both Heroes and members of the Sock Monkey Guild. My mother was a Shieldmaiden, and my father is a Shinobi.  We lost Mom a few months ago during the last Troll War. Apparently, they'd been messaging each other online for months before I was born.

Let's be clear: my grades have never been good. I was convinced I'd fail the test and be condemned to life as a Monster.  The transformation is permanent, and while your children are born human, they too face the test and the risk of monstrous transformation.

For weeks, Dad had been drilling me relentlessly.  Standing in line, sandwiched between a guy who reeked of troll and my best friend, Lori Taylor, my mind went blank.

Lori and I have been inseparable since second grade, when her family moved here. She's saved me countless times and is incredibly bright. I could hear her muttering to herself, something about, "The Troll rebellion lasted anywhere from five to twelve months. Three plus five is eight. The current King is Quinten..."

The line inched forward slowly. This year saw record turnout. Even after the test, we wouldn't know the results for a week, until they were posted in the town square. I wondered how many of these kids would be transformed into monsters. I was almost certain Iâ€™d be among them, yet I desperately wanted to live up to my parentsâ€™ legacy.

"Freya Moonstone," a blonde woman called. In case you're wondering, I have no idea how my parents chose my name, or if it was somehow assigned to me.

"Here," I called back. I was led down to a dimly lit chamber where a small man waited.

"Everyone has magical capabilities, though typically minimal.  There was once a race of beings composed almost entirely of magic, but they haven't been seen for generations. This test measures your magical potential."  He led me to a desk with a ping-pong ball and a set of cups. "All you have to do is move the ping-pong ball through the cups using only your mind, while blindfolded."

The article "Driverless Cars Are Coming" promotes the idea of autonomous vehicles, but I believe human drivers should remain in control.  The current system has worked, so why abandon it?  Driverless cars present several significant problems.

First, these vehicles lack the common sense of a human driver and cannot handle complex traffic situations. As mentioned earlier, a driverless car might not appropriately respond to unexpected roadwork or other hazards.  Imagine a driver falling asleep at the wheel, relying on the car's automation, only to be jolted awake by a collision caused by the car's inability to navigate the situation.  The driver would ultimately be responsible for any resulting injuries or fatalities.  What if the car encountered an accident scene?  It might not react appropriately and could even become part of the incident, again leaving the human "driver" liable.

Second, driverless cars rely on computers, which are inherently prone to malfunction.  Computers crash, require reboots, and sometimes simply stop working.  Just as a student might lose a school project due to a computer malfunction, a driverless car's systems could fail while on the road.  Picture this: the "driver" is asleep, relying on the automation, and the car's computer shuts down. The result could be a catastrophic accident.

These examples of driverless cars failing to handle complex traffic situations and the inherent risk of computer malfunction illustrate why this technology is not ready for public use.

North Korea is gearing up for a major military parade, likely to coincide with the 75th anniversary of the Workers' Party of Korea on October 10.  Satellite imagery from August 31, released by the Stimson Center, reveals troops and vehicles practicing maneuvers at the Mirim Parade Training Grounds outside Pyongyang.  Hundreds of vehicles and thousands of troops are visible in the images, practicing formations in the facility.

These anniversaries are traditionally celebrated with large-scale military parades in Kim Il-sung Square, attended by thousands of citizens.  Dan Pinkston, a professor of international relations at Troy University's Seoul campus, explains, "These anniversaries are very important to the leadership in Pyongyang. They celebrate with symbolism." He adds, "We know they have been working on a lot of new weapons systems and upgrading others, including rocket artillery, unmanned aerial vehicles, and guided missiles. It will be a political decision on whether to put them on display at the parade, but it's what they have done in the past.â€  For instance, a new intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) was showcased on a tractor-trailer launcher during the 2017 parade celebrating the birth anniversary of Kim Il-sung, the country's founder and grandfather of current leader Kim Jong-un.

The Stimson Center's analysis describes hundreds of vehicles parked near the training facilities and thousands of troops in formation.  Recent improvements at the Mirim training grounds include permanent garages replacing temporary tents, making it harder for satellite imagery to identify the equipment within.  However, tracks within the facilities confirm the presence of vehicles.

Rah Jong-yil, a former diplomat and senior intelligence official specializing in North Korea, believes it highly probable that new weaponry will be displayed.  He notes the international attention on the event, occurring shortly before the US presidential elections, provides a platform "to send a series of messages.â€ He suggests the parade serves to project an image of military strength to the North Korean populace, despite recent crises, and to downplay the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, which North Korea officially claims has not affected the country.

This upcoming parade is anticipated to be a significant display of North Korea's military capabilities and a platform for political messaging to both domestic and international audiences. The ongoing upgrades and practice maneuvers underscore the importance of this event for the North Korean leadership.

The first Purge took everyone by surprise. No one anticipated the savagery, the willingness to turn on one another.  Then, a desperate group known as Al Qaeda shattered the illusion of civility. They broke the unspoken rule, committing an act of unthinkable violence: bombing Manhattan. This single act of terror devastated not only the Republicans and Democrats but also the nation's morale.

Hundreds of panicked, heavily armed politicians poured into the streets, firing wildly and shouting incoherently.

"Test 195-C, begin."

I observed from the glass box overlooking the vast experimentation chamber.  At its center sat the Disc, harsh light glinting off its polished surface.  My colleagues were once again scanning it, once again finding nothing. Our leading academics had postulated that mathematics, unlike our complex language, would be the key to efficient communication with extraterrestrial civilizations.  They reasoned that mathematics offered a universal language that wouldn't require the assistance of translation.

Initial scans had revealed the Disc's physical properties: hundreds of rings, each etched with even more grooves. We initially hypothesized that we were meant to run an itemâ€”a sort of bitâ€”through the rings. However, this theory proved nonsensical once we fully grasped the Disc's intricate structure.

Leaving the Disc's analysis to a scientist under my supervision, I proceeded to the second test chamber. Here, the recovered spacecraft was undergoing examination. Its design, featuring a dish antenna, was intriguing.  The original craft had been meticulously disassembled, cataloged, and replicated before any physical testing commenced.  The tests on the original revealed standard markers of interstellar travel: traces of G'ohti radiation, indicative of near-black hole proximity, and residue from various gaseous planets.  Nothing out of the ordinary.

Unsure what to have for dinner Tuesday?  Consider ordering pizza and contributing to the eradication of polio.  The Rotary Club of LaSalle Centennial is partnering with local pizzerias for its annual Pizza for Polio fundraiser.

This Tuesday, over a dozen pizzerias throughout Windsor-Essex will donate a portion of their proceeds to Rotary Internationalâ€™s Global Polio Eradication Initiative.  Ordering a pizza is all it takes, according to coordinator Mary Lou Amlin.

"The money will help eradicate polio worldwide, a cause Rotary has championed since 1988.  Weâ€™re down to just two countries with polio cases: Afghanistan and Pakistan," Amlin explained.

She emphasized the world's progress toward a polio-free future. "As Rotarians, we say we're 99% of the way to eradicating polio. This fundraiser is another push, a worldwide Rotarian effort to raise the necessary funds to finish the job."

Amlin highlighted the mutual benefits for both the participating pizzerias and Rotary.  "We're thrilled to partner with these businesses and appreciate their support in eradicating polio.  Especially this year, with the challenges of COVID-19, the increased sales are a real benefit for them. It's a win-win situation."
