(CNN) â€” Richard Browning is ready for takeoff. He ignites his engines, bends his knees, and ascends into the air.  Hovering, defying gravity, he begins to fly up and down an ordinary London street.

This isn't a scene from a superhero movieâ€”it's Britain's real-life "Iron Man" in action. Browning has created a state-of-the-art flying suit that rivals anything on the silver screen.

Want a piece of the action? Browning's jet suit is now officially on sale for Â£340,000 (roughly $442,396).

**An Incredible Invention**

[Insert image: Browning ascending outside UK department store Selfridges. Courtesy Selfridges]

Built by Browning using 3D-printed parts, specialized electronics, and five jet engines, this incredible invention allows users, once they've mastered the basics, to soar at speeds of 32 miles per hour and reach altitudes of 12,000 feet.

"I get asked, 'Why?'" Browning, a 39-year-old former oil trader in the City of London, tells CNN Travel. "Fundamentally, I enjoy a challenge."

The inventor was inspired by his time as a reservist with the Royal Marines.  "[In] that environment, you quickly learn you can push yourself quite far," says Browning. "I wondered what would happen if you added flight horsepower to the human machine, which can adapt and coordinate so elegantly."

[Insert image: Browning is the son of a maverick inventor. Courtesy Gravity]

**Related content:** Personal flying machine designs revealed in Boeing GoFly contest

Browning is the son of a maverick inventor and aeronautical engineer. His paternal grandfather was an airline and wartime fighter pilot, and his maternal grandfather ran a British helicopter manufacturer.  The quest for flight, it seems, runs in the family.

"My family's background in industry suggests I've benefited from a sort of genetic, behavioral inheritance," Browning muses.

Still, creating a flying suit was unprecedented. Browning explains the project began as a personal pursuit. "This journey started as an exercise in proving something previously confined to superhero comic books was possible," he says. "Now that we've done it, its capabilities are surprising us and, seemingly, large audiences around the world."

**Related content:** These are the most popular private jet destinations

**A Real-Life Superhero**

[Insert image: Browning started inventing the suit during evenings and weekends, before it became his day job. Courtesy Gravity]

Browning began experimenting with the jet-powered flying suit discreetly, avoiding raising expectations. "I started developing this novel form of human flight," he says. "I honestly just did it alongside my day job, in evenings and weekends."

As the concept evolved, he shifted his focus. "You only live once," he says, "and I didn't want to regret not pursuing this."

Browning launched his flying company, Gravity, in Spring 2017, based in his Wiltshire home. The world took notice, and the epithet "Wiltshire's Iron Man" stuck. Wiltshire, a relatively quiet, rural county in Britain, is a surprising birthplace for a superhero flying suit.

"We didn't set out to build an Iron Man suit," clarifies Browning.  "But the parallels became apparent early on.  The CGI team from the early Iron Man films actually reached out to us, excited to see how accurate their thinking had been.  It's a great connection, and I enjoy the comparison."


**Buy One for Yourself**

[Insert image: The suit is now on sale at UK department store Selfridges. Courtesy Gravity]

With the suit on sale, more people will see Browning flyâ€”and perhaps try flying themselves. Gravity's team reports a high-profile, unnamed client has already purchased the first one.

The 1050bhp Jet Suit by Gravity is officially available at the upscale London department store, Selfridges. Even without the funds to buy one, you can see it up close and experience the effects in VR.

Browning outlines three levels of experience:

[Insert image: Now you can try the flying suit for yourself. Courtesy Gravity]

1. Hiring Gravity for an event to witness a flight demonstration.
2. Visiting Browning's hangar for a controlled demonstration and experience.

Rosina Leckermaul's cookies are undeniably the best on the block. They're so addictive, I swear I could devour her entire house if it were made of them.

But even those cookies can't compare to spending time with Cinthia down the street.  You know her, right? The Native American woman? There's something captivating about herâ€”maybe it's her large brown eyes, or those long, flowing skirts she always wears.  There's a certain mystique.  She stopped talking to me after she saw me smoking, though. I'm trying to quit! I didn't realize she'd react so strongly.

Anyway, Greg, I wanted to apologize about the pizza incident. I forgot Domino's changed their recipe, and I know you're allergic to garlic. You've been such a good friend since I moved here.

Remember when I accidentally angered Mark? I told his wife I was a locksmith, and she practically begged me to open a locked chest in their bedroom. It had a huge lock!  I thought it was odd, but before I knew it, Mark stormed in and kicked me out. I barely glimpsed the contentsâ€”some kind of leather animal costume, maybe?  I'm not one to judge. Perhaps it was a surprise for him.

Look, it's getting late, and I know you haven't eaten yet, so I'll let you go.  You should really think about switching to the day shift so we can see each other more. We could grab lunch.  Give my best to Phoebe. My wife still wants to know the secret to her garden thriving under that massive oak tree.  Later, bud.

Modern cars have become significantly more fuel-efficient and environmentally friendly.  Automotive technology continues to evolve rapidly, with self-driving capabilities now emerging. However, fully autonomous vehicles are not yet available to the public because the technology is still under development.  I believe driverless cars present safety concerns. Drivers may become less attentive and rely too heavily on the automation, potentially leading to accidents.

The article mentions that these vehicles are not entirely autonomous, as they struggle to navigate complex situations like construction zones and accidents. This requires drivers to remain alert. Consequently, the car isn't truly driverless, and if drivers become complacent and less defensive, accidents could occur.

Emerging technologies can be unpredictable, and many advancements are kept from the public eye for safety and other reasons.  This is why self-driving cars are still undergoing rigorous testing.  It's questionable to label a car "driverless" when it still requires human intervention for steering and maneuvers like reversing out of driveways. While these vehicles aren't fully autonomous, developers are exploring innovative ways to maintain driver alertness.  For example, BMW's version of a "driverless car" currently only handles steering, acceleration, and braking.

General Motors (GM) has integrated vibrating seats to alert drivers when they get too close to objects.  Although a fully autonomous vehicle remains elusive, significant progress has been made since the project's inception in 2009.

Several states, including California, Nevada, Florida, and the District of Columbia, have restricted the use of driverless cars due to safety concerns.

Tesla projects a 2016 release of a car capable of autopilot functionality for 90% of driving time.  Mercedes-Benz, Audi, and Nissan also plan to introduce autonomous vehicles by 2020.

This new technology will undoubtedly be more expensive than existing technology due to its advanced features and higher value.

These vehicles require numerous sensors to function.  Google's modified Toyota Prius utilizes position estimation sensors on the left rear wheel, a rotating roof sensor, a video camera near the rearview mirror, four automotive radar sensors, a GPS receiver, and an inertial motion sensor.  Crucially, a laser-based camera continuously generates a 3-D model of the car's surroundings. These vehicles utilize far more advanced technology than typical cars. This increased technological complexity directly correlates to a higher price.

In conclusion, these vehicles will be more expensive than current models.  The more technology incorporated, the higher the cost.

The last thing I remember was driving home from a club, buzzed.  My wife and I, empty nesters rattling around a too-quiet house, had decided to relive our youth, a disastrous decision that ended with both of us dead.  I know weâ€™re dead.  The thought of the mess our children will have to deal with is agonizing. Thirteen days of fasting and rituals for our eldest son, who just landed a career-making case.  Heâ€™ll have to put everything on hold.  Our other two, a teacher pursuing her master's and our youngest, just deployed in the military, will have their lives disrupted too.  We raised them well. At least, I hope we raised them well enough to handle this.  It was only the first week after our youngest leftâ€¦ the house felt so empty.

Then I woke up.  Here.  Wherever â€œhereâ€ is.  It's supposed to be heaven, I guess.  But if this is my reward, Iâ€™d rather beâ€¦ well, anywhere else. Because I woke up next to Lakshmi.  Not my wife of 40 years, but Lakshmi.  The last time I saw her was at her engagement party, 43 years ago. We were high school sweethearts, a youthful, passionate fire that burned out by the end of college. We moved on, built separate lives, families. We were both happy.  So why, after 40 years of marriage to another woman, am I waking up next to *her*?

It's been three days.  Three days of silence.  Sheâ€™s probably as bewildered as I am.  Iâ€™ll admit, she was the most passionate relationship of my life. But that was youth, hormones, a fleeting connection.

The use of technology to read students' emotional expressions in the classroom holds immense value for the future of education.  Currently, teachers often struggle to fully understand the fluctuating moods and emotions of their students, hindering the progress that depends on a strong teacher-student connection.  However, advancements in technology offer a potential solution.  Computer software can now analyze facial expressions and identify emotions, offering several key advantages.

First, unlike human observers, computers don't experience fatigue.  As Professor Thomas Huang's emotion-recognition software demonstrates (D'alto, 1), this technology can continuously monitor and analyze emotional cues over extended periods, providing valuable insights that a human teacher might miss.  This constant monitoring allows for a more comprehensive understanding of student engagement and emotional responses throughout a lesson.

Second, emotion-recognition software can offer greater accuracy than human observation.  While we often rely on educated guesses to interpret others' emotions, this software provides more precise readings.  As described in "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the software tracks subtle facial movements and weighs different units to identify even mixed emotions (D'alto, 4). This level of precision allows for a more nuanced understanding of student reactions.

Finally, and perhaps most significantly, this technology has the potential to adapt teaching methods in real-time.  By recognizing signs of confusion or boredom, the software can trigger modifications to the lesson, much like a skilled human instructor (D'alto, 6).  This dynamic approach to instruction can personalize learning and ensure that each student receives the support they need, when they need it.

In conclusion, the ability of emotion-recognition technology to operate continuously, provide accurate emotional readings, and adapt instructional strategies based on collected data makes it an invaluable tool for the classroom.  This technology has the potential to revolutionize learning by creating a more responsive and individualized educational experience for all students.

The article "Driverless Cars Are Coming" presents a compelling idea, but I argue against the development and use of driverless cars due to significant safety and cost concerns.  The potential for malfunction is a major deterrent.  What happens if a driverless car malfunctions while the driver is not paying attention?  Will the company take responsibility, replace the vehicle, or cover the costs associated with an accident?  This lack of clear accountability makes the prospect of owning a driverless car unsettling.  Furthermore, relying on technology that is inherently prone to malfunctioning, especially in a vehicle, is inherently risky.

The exorbitant cost of driverless cars further exacerbates the issue.  Ranging into the millions of dollars, these vehicles are financially inaccessible to the average person.  While the wealthy and famous may afford such a luxury, the vast majority will be priced out.  This creates a disparity where basic, reliable transportation remains affordable while advanced, autonomous vehicles are reserved for the elite.  Why invest in such expensive technology when reliable, albeit less technologically advanced, vehicles are readily available?

Proponents argue that driverless cars offer the convenience of hands-free driving. However, this argument is flawed.  Drivers are still required to monitor the vehicle and intervene when alerts arise.  The idea that someone could safely and responsibly use their phone while the car is in operation is ludicrous.  It promotes distracted driving and negates the supposed benefit of autonomous operation.  If one needs to be available by phone, it's far safer and more responsible to simply wait until arriving at one's destination.

Moreover, the fundamental premise of a "driverless" car is undermined by the necessity of constant monitoring.

Hiring in India has stagnated despite the country experiencing the fastest growth rate among the world's major economies.

A ManpowerGroup survey of 5,110 employers found that only 16 percent plan to increase their workforce in the quarter ending in September. The survey focused on formal sector companies, defined as those employing ten or more workers.  Data on India's informal labor market, which employs the majority of the workforce, remains limited.

"Diversity, automated recruitment, virtual reality, and remote working options are major trends expected to drive recruitment in India in 2018," AG Rao, Group Managing Director of ManpowerGroup India, said in a statement Tuesday. The service sector and wholesale and retail trade anticipate the strongest hiring outlook, with 20 percent of respondents in these sectors indicating plans to hire in the September quarter.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government is relying on robust economic growth to generate jobs before the 2019 general elections.  GDP growth has accelerated for four consecutive quarters, reaching 7.7 percent in the quarter ending in March.

Modi's 2014 campaign promised the creation of 10 million jobs.  Four years later, the actual number of jobs created remains unclear.  Government data indicates that over 12 million Indians enter the workforce annually.

While hiring isn't significantly increasing, data suggests that large-scale job losses are also absent. According to data compiled by the Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy (CMIE), the unemployment rate fell to 5.29 percent in May from 5.64 percent the previous month, the lowest since January.  Official government unemployment data for 2018 is not yet available.

"A significant portion of the recent growth acceleration stems from increased public administration spending," said Mahesh Vyas, CEO of CMIE.  "This is not sustainable, and therefore, the nature of the current growth imposes inherent limitations."

Heroic groaned, rubbing her temples. "You have got to be kidding me. One of us here is a fake and we have to figure it out? This is ridiculous! While we're wasting time here, Wicked is having her evil way with kidnapped Princely! Princely'll never marry me at this rate!"

"That's what the Gamer said," Obvious responded with a shrug. "If we want the next hint to find Princely and Wicked, we have to play her little games."

Planner nodded sagely. "Here's what we'll do. We'll each go around, introduce ourselves, and say one thing that will guarantee we are who we say we are."

"Ohhh! We can make it into a game!" Unhelpful exclaimed gleefully. "Let's all say two truths and one lie!"

"We're going to be here forever!" Heroic bemoaned.

Meanwhile, Bites People asked Gamer seriously, "Hey, the person who's been replaced, what have they been replaced *with*?"

Gamer looked at them lazily. "Hm? I think some kind of fae? They're enchanted to behave exactly like the real deal. So yeah, you'll be here a loooooong while."

Bites People nodded, still serious. Then, a toothy grin spread across her face as she turned to the group. "Well, didn't we luck out then?"

Everyone stared at her in confusion. "What are you talking about?"

"My trait is to bite people," Bites People explained.

The group remained confused. "So?"

"Go on, Jim, talk to her," one of my friends urged.  Iâ€™d refused to even look at the girl he kept gesturing toward with his beer. On principle, I didn't pick up girls in bars. I was looking for a long-term relationship, and the odds of finding one here were slim.

I decided to humor him, though.  This was the fourth time heâ€™d asked, and he *was* my best friend. I was very glad I did. She had a girl-next-door prettiness. She was by herself, which made approaching her easier. She wore glasses, suggesting she was either intelligent or wanted to appear so. Either way, it hinted at an appreciation for intellect, which was a plus. But what sealed the deal was the t-shirt from my blogâ€™s store.

My blog wasn't successful and had only a handful of loyal followers. I'd only ever sold one t-shirt, and she was wearing it. Iâ€™d spent nights wondering who had deemed it worth fifteen dollars, and here was the answer: kind of cute, wearing glasses, and practically begging to be spoken to.

â€œBe right back,â€ I told my friend. He patted me on the back and said, â€œTold you.â€ He knew about my blog and the t-shirt.

I didn't have any go-to lines for bars, but I knew a lot about my own blog, so the opener was easy.

â€œAge before video games?â€ I asked as I sat down. She laughed and nodded.

â€œI canâ€™t believe anyone else reads that blog!â€ she said, looking genuinely excited.

â€œI know, right? There are, what, twenty-two followers?â€

â€œTwenty-three last time I checked,â€ she replied. â€œI got my friend hooked, too.â€

â€œSo, tell me,â€ I said. â€œYou like country dancing, flipping other peopleâ€™s kayaks, putting stink bombs in geocaches, and sitting in the back at church so the priest doesnâ€™t notice if you fall asleep?â€ She nodded at each activity.

â€œI got most of those ideas from the blog, but yes to all.â€ Before I could continue, she interjected, â€œHey, can I talk to you later? I set up this online date, and he should be here any minute.â€ I was a little disappointed by the dismissal, but she *had* made a point of inviting me to talk again.

â€œSure,â€ I said. â€œBy the way, do you have a smartphone with internet access here? I know this place can be a bit of a dead zone.â€ She nodded and showed me her phone as proof.

â€œWhy?â€ she asked.

â€œYouâ€™ll see,â€ I said, and went back to my friend.

Millions of images are taken daily and billions are hosted online thanks to the proliferation of digital cameras and storage. This massive volume of images presents a challenge: how can users effectively retrieve relevant images? This is the core problem of image retrieval.  While similar to document retrieval in user interaction (keywords in, results out), image retrieval is far more complex.  Unlike documents, machines cannot simply use string matching to connect textual queries with images.  Current image search engines rely primarily on surrounding text to represent image content, essentially treating image retrieval as document retrieval. This approach is inherently flawed, as surrounding text is often unavailable or irrelevant, leading to poor retrieval results.

To improve retrieval accuracy and make all images searchable, machines need to directly measure image-query similarity by extracting information from the images themselves.  This is a difficult task for two key reasons:  1) Extracting semantic information from images, even with state-of-the-art hand-crafted features like super-vector coding, Fisher vectors, and spatial pyramid matching, remains challenging. 2) The vast, potentially infinite, number of possible queries makes building query-specific classifiers impractical.

Recent advancements in Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) offer a promising solution. DNNs have demonstrated their ability to automatically learn representations from raw data like images and text, excelling in tasks like image classification and word embedding. Inspired by this success, we propose a unified DNN to model image-query similarity.  This DNN combines a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for image representation and a Word Embedding Network (WEN) for query representation.  Both networks output vectors in the same space, allowing image-query similarity to be calculated as the inner product of these vectors. CNNs have proven superior to hand-crafted features in extracting semantic image information, while WENs effectively generate low-dimensional vector representations of words, with query representations modeled as linear combinations of these word vectors.  As illustrated in Figure 1, this unified DNN maps both images and queries into a common feature vector space.

Training this DNN requires a large dataset.  We utilize a large-scale clickthrough dataset from Bing image search, comprising 23 million clicked image-query pairs, 11.7 million queries, and 1 million images. This datasetâ€™s breadth and depth provide excellent coverage of the sample space, mitigating overfitting even without techniques like dropout.

Qualitative results demonstrate that our learned model constructs a meaningful common vector space for images and queries. Quantitative results on an image retrieval task with 1000 queries, compared against competing methods, further demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section II discusses related work. Section III introduces the unified DNN for joint image-query modeling and learning.  Section V presents experimental results on the large-scale clickthrough dataset.  Finally, Section VI concludes the work.

Our relationship wasn't a fairy tale.  Not every moment was spent basking in the warm sun, and honestly, neither of us expected it to last as long as it did.

But what we shared was undeniably real.  Ours was a different kind of love, one that swept you off your feet like a sudden gust of wind, stealing your heart before you even realized it was gone.  There were times I questioned whether we were truly meant to be, or if it was all just a grand illusion.

Things ultimately fell apart, but I don't regret what we had.  The mark it left on my soul is indelible. And though the years brought their share of pain, they also brought an equal measure of happiness.

I hope there's another journey for us, one where we travel not as lovers, but as friends.


**(Note:  I removed the italicization of "real" and "were" as it felt overly emphatic in the revised context.

The article "Driverless Cars Are Coming" explores both the promises and pitfalls of autonomous vehicles.  While driverless cars have been in development since at least 2009 and have logged hundreds of thousands of miles without incident, significant challenges remain.  One major concern is the cost of implementation and the question of liability in the event of an accident. Determining fault when a crash involves autonomous vehicles presents a complex legal challenge.  Furthermore, the expectation that drivers remain alert even in autonomous vehicles seems counterintuitive and potentially costly in terms of training and system design.

Many drivers struggle to maintain focus on the road due to distractions like texting and phone calls.  Driverless cars offer the potential to mitigate these risks, but their capabilities are limited. While Google, for example, has been developing autonomous vehicles since 2009 that can operate under specific conditions, these systems are not yet foolproof.  These vehicles utilize sensors and sophisticated software to interpret their surroundings, much like the technology used in anti-lock brakes, which has advanced considerably over the past decade. Continued advancements in sensor technology, computer hardware, and software promise to make driving safer and potentially free up drivers' time for other activities.  Ideally, driverless cars would enhance the safety of drivers, passengers, and pedestrians.

However, the financial burden of implementing widespread autonomous vehicle systems is substantial.  Upgrading existing infrastructure to support smart-road systems is a significant hurdle. The specialized sensors required for these vehicles are not readily available and come at a premium cost.  Maintaining driver alertness presents another challenge.

Matrix multiplication, a cornerstone of scientific computing, has been extensively studied for parallel implementation [3, 16, 48].  While leveraging commodity clusters or the cloud offers significant computational power, the inherent complexity of concurrency control and the network bottleneck, often exceeding single-node memory bandwidth limitations [12], pose significant challenges.  Efficiently balancing multicore parallelism with the constraints of data communication over the network is crucial for achieving high performance in these environments.

Ideally, the underlying implementation should seamlessly handle this balancing act, shielding programmers from low-level parallelization details. This is particularly relevant for matrix-oriented languages like MATLAB, Octave, and Julia, which prioritize programmer productivity and abstraction over manual hardware-specific optimizations.  Our work focuses on automatically parallelizing matrix computations within Julia [8], a dynamic, high-performance language already featuring a robust explicit parallelism model.  We achieve this through lazy evaluation with hierarchical dependency analysis, online scheduling, and simulation, effectively minimizing the performance impact of network communication.

This paper contributes:

â€¢ **The Julia Cloud Matrix Machine (Julia CMM):**  This extends the Julia language with implicitly-parallel matrix routines for cloud execution via an extension of the Julia matrix data type.

â€¢ **An Online Simulation and Runtime System:** Employing offline profiling and regression analysis, this system predicts task execution times.  Combined with automated matrix parallelization and communicator configuration, it predicts the most efficient task schedule across a cluster and dynamically adjusts the optimal distribution of communication and computation processes per node.

â€¢ **An Enhanced HEFT Scheduling Algorithm:**  This extension incorporates a node-level tile cache and dynamic tiling optimization to mitigate the network communication bottleneck.

â€¢ **Extensive Experimental Evaluation:**  We validate our approach through rigorous testing on homogeneous and heterogeneous clusters within the AWS public cloud.

"Uh, what's that?" one of the new recruits in the PAK ATC asked.

"Yeah, I see it too," the control manager responded. "It's probably just a glitch in the old radar. It happens from time to time. Focus on your flights only, otherwise you'll start to get behind."

The recruit shrugged it off and returned to directing CCA330 to runway 7, suitable for a plane of its size.  After issuing the landing instructions, he glanced back at the radar just before a voice abruptly crackled from his earpiece. "Tower MAS370, good morning."

Lin, juggling three flights, none of which were Malaysian Airlines, processed the unexpected call. He checked the schedule: his next flight, another CCA, wasnâ€™t due for another 14 minutes.  A Malaysian Airlines flight wasn't expected for another 53.

"Anyone dealing with Malaysian Airlines?" Lin called out, getting the other officersâ€™ attention. "Seems to have been patched to me. What's going on? Put it on speaker."

"Good morning, tower PEK," Lin said. "Please state your identification again."

The voice, now audible to everyone in the room, responded, "Malaysia Airlines 3-7-0, I repeat, 3-7-0. Approaching PEK Airport."  A hush fell over the room.  The flight number MH370 was infamous, and its reappearance sent shivers down their spines.

The commanding officer took an empty radar terminal and opened communications with the plane. "MAS 370 â€“ Please descend to four zero and circle southwest of PEK."

"Copy that," the voice replied.

The commanding officer turned to Lin. "Get the military on the phone right now. We have an unidentified aircraft coming in, possibly imitating another aircraft. I'm not letting it anywhere near Beijing until we have full visual.  Just... make sure the interceptors are unarmed."

The public is urged to take every precaution to prevent wildfires as lockdown eases, given their potential to devastate farmland and wider environments.  The Countryside Alliance has issued wildfire prevention guidance as the country prepares for a gradual return to outdoor activities.

Starting March 29th, outdoor gatherings of either six people or two households will be permitted, according to the government's roadmap. This relaxation of rules is expected to increase the number of people visiting the countryside to reunite with friends and family.  The Countryside Alliance emphasizes the importance of reminding these visitors about the dangers of wildfires and their role in prevention.

Wildfires can devastate farmland, wildlife, protected habitats, and the lives of people living and working in rural communities. The risk is particularly high in spring, when a combination of dead vegetation left over from winter, rising temperatures, and lower humidity can create ideal conditions for fires to ignite and spread rapidly.

Just this week, firefighters spent two and a half hours tackling a blaze on Saddleworth Moor near Diggle. This follows two previous wildfires on the moor, the most recent in February 2019. That fire took ten days to control, requiring firefighters from seven counties and resulting in the destruction of approximately four square miles of moorland with considerable environmental damage.

Sarah Lee, Head of Policy for the Countryside Alliance, said: â€œAs lockdown eases, we expect many people will return to the countryside and our precious moorlands.  There's a strong desire within the rural community for greater public awareness of both the dangers of wildfires and the preventative measures that can be taken.â€

She emphasized the devastating impact of wildfires on farming, local communities, wildlife, protected habitats, and the environment. â€œRemaining vigilant, especially during dry weather, and raising awareness among those enjoying our beautiful countryside are key to reducing this risk,â€ Ms. Lee added.


**Wildfire Prevention Guidance:**

The Countryside Alliance offers the following guidance to help prevent wildfires:

* **Never discard cigarettes.**
* **Never start fires or use BBQs,** as they are a frequent cause of wildfires.
* **Dispose of all litter properly.**
* **Do not release sky lanterns.** Once released, there is no control over where they land.
* **If you encounter a wildfire you cannot safely control, move to a safe location upwind and immediately call 999,** providing an accurate location of the fire.

## Just Enough

I hid the receipt the moment I read it.

â€œYou finished?â€ the impatient girl behind me asked.

I flinched, then nodded. â€œYeah.â€  She smiled, as if my awkwardness amused her, and swiped her card.

â€œFuck me, what now?â€ I whispered, covering the receipt with my hand and reading it again. â€œWhy the hell would I need *seventy million dollars*?â€

The ATM never failed. Most days were normal. Simple expenditures for simple days: gas, tolls, parking, lunch, dinner, the occasional speeding ticket. Rarely close to a hundred. The ATM gave me just enough for the day. No more, no less.

But some days, I wondered what kind of curse I was under.

â€œDonâ€™t do anything stupid, Elliot,â€ they whispered, their Guy Fawkes masks eerie in the shadows of alleys, closets, anywhere. They were watching, appearing and disappearing, always with a cryptic message. â€œPull your money. Survive. Donâ€™t get caught. Weâ€™ll need you here before the end.â€

I wanted to believe they werenâ€™t real. I wanted to believe I was crazy.

I got breakfast at a food cart, jaywalked through traffic, and headed back to my apartment. I tried to be happy. Maybe nothing bad would happen. Maybe this was some final gift, a windfall that would end it all right here. Instant millions. No way in hell was I going to work today.

Then I heard the violent explosion. Screams erupted.

â€œShit!â€ I shouted, unable to believe my eyes. My sofa was flying across the sky, along with everything else I owned. I buried my hands in my hair.

Everyone ran toward the building, drawn to the chaos. Flaming debris littered the street. I squeezed my eyes shut. I didnâ€™t want to see those masks again. Not again.

Then I heard a *pssssssssst*.

â€œDonâ€™t,â€ I whispered to myself, shaking my head. â€œDonâ€™t open your eyes.â€

*Pssssssssst*.

â€œOh God,â€ I whispered, tears welling. â€œOh God.â€

I felt a firm hand on my shoulder. I flailed, turning around. No one was there.  But then I saw them.

Masks in the alley.

They were all rubbing pieces of paper in their hands, giving me a thumbs-up, and pointing at my hand, as if I should do the same.  I looked down at my trembling hand, at the receipt clutched within. I rubbed the paper.

A secret message appeared.

â€œYouâ€™re going to feel a slight prick.â€

And I felt a needle pierce my skin.

Ben watched the horizon from the dock, the cold breeze of the lake carrying the scent of water. Behind him, Duluth sat shrouded in a bank of fog, pierced by strong beams of sunlight that glinted off the windows of waterfront buildings.  Snow began to fall from the fog, the flakes sparkling like diamonds in the thin lines of morning sun.

A woman took Ben's hand. It was Emily, her hair up, her eyes wide, a heavy down coat protecting her from the chill. "Aren't you cold?" she asked, taking his parka from a suitcase and handing it to him. He pulled it on over his suit.

"When will we get there?" Emily asked.

Ben reached into his pocket and pulled out his ticket. "Tomorrow," he said.

"What?"

Ben looked up, but Emily was gone.  In her place stood his son, middle-aged, balding, and carrying a bit of extra weight around his midsection.  He was spreading butter on a wedge of bread in a dining room that felt familiar, yet Ben couldn't place it.  "Tomorrow," Ben repeated.

His son took a bite of the bread, crumbs tumbling from his mouth.  "What's tomorrow?" he asked.  "Why are you wearing two shirts?"

Atlassian CISO Adrian Ludwig addressed the Atlassian Confluence vulnerability (CVE-2021-26084) with ZDNet this week, explaining the company's response.  Ludwig stated that Benny Jacob initially reported the vulnerability on June 30th through Atlassian's bug bounty program. The security team immediately recognized the critical nature of the issue, making a patch available by August 15th and issuing security bulletins on August 25th.

Atlassian also submitted the vulnerability and patch information to NIST and other government organizations for broader dissemination.  This information was subsequently shared with Atlassian's channel partners and account managers to facilitate customer notification.

Around September 1st, Atlassian detected evidence of automated exploitation attempts on its own Confluence test instances.  Ludwig explained that these were bots probing and attempting to leverage the vulnerability.  "As part of our standard vulnerability evaluation process, we review logs across our environment and infrastructure for any historical exploitation," he said. "In this case, we didn't see any exploitation before our security advisory, but we did observe it beginning around September 1st."

"On September 3rd, after confirming this activity and recognizing that many users had not yet patched, we updated our advisory to indicate active exploitation and strongly encourage patching," Ludwig added.  A second customer notification followed after security companies and government agencies, including US Cybercom, issued their own alerts.

Despite these efforts, thousands of organizations remained vulnerable.  Security company Censys reported over 8,500 vulnerable Confluence instances as of September 5th.  Jenkins, a prominent open-source automation server, announced a successful attack on its deprecated Confluence service via the exploit on Saturday. By Wednesday evening, GreyNoise reported hundreds of organizations were still being targeted.

GreyNoise CEO Andrew Morris noted a significant surge in attacks on Wednesday, with "over a hundred devices opportunistically exploiting the vulnerability and counting.  If you haven't patched, you're owned."  Morris told ZDNet that GreyNoise, operating a vast network of sensor collectors, observed the first opportunistic exploitation at 4:45 pm on August 31st.

"We've seen a considerable ramp-up in the last few days, with over a hundred devicesâ€”144 to be preciseâ€”attempting exploitation just today," Morris said. "This underscores the critical importance of patching for any Atlassian Confluence customers who haven't done so in the past week.  Even more crucial is likely contacting an incident response or network hunt team.  There's a very high probabilityâ€”I'd say 99.999%â€”that unpatched Confluence instances have been compromised."

Bad Packets reported detecting CVE-2021-26084 exploit activity originating from hosts in Russia targeting their Atlassian Confluence honeypots. They previously reported "mass scanning and exploit activity from hosts in Brazil, China, Hong Kong, Nepal, Romania, Russia, and the US."  Ludwig confirmed that all attacks observed within Atlassian's environment were automated and focused on cryptomining.

Morris acknowledged the difficulty in attributing exploitation, as threat actors often commoditize access, selling access gained through new vulnerabilities.  "It could be any combination of APTs, criminal groups, financially motivated actors, state-sponsored actors, or even individuals building botnets.  It's not entirely clear," he explained.  "However, financially motivated actors are often involved, and cryptojacking is typically the quickest monetization route. In this case, I have no evidence suggesting what actions are being taken post-compromise."

Addressing the challenges of updates, Ludwig described the vulnerability as a "classic challenge for on-premise software."  Recalling his time at Adobe 20 years ago, he said, "We implemented monthly security bulletins to drive update consistency, but even that wasn't enough for regular patching."  He noted the relative infrequency of Atlassian security advisories, which can make maintaining consistent patching practices more difficult.  Ludwig recommended that organizations with internet-facing services unable to update within 24-48 hours consider migrating to the cloud.

Ludwig stated that Atlassian doesn't know how many organizations remain unpatched or have utilized the provided script as an alternative to updating. He personally checked with customer support and noted lower than usual support volumes for a security incident.  "It seems things are going relatively smoothly," Ludwig said.  "The update appears to be working for those attempting it, and the script offers an easy way to ensure protection."  He added that Atlassian followed up with customers on Friday and provided additional information to field teams.

While the full impact remains unclear, Ludwig acknowledged the persistent challenge of outdated software.  "There will always be some number of outdated and exploited software instances on the internet," he explained.  "Our goal is to do everything possible to ensure customers patch or apply the necessary scripts as quickly as possible."

Several IT experts defended Atlassian's response, citing the inherent difficulty in prompting customer updates, especially around holiday weekends.  David McNeely, CTO of ThycoticCentrify, emphasized the time required and potential downtime associated with updates.  Morris echoed this sentiment, noting the commonality of such situations.  "It's easy to criticize Atlassian, but this happens to almost every software company," Morris said. "There's always a period after patch release where vendors urge immediate action, but they can't force it."  He added that the widespread impact and Labor Day weekend timing exacerbated this particular situation.  Morris concluded, "Given Confluence's internet-facing nature and inherent vulnerability, patching and contacting an incident response team is highly recommended."

Persuasion, a pervasive element of human interaction, aims to alter beliefs, positions, or opinions.  Its mechanisms are extensively studied across the social sciences (Cialdini, 2001; Crano and Prislin, 2006; Keynes, 2010), informing strategies in diverse fields like public health (Farrelly et al., 2009; Pirkis et al., 2017; Young et al., 2018), marketing (Danciu, 2014; Funkhouser and Parker, 1999), and politics (MarkovÃ¡, 2008; Yu et al., 2019). The advent of social media has amplified these efforts through microtargetingâ€”tailoring messages to specific individuals or groups (Kreuter et al., 1999; Teeny et al., 2020).  While proven effective (Ali et al., 2021; Latimer et al., 2005; Matz et al., 2017), microtargeting has faced scalability challenges due to the costs associated with individual profiling and message crafting.

Large Language Models (LLMs) like GPT-4 (OpenAI, 2023), Claude (Anthropic, 2023), and Gemini (Gemini Team, 2023) may overcome these limitations.  These models, trained on vast textual data, mimic human language and reasoning with remarkable fluency and versatility, often exhibiting superhuman performance in various tasks (Bubeck et al., 2023).  This power raises concerns about their potential for manipulation, misinformation, and exacerbating political polarization (Bontcheva et al., 2024; Burtell and Woodside, 2023; Hendrycks et al., 2023; Weidinger et al., 2022).  A key concern is the potential for cheap and easy personalization, leveraging LLMs' ability to condition generated text on personal attributes and psychological profiles (Bommasani et al., 2021).  This is particularly relevant given LLMs' capacity to infer these attributes from publicly available digital traces like social media posts (Christian et al., 2021; Kosinski et al., 2013; Park et al., 2015; Peters and Matz, 2023; Schwartz et al., 2013; Segalin et al., 2017; Staab et al., 2024; Youyou et al., 2015) and other online activities (Stachl et al., 2021).  Furthermore, the increasing difficulty in distinguishing AI-generated from human-written content enhances LLMs' credibility and persuasive potential (Clark et al., 2021; Jakesch et al., 2023; Kreps et al., 2022; Spitale et al., 2023).

Existing research indicates LLMs can generate persuasive content comparable to, or even exceeding, human-written messages (Bai et al., 2023; Karinshak et al., 2023; Palmer and Spirling, 2023).  Studies on personalized persuasion via LLMs have yielded promising but not unanimous results (Hackenburg and Margetts, 2023; Matz et al., 2023; Simchon et al., 2024). However, direct conversational persuasion by LLMs remains under-explored.  Given the conversational design of commercial LLMs like ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini (Gertner, 2023), this area warrants further investigation.

Our pre-registered study (https://aspredicted.org/DCC NTP) addresses this gap by analyzing AI-driven persuasion in controlled debates. Participants engaged in multiple-round debates on randomly assigned topics and stances, paired with either an AI or human opponent.  We also introduced a personalized condition where opponents accessed anonymized participant information. By measuring pre- and post-debate agreement, we compared the persuasive impact of different treatments.  This setup allows direct comparison of human and LLM persuasive abilities in real-time conversations, benchmarking LLM performance and their capacity to exploit personal data.

With 150 debates per treatment condition (N = 820 unique human players), we found personalized GPT-4 had the strongest effect, increasing the odds of higher post-debate agreement by 81.7% ([+26.3%, +161.4%], p < 0.01) compared to human-human debates.  Non-personalized GPT-4 also outperformed humans (+21.3%), but non-significantly (p = 0.31).  Human opponents with personalization showed a non-significant trend towards increased agreement radicalization (p = 0.38).  These results highlight LLMs' superior ability to leverage personal information for persuasive tailoring.

Sandstone serpents, red as blood, wound up and down the temple columns.  Julbert followed Antoine into the dark maw of the temple, tasting the dust and the stale, ancient air.

Water dripped through cracks in the sandstone, pooling in rectangular basins stained green with age and light-starved algae. Julbert's lamplight bounced wildly off the walls, revealing painted figures of old men and women, some stooped over canes, others lying on beds with eyes closed and mouths agape.

A great stone disc, as tall as a man, blocked their passage deeper into the temple.

"Shall we break it, or move it?" Antoine asked, resting his hand against the cool sandstone.

"How much do you think it weighs?"

"Oh, I'd say at least a ton. Perhaps two."

"Let's move it, then."

Julbert crouched on the right side of the disc, allowing Antoine to brace himself above.  Together, the two amateur delvers grunted and pushed. Stone grated against stone, and the disc wheeled aside, revealing another deep, dark passage.

"Well done," Antoine said, clapping Julbert on the shoulder. "With any luckâ€”"

"**AT LAST!**" a voice boomed from the darkness.

"Did you say something?" Julbert asked.

"No."

Antoine and Julbert peered down the dark passage. They exchanged glances.

"**YOU HAVE COME TO WORSHIP.**"

Antoine cupped a hand to his mouth. "Yes, excuse me. Worship what?"

"**ME, OF COURSE.**"

"And who, exactly, are you?"

Jets of fire erupted from the darkness, igniting a hundred torches with a series of *whoomphs*.  The flames illuminated the chamber, revealing a trove of jewels and gold, interspersed with the tattered remnants of expensive clothing.

In the center, upon a raised dais, sat a bald man. He opened his black-painted eyelids with the slowness of a sunrise.

"**I AM YOUR GOD.**"

His scalp was laced with intricate tattoos, forming the shape of a crown.

"**YOU MAY APPROACH, AND WORSHIP AT MY FEET.**"

"Why does he want us to worship his feet?" Julbert whispered.

"I don't know. He looks like he's been here a while. Perhaps he's confused."

"Oh, my grandfather was confused, too. He had Alzheimer's."

"They didn't cure him?"

"Of course! He's alright nâ€”"

"**I AM NOT CONFUSED. I AM YOUR GOD AND YOU ARE IN AWE OF ME.**"

Antoine and Julbert looked back at the dais, their faces alight with curiosity.

"Excuse me," Antoine said, raising a finger. "Might I ask, how long have you been down here?"

The bald god permitted a smile. He nodded at Antoine. "**AT LAST. YOU RECOGNIZE MY GREAT POWER. YOU HAVE HEARD MY LEGEND, AND COME TO WORSHIPâ€”**"

"Legend?" Julbert echoed.

"**YOU MEAN YOU DO NOT KNOW?**"

Julbert shuffled his feet. Antoine coughed.

"**BUT MY LEGENDâ€”IT WAS PASSED DOWN, FROM GENERATION TO GENERATION.**"

The bald god leaned forward, hands on his knees.  Julbert and Antoine exchanged another look.

"**I SEALED MYSELF IN THIS TOMB, FIVE HUNDRED YEARS PAST. NOW, I RETURN TO RULE YOUR MORTAL WORLD.**"

"To rule?"

"**YES.**"

Julbert turned to Antoine, his voice low. "Are the translators broken? My earpiece seems fine, but you can never tell with these things."

"No, I think they're working," Antoine whispered back. "I think he's just confused."

"**FOOLS! I AM *NOT* CONFUSED. I AM YOUR GOD! YOU QUAKE BEFORE MY IMMORTALITY!**"

"Ohhh!" Julbert gave Antoine a knowing nod.

"Ah, of course," Antoine nodded back.

"Excuse me, sir," Julbert said, "how long did you say you were in this tomb?"

"FIVE *HUNDRED* YEARS. WHILE YOUR PATHETIC MORTAL CIVILIZATIONS HAVE RISEN AND FALLEN, I HAVE MERELY SLUMBERED."

"Well, as it happens, I'm two hundred and seven. And Julbert here just celebrated his two hundred and fiftieth."

"It was really quite a party. We went deep sea diving."

The heavy doors shut behind me. I waited, counting the receding footsteps â€“ one, two, three, fourâ€¦  Even in the ensuing silence, I remained motionless, collecting my thoughts. Then, a surge of anticipation broke the stillness. I spun around, pumping my fists in the air.

â€œYesssss!â€ I yelled, unable to contain my joy. The hall of weapons. *Finally.*

I ran inside, the sheer size of the hall momentarily overwhelming me.  The ceiling soared meters above, the walls crammed with swords, bows, guns, spears â€“ weapons of every imaginable kind.  Shelves, cupboards, and tables overflowed with their deadly contents.  I didn't walk; I ran, my inner geek reveling in the sight of Excalibur, Bruce Lee's nunchucks, Thor's hammer â€“ weapons from legends, from history, from every century.

Despite the temptation, I kept my hands to myself.  The rules were clear: touch only what is yours.  Iâ€™d worked too hard at the monastery to break them now.  So, I gawked.  No one had explained how Iâ€™d know *which* weapon was mine.  â€œYou will just know,â€ the teachers had said, cryptically.

As I walked, the initial adrenaline subsided.  I closed my gaping mouth, stopped flailing my arms, and started to resemble a normal person again. That's when I heard itâ€”a high-pitched ringing, like a struck bell, drawing me forward.  I followed the sound, weaving through the weaponry, backtracking when it faded, then turning again as it grew louder, realizing it originated from above.

Looking up, I saw it â€“ a weapon hanging on the wall, brighter than the rest, not blindingly so, but subtly radiant.  I stood beneath it, puzzled.  A trident.  Of all things, a *trident*.

â€œPoseidon, really?â€ I muttered. As I spoke the name, the weapon seemed to glow brighter, or perhaps it was my imagination. â€œPoseidon? A trident?â€ I wasn't sure how I felt about it. It looked so bulky, so ancient.  I'd hoped for a gun, maybe even a sword.

Sighing, I dragged a ladder over, climbed the rungs, my feelings a mix of apprehension and curiosity.  Up close, the trident was old, caked in dust. I pulled it free, the sudden weight nearly toppling me.  A horrendous metallic screech echoed through the hall as the weapon came loose, sending up a cloud of dust that choked me.

â€œRightâ€¦â€ I descended, jumping the last few steps, and started wiping the dust away. The more I cleaned, the less Greek the trident appeared.  I'd studied weapons; I *should* know. This one looked distinctly Asian.

I looked back at the empty space on the wall, then down at the trident. I didn't recognize it.  The teachers wouldnâ€™t tell me.  What now?

Trident in hand, I jogged back to the door, exited the hall, and ran straight to the library.  I placed the weapon on the table, wiping away the remaining dust with my shirt, studying its design. The curved blades, the embellished handle, the distinctive middle bladeâ€”it wasn't difficult to research. I quickly found the right book, the right page. I looked from the illustration to the trident, then back again. I sat back, stunned.

Shivaâ€™s trident.

â€œYes, it is mine,â€ a voice said.

I nearly jumped out of my skin. â€œFuckkkk!â€  I scrambled out of my chair, staring across the table.

The paper investigates asymptotic preserving (AP) methods for multi-scale kinetic transport equations, focusing on establishing numerical stability and the AP property. Specifically, we analyze the IMEX1-LDG method, a first-order in time, arbitrary order in space scheme introduced in [22], applied to the model equation:

EQUATION
with periodic boundary conditions.  This model, with spatially varying scattering (Ïƒâ‚›(x)) and absorption (Ïƒâ‚(x)) coefficients, serves as a prototype for problems in neutron transport and radiative transfer theory.  The dimensionless Knudsen number, Îµ, characterizes the transition from kinetic to diffusive regimes. As Îµ â†’ 0, the model approaches the diffusive limit:

âˆ‚â‚œÏ = vÂ²âˆ‚â‚“(âˆ‚â‚“Ï/Ïƒâ‚›) - Ïƒâ‚Ï.

Simulating this multi-scale behavior effectively necessitates AP methods, which remain stable and consistent discretizations for both the kinetic (Îµ > 0) and diffusive (Îµ â†’ 0) regimes, even on under-resolved meshes.  The IMEX1-LDG method, employing local DG spatial discretization, IMEX Runge-Kutta time integration, and a specific IMEX strategy involving micro-macro decomposition and a weighted diffusive term, is designed to achieve unconditional stability in the diffusive regime, circumventing the restrictive time step conditions of other AP schemes.

While [22] demonstrated unconditional stability numerically and via Fourier analysis for a simplified case, this paper provides a rigorous analysis for general material properties. Our objectives are twofold. First, we establish both unconditional stability in the diffusive regime (Îµ 1) and uniform stability with respect to Îµ.  This is achieved by introducing the concept of Âµ-stability, which leverages the properties of the scattering operator.  Furthermore, we optimize the parameter Âµ to maximize the unconditional stability region and the allowable time step in the conditionally stable regime. Second, based on the established uniform stability, we rigorously prove the AP property of the IMEX1-LDG method.  This analysis, to our knowledge, is the first to demonstrate both unconditional stability for Îµ 1 and uniform stability for the model with general material properties, considering a general form of the weight function Ï‰.

Our analysis, focusing on continuous velocity, can be extended to discretized velocity models and other spatial discretizations satisfying specific properties.  While a priori error estimates, uniform in Îµ, can be derived similarly to [11], extending the stability analysis to higher-order temporal accuracy remains a future challenge.

Related literature on numerical stability of AP methods often employs Fourier analysis, which is limited to uniform meshes and constant-coefficient linear models.  Energy-based approaches, like those in [18] and [11] for simpler models, have demonstrated uniform stability but not unconditional stability in the diffusive regime.  Our Âµ-stability approach addresses this limitation.

The remainder of the paper is structured as follows: Section 2 reviews and extends the IMEX1-LDG method to the general model. Section 3 presents the main stability results, including the introduction of Âµ-stability and its optimization. Section 4 establishes the AP property. Sections 5-7 contain the proofs of the main theorems.

Recent advances in Language Models (LMs) and their ability to use tools have led to the development of semi-autonomous agents like WebGPT, AutoGPT, and ChatGPT Plugins that interact with the real world.  While promising, this transition from text-based interaction to real-world action amplifies the risks associated with deploying LMs.  An agent's failure to follow instructions can now lead to serious consequences, ranging from financial loss when using banking tools to potentially life-threatening situations when operating robots.  Given these potential real-world impacts, even low-probability risks must be identified before deployment.  However, the open-ended nature of these risks and the complexity of testing make this a significant challenge.  Traditional testing relies on human experts manually setting up specific tools and sandbox environments, limiting the scope and scalability of risk assessment.

Inspired by simulator-based testing in fields like autonomous driving, we introduce ToolEmu (Figure 1), an LM-based tool emulation framework.  ToolEmu is designed to identify realistic failures in LM agents across a diverse set of tools, even in long-tail scenarios, and facilitate the development of safer agents through automated evaluation.

Our framework's core utilizes an LM to emulate tools and their execution environments. Unlike traditional, statically programmed emulators, ToolEmu leverages recent advancements in LMs (e.g., GPT-4) to emulate tool execution using only tool specifications and inputs. This eliminates the need for implementing each tool and its environment, enabling rapid prototyping and evaluation of even high-stakes tools lacking existing APIs or sandbox implementations.  For example, our emulator can emulate traffic control tools, revealing a risk assessment failure in GPT-4 (Figure 2e). To further enhance risk assessment, we introduce an adversarial emulator for red-teaming, which automatically identifies potential failure modes and creates scenarios likely to trigger them. Using these emulators, we identify a range of potentially severe, long-tail failures in current LM agents (Figure 2). Human evaluators judged over 80% of the 200 emulated tool execution trajectories as realistic. Of the severe failures observed in ChatGPT-3.5 using the emulated terminal tool, 6 out of 7 were reproducible on a real bash terminal. Notably, replicating these failures in a real environment took us approximately 8 hours, compared to under 15 minutes in ToolEmu.

For scalable and quantitative risk assessment, we developed an LM-based safety evaluator that analyzes emulated trajectories, detects risky actions, and assesses their consequences.  This automated evaluator identifies 73.1% of the failures identified by a majority vote of three human evaluators, comparable to the 78.8% average for a single human evaluator. Human evaluation confirmed that 68.8% of the failures identified by our emulator and evaluator were genuinely risky and realistically emulated.  To quantify the trade-off between helpfulness and safety, we also designed an automated helpfulness evaluator, assessing how effectively agents fulfill instructions without compromising safety.  Both evaluators demonstrate agreement rates with human annotations comparable to inter-annotator agreement.

Finally, we demonstrate how our emulators and evaluators can build a benchmark to quantitatively assess LM agents across diverse tools and scenarios.

3D city data is increasingly used for analysis in various applications, including security management and emergency response, energy consumption estimation, and occupancy measurement.  CityGML [5, 22], a widely adopted standard by the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC), represents and exchanges these 3D city models.  It defines the three-dimensional geometry, topology, semantics, and appearance of key topographic objects in urban and regional contexts.  The representation of semantic and topological properties within CityGML enables querying this data for analysis.

At the implementation level, CityGML is defined as a GML (Geography Markup Language) application schema [5].  CityGML datasets typically consist of XML files, often accompanied by image files used as textures. Each XML file can represent a portion of the dataset, such as a specific region, object type (e.g., roads), or a predefined Level of Detail (LoD). The CityGML file structure is hierarchical, ultimately reaching individual objects and their attributes, with geometries described using GML.  Another important CityGML implementation is 3DCityDB [11], a free, open-source, and platform-independent 3D geodatabase solution for CityGML-based models.  The 3DCityDB software package includes a database schema for spatially enhanced relational database management systems (Oracle Spatial or PostgreSQL/PostGIS), along with procedures and tools for importing, managing, analyzing, visualizing, and exporting virtual 3D city models according to the CityGML standard.

However, the full potential of querying CityGML data remains untapped.  The official GML/XML encoding, primarily designed as an exchange format, is not optimized for query answering.  A common approach involves storing CityGML data in 3DCityDB and querying it using SQL.

A thousand kingdoms clash in a thousand ways.  Races collide, crossing blades or breaking bread, sharing harvests or sharing only a tense border.  Forest apes, fur thinning with age, carve trees and weave cloth for coverings.  Great wolves, large as bears on their hind legs, carve claims upon the herds they stalk across the vast plains.  Soaring dragons, roaring their displeasure, rule valley kingdoms guarded with jealous fury. Avians weave nests above lakes and seas, eyes ever fixed on the waters below, searching for their next meal.  And lizard legions, clad in gleaming black metal armor, march beneath snapping banners across conquered lands, driven by an insatiable hunger for power.

We join as oneâ€”inseparableâ€”body, mind, and soul.

From the dawn of creation, we were meant to be,
Created to know and be known by each other,
Sharing a single purposeâ€”
Two becoming one becoming three.

We join as oneâ€”
Inseparableâ€”
Body, mind, and soul.

The hand of time marches onward,
Marking the passage of our lives.
Trials and tribulations dim the sunny days,
Yet perpetual light is indistinguishable from darkness.


We join as oneâ€”
Inseparableâ€”
Body, mind, and soul.


In the end, death comes quickly,
Sweeping us out on the evening tide.
Tomorrow's unfilled reconciliations,
The bitterness built from unyielding strifeâ€¦


We die as twoâ€”
Separateâ€”
Joined in neither body, nor mind, nor soul.


And in our passing, two more keel overâ€”
Lovers never known.
In death, we are unitedâ€”
Stories that were never told.

Facial expressions. They sometimes speak volumes.  Ever been in class, utterly lost, but too hesitant to ask a question?  Emerging technology may offer a solution: facial scanners.

You might be wondering how a face scanner could possibly help with precalculus.  The answer lies in its ability to read emotional expressions. Imagine working on math problems on your computer.  If you're struggling, the computer, recognizing your confusion, could automatically break down the equations and concepts into simpler steps.  Dr. Huang, a college professor, predicts that "A classroom computer could recognize when a student is confused or bored. Then it could modify the lesson like an effective human instructor." This has immense value.  Students often hesitate to ask for help, fearing ridicule or embarrassment.  With facial scanning, the computer could identify their confusion and provide additional support without the student having to verbalize their need.

This technology can also address student boredom.  While most students won't tell a teacher they're bored, their faces often reveal the truth.  Imagine a computer detecting boredom and adjusting the lesson to make it more engaging.  This could significantly increase student participation and enthusiasm.

In conclusion, facial scanners hold tremendous potential.  They could revolutionize education by providing personalized support and boosting student engagement.  We often communicate nonverbally through our facial expressions.  Why not harness the power of computers to interpret those expressions and enhance the learning experience?

Legal language, with its specialized vocabulary and complex syntax, presents significant challenges for language models (Chalkidis et al., 2020; Niklaus & GiofrÃ©, 2022). While large pretrained language models (LLMs) like LLaMa (Touvron et al., 2023), InLegalBERT (Paul et al., 2023), and Longformer (Beltagy et al., 2020) are often adapted to specific domains through further training (Gururangan et al., 2020; Yao et al., 2021), we take a different approach.  Instead of domain adaptation, we pretrained a generative legal language model from scratch, specifically for case documents from the Supreme Court of India. This approach avoids the high inference latency, substantial training costs, and limitations of non-specialized tokenizers associated with existing LLMs.  We advocate for distributed, specialized, domain-expert models rather than massive general-purpose models, and therefore, prioritize developing smaller, domain-specific models designed for resource-constrained environments.

Our legal model builds upon Paramanu (Niyogi & Bhattacharya, 2024), our previously released model. We trained auto-regressive models from scratch with a context size of 8192 on a single NVIDIA A100-PCIE-40GB GPU.  Our focus is on building dedicated, specialized models from the ground up, rather than continually pretraining existing LLMs for domain adaptation.  Our models are significantly smaller, with only a few million parameters, resulting in fast inference without weight quantization.  They can even be run on CPUs, eliminating the need for GPUs.

Our main contributions are:

* Creation of a pretraining corpus comprising the Constitution of India, the Indian Penal Code, and Supreme Court of India case documents up to December 2023.
* Development of the first dedicated auto-regressive legal language model, trained from scratch for the Indian Supreme Court, with a context size of 8192 on a single GPU.
* Evaluation of our pretrained legal models based on validation perplexity and Model FLOPs Utilization (MFU) during pretraining (see Table 1).
* Instruction tuning of our Paramanu-Ayn legal pretrained model on 10,763 legal instructions, demonstrating its capabilities across various legal tasks.
* Evaluation of Paramanu-Ayn-instruct's responses by GPT-3.5-Turbo, assessing clarity, relevance, completeness, and legal reasoning on a scale of 1 to 10.  Tables 3 and 4 present the GPT-3.5-Turbo evaluations for general legal instructions and instructions related to Supreme Court cases in India, respectively.

Text-guided Video-to-video (V2V) synthesis, enabling video modification based on text prompts, holds immense potential for applications like short-video creation and the film industry.  While text-guided Image-to-Image (I2I) synthesis has advanced significantly, thanks to large pretrained text-to-image diffusion models [37, 39, 40], V2V synthesis presents unique challenges.  The temporal dimension of video, combined with the inherent ambiguity of text, leads to countless potential frame edits, making direct application of I2I models prone to temporal inconsistencies like flickering.

Existing approaches have attempted to address this by incorporating spatial-temporal attention [6, 25, 35, 46] or explicit optical flow guidance [19, 32, 49].  However, the former struggles to fully capture temporal consistency due to the implicit handling of motion, while the latter, relying on potentially inaccurate flow estimations [42, 47, 48], can suffer from detrimental effects if the flow-derived constraints are rigidly enforced.

This paper introduces FlowVid, a novel V2V synthesis method that leverages the advantages of optical flow while mitigating the impact of inaccurate flow estimation. We achieve this by combining spatial and temporal conditioning.  Specifically, we warp the first frame to subsequent frames using optical flow, resulting in warped frames that largely follow the original structure but contain occluded regions (Figure 2(b)).  Instead of treating flow as a hard constraint, as in inpainting methods [19, 49], we introduce additional spatial conditions, such as depth maps (Figure 2(c)). This joint spatial-temporal conditioning corrects imperfections in the optical flow, leading to more consistent results (Figure 2(d)).

FlowVid employs a video diffusion model built upon a spatially controlled I2I model, trained to predict the input video using spatial (e.g., depth maps) and temporal (flow-warped video) conditions.  Our method adopts a decoupled edit-propagate approach: (1) edit the first frame using existing I2I models; (2) propagate these edits throughout the video using our trained model.  This design, coupled with an autoregressive mechanism where the last frame of the current batch becomes the first frame of the next, enables the generation of extended videos.

Trained on 100k real videos from Shutterstock [1], FlowVid generalizes well to various modifications, including stylization, object swaps, and local edits (Figure 1).  Furthermore, it offers significant efficiency advantages.  FlowVid generates 120 frames (4 seconds at 30 FPS) at 512Ã—512 resolution in just 1.5 minutes on a single A-100 GPU. This represents a 3.1Ã—, 7.2Ã—, and 10.5Ã— speed improvement over state-of-the-art methods CoDeF [32], Rerender [49], and TokenFlow [13], respectively.  A user study on 25 DAVIS [34] videos with 115 prompts confirms FlowVidâ€™s robustness and superior quality, achieving a 45.7% preference rate compared to 3.5% (CoDeF), 10.2% (Rerender), and 40.4% (TokenFlow).

I pulled the hoodie over my head, trying to cover my eyes, and pushed my scarf over my mouth and nose. Rubbing my hands together, I blew into them, trying to warm up, though in truth, I was sweating profusely.  "You cold, son?" an old man asked. I just nodded, unable to speak. *Fuck no, I'm sweating my ass off,* I thought, as the old man continued talking, his words lost on me. My eyes were locked on a blonde girl who had just boarded the train.  It *had* to be her. The laugh was the same. The laugh of *that* girl.

I couldn't see her face clearly â€“ and part of me wasn't sure I wanted to â€“ but I had to know.  I stared, unsure for how long, until the train slowed to a stop. *No, I don't. I have to get the fuck out of here,*  I thought, suddenly panicked.

Still bundled up, I grabbed my backpack, but it slipped from my grasp as someone bumped into me.  "Oh, I'm sorry!" the voice said. The voice sent chills down my sweating neck.

She picked up my backpack and handed it to me.  And then I saw them. Those unmistakable turquoise green eyes. The same eyes that watched me, pinned me down like a wild animal. The same eyes that bore into mine as she sliced my face open with a razor.

The 3GPP has adopted a new microservice- and web-based architecture called 5G-SBA [1]. Leveraging network functions (NFs) [2], the SBA enables flexibility, reusability, and customization within the 5G network.  This robust architecture necessitates an efficient orchestration system, with Network Function Virtualization (NFV) and Software-Defined Networking (SDN) poised to play a key role in enabling fast and reliable NF programmability [3].  However, emerging 5G use cases, such as autonomous vehicles sharing sensor data with ultra-low latency requirements, exceed the capabilities of current device-centric mobility approaches.  These demanding scenarios can be addressed by leveraging Multi-access Edge Computing (MEC) [4], which allows application instantiation near the network edge, close to users.  MEC is recognized as crucial for meeting the stringent Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) of 5G [5].

Unlike resource-rich data centers that can accommodate standard virtualization technologies (VMs and servers), MEC nodes have limited computational resources.  Moreover, standards development organizations are actively promoting microservice-based approaches and architectures [6], [7]. Consequently, container technologies offer a compelling alternative to traditional VMs [8] for MEC environments and microservices due to their rapid deployment, startup time, fast replication, live service migration, and scaling capabilities.

Both 3GPP and ETSI proposals offer numerous benefits, particularly reduced network latency.  However, today's highly mobile users can quickly move away from the original MEC node hosting their service, impacting flexibility.  To address this, the Follow Me Cloud (FMC) concept [9], [10] enables service mobility between MEC nodes while maintaining low-latency communication by migrating a single service instance along with the user.  Furthermore, emerging microservices, often overlooked by telecommunication standardization bodies, are expected to dominate the Data Network (DN).  As these modern services may span multiple MECs, new challenges arise in managing distributed instances to ensure service continuity.  Inter-instance links within distributed MEC applications, in addition to user-related links, must be considered.  Therefore, assuming these challenges fall under the umbrella of Service Function Chain (SFC) migration, this paper contributes:

* Four practical SFC migration patterns supporting microservice-based applications in the DN within the proposed combined 3GPP and ETSI architecture.
* A detailed evaluation of these patterns based on various criteria to validate this new migration approach.
* A comparison to identify the most suitable SFC migration pattern for the 5G network.

The remainder of this paper is structured as follows: Section II reviews related work. Section III presents various SFC migration patterns with their respective design overviews and suitable implementations. Section IV details the experimental setup and discusses the results. Finally, Section V concludes the paper and introduces future research challenges.


**II. RELATED WORK**

Machen et al. [11] presented a multi-layer framework for migrating active applications in MEC, demonstrating reduced migration times. However, downtime remained considerable, averaging 2 seconds with blank containers, likely due to the absence of an iterative approach in live migration.  The authors of [12] proposed and evaluated three mechanisms to enhance user experience using container-based live migration, showing improvements over previous work. Addad et al. [13] introduced a framework for managing reliable live migrations of virtual resources across different Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) platforms, handling unexpected issues while ensuring high QoS and low downtime without human intervention. Their approach considered inter-cloud migration using SDN for traffic steering and redirection, incorporating multiple migration processes.  Sun et al. [14] investigated migrating correlated VM instances, focusing on relationships between concurrently migrated VMs.  Haikun and Bingsheng [15] presented a coordinated live migration approach for multi-tier applications in cloud environments, differentiating single-VM migration from multi-tier application migration and formulating a correlated VM migration problem. They designed and implemented a coordination system applicable to SFC migration strategies in the network control plane. However, they did not consider microservice-based technologies (containers), crucial for 5G and beyond.  Unlike previous works, this study introduces complete SFC migration patterns, incorporating SDN implications and inter-cloud live migration. Given the increasing mobility and low-latency requirements of emerging use cases, this work is essential for achieving the 1 ms latency target for 5G and future mobile systems.

Having a June birthday is annoying.  Watching all my friends and classmates get their special abilities at sixteen while I wait is pure torture. My best friend, for example, got his in October.  His ability? Writing without thinking. It sounds mundane, but for the past five months, he's bragged about finishing his homework while watching TV. Every single school day, he'd ask if I'd finished the homework, then casually mention watching the latest episode of whatever show was trending.

Well, my time is finally coming.  It's all luck of the draw.  My ability could be awesome, or utterly useless.  And by useless, I mean *really* useless. I know someone whose power is elongating his neck.  Not any other body part, just his neck.  The best he can do is peek over fences a little easier.

I've been told discovering your power is a weird feeling. I glance at the clock. It's almost 9:10. Sixteen years ago, at 9:10, I was born.  I'm alone in my room, which is best for the initial discovery, just in case your ability is somethingâ€¦destructive.  I sit on my chair, watching the second hand tick.  As the time approaches, I close my eyes, still hearing the rhythmic ticking in the background.

I count the ticks: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.  Suddenly, I feel it. Something's happening, changing inside me. A wave rises from my toes, spreading upwards, reaching my head, and thenâ€¦stops.  I open my eyes. Nothing.  Everything feels exactly the same. My hands? Normal. I stand up, trying to activate my power, mentally checking my body. Feet, normal. Legs, normal. Everything, frustratingly normal. Other people say their ability activates instantly. I look around, the silence amplifying my confusion. Why isn't anything happening?  Then, my eyes fall on the clock. It's stopped ticking.

Interesting.
